Underrated Age of Empires game that was dumped on by older Age of Empires fans who felt this game was to mainstream or to simplified or didn't require as much strategy and felt to easy. They were way to harsh as Age of Empires 3 may not be as complex as 2 but 3 is an amazing game in it's own right. Age of Empires 3 campaign is based less on historical events and battles that happened and was more like trying to tell a historical fictional story with real historical figures and factions like the Knights of St. John and the Ottomans. The Asian Dynasties is the best expansion in the whole Age of Empires 3 package as it has the most game play mechanics and content. i highly recommend this game and everything that comes with it! This is a perfect Age of Empires game for newcomers who may be intimidated by the pacing and mechanics with the first two Age of Empire games excluding Mythology. I am so excited for the definitive edition!!! It will turn out to be so much better than the one for Age of Empires 2!!!

This game is a classic. It gets an undeserved bad reputation these days from AOE2 fanatics, who really only hate it because they're so passionate about the medieval period. In reality, this game is a masterpiece -- well balanced nations, thrilling and timeless multiplayer, fascinating differentiation between every civilization (making it very replayable), and an engaging campaign. 11/10.

The year is 2008 and I am 10 years old. I've just gotten out of school and have all the lunch money in my pocket, because I'd never eat.

I enter the LAN House, pay R$5 (less than a dollar) for an hour of time and go sit on one of the brown stained office chairs in the back. I'm not here to read and write emails, and I don't have friends to play CS 1.6 over LAN, so Age of Empires 3 it is.

Unironically, I had decided to follow my Dad's advice to stop playing violent video games (GTA San Andreas) after he found out what I'd been spending my lunch money on. Play something educational and real instead, he said. Naturally, a game about pillage and conquest; New World Order conspiracies; and hundreds of bodies seemed a better fit so I fired this up instead.

Ten year old me was never good at resource management, so finishing the campaign took an obscene amount of time, if I didn't get frustrated with a mission and call in cheats instead.

Skirmish mode kept me busier for even longer, but it was all the same and it grew boring eventually. Factions had a few different units a piece, but to be competitive you had to collect cards for each nation. Cards allowed you to send provisions to your colony, such as resources or powerful units, that you couldn't get elsewhere. The only way to collect new cards was by playing each nation, putting you at a disadvantage compared to a high level nation that you'd been playing for a while. And some cards took a long, long, long time to acquire. It didn't help that the AI was very passive on the lower difficulties, or a souped up monster on the higher ones (because it cheated). 

Returning to it nearly 12 years later has been nostalgic, but not in a good way. Limits that were there before are still there. Limited cards in your deck, limited unit counts, limited buildings, limited outposts, limited ships... Naturally, there are mods that address this, but I wanted the experience as intended. The campaign itself has good structure, but the missions usually boil down to a simple formula. You, the player, start at a very disadvantaged and underpowered position and have to go fetch, build, or destroy something. There's not a lot of variety to it. And when they do try to add variety, such as the mission in the Andes it is just plain awful. For example, in that mission you have to go hopping from campfire to campfire to avoid dying from exposure. On top of that, you can't recruit any soldiers, just 'find' them on the map. Perhaps a good mission for Company of Heroes, which is a game all about tactics. But in AOE 3, you often have little control over your units and who they attack. And if you try moving them away, most units slow down to a crawl, so the enemy can hit them without taking damage (even cavalry).

Overall, I'm happy with the entertainment this provided to me as a kid. But, now this one needs to go back in the dusty old toy bin of sacred childhood memories.

6.5/10

This game is something else. The graphics are striking even today, with really cook Havok-based physics, sweet graphics, it has a soothing effect stemming from its setting, the wonderful map design and down to its artistic style that make it a great game. The saddest thing about the game's history is that its developer Ensemble Studios has been shut down by Microsoft (the utter despicable cretins), but the best thing is that Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is dropping on the 15th of October. 
From a gameplay standpoint, it is very complex, expansive, the Home City Card Deck is a strategy-deciding element and you are extremely motivated to play the game a lot, only to unlock cards and build your deck. You end up with utterly unlike decks if you are going against one opponent, if you are part of a team, if you play on water or land or if you decide to rush, turtle or boom. 
All-in-all: Awesome Game with almost endless replayability, thanks to it being a package in which you can fight your very own way by using your own strategy and perks. 
11/11 I will always recommend it and Definitive Edition will fix any crappy ESO internet matchmaking issue, to make it even Awesomer! \m/

"Age of Empires III" was once thought to be the swan song of a very admirable and endlessly enjoyable classic real-time strategy series, but now it just remains as a very quality entry in that now revived franchise.

"Age of Empires III: Complete Edition" is a game which holds the core game along with all the released expansions packs, including "Age of Empires III: The WarChiefs" and "Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties", both of which are quality additions to the main experience. Though this is not in the same vein as the "Civilization" series in terms of complexity, this game is still undoubtedly strong in its own right, however it ends up being a more mainstreamed alternative experience, even when compared to its predecessors. Nonetheless, this game is still more than quality, especially if you want to sit down for an hour or two rather than multiple hours in a single match. The nationalities all have their own distinct leader and culture, and have advantages to be wary of, as well as disadvantages that you can exploit given you tackle the enemy right. The graphics are nothing to look down upon either, even by today's standards, as it beautifully paints these colonial battlefields on which you and your enemy's blood will spill. 

There are a couple of grips I have with this game, and one specifically with this Steam version. The first that applies to any version you get is the campaign itself. Though the gameplay is good, the campaign designed for the player to practice in and get something out of is subpar at best. Usually, one will just play the Skirmish mode and ignore this portion completely, as it is confusing and rather boring to say the least.The other issue that is more specific to the Steam version of this game is that there is an inability to access online multiplayer, which is a possibly major chunk of the game and a deal-breaker depending on what you prefer. Steam will give you a CD Key, but this is completely worthless in making an online account due to its invalidity. This can't be that hard to fix, but it sadly isn't surprising that nobody cares enough to fix these issues with an over a decade old title. Therefore, we are stuck with either LAN connection or the single player experience. This, however, is not something to loathe entirely, as there is enough content here to keep you invested and entertained regardless of online multiplayer's absence.

Although we are now on our way to having an "Age of Empires IV", this was not a perceived sendoff worth complaining about, as even if it lacks extraordinary complexity, it has helped the series remain as triumphant as it has ever been. I would likely recommend this title if you prefer shorter games and faster-paced combat, as the other entries in this series can have games that last multiple times as long as the usual hour or two this game's matches usually last.

[RATING: 7.9/10]

[Edit: Through contacting Steam support, although a hassle, eventually I got a renewed CD Key that allowed for online play, as did my brother so we could finally play this together. Unfortunately, Steam Support gave him a faulty key that triggered his service provider's anti-pirating red flags and they sent him a warning about using his version of the copy. Although this is the only case of this I have heard about, as I am perfectly fine, it is something one should be cautious about.]
full of strategy

If you're looking for an AOE II experience, this would be considered a shell of its predecessor, especially with multiplayer Customization. Instead it's more of an RTS deck-builder where you play and get allotted new cards to further establish and improve your home city. While in game, you can access your home city for shipments that can ship anything from resources to troops to you colony. 

Speaking of resources, there are no more mines, farms, and wood-mills. Instead the villagers will just automatically collect wood from the trees without having to walk it back to your village, and if you want infinite gold or food, you can build a plantation or farm, where you place villagers to constantly gather goods at a slow rate. This streamlining of the grind for resources allows for less micromanaging and more troop building and exploring.

Oh did I say exploring? Yes I did. At the start of every match you get an explorer who's soul purpose is to wonder the map and establish trade routes that help you accumulate extra resources periodically, and to capture treasures that are scattered about the map, usually guarded by enemies. Proper utilization of the explorer early on can get you an advantage in resources.

All in all, solid game, but if you're looking for AOE II but improved, you will probably be disappointed. All of the changes that the developers implemented completed change the infrastructure of the game, making it feel different on a fundamental level. It's good in its own right, but shouldn't be compared the other's in the series.

The AOE franchise has been exceptional since the very first releases from Microsoft Studios. Gamers have grown alongside the franchise and realized that very few other titles match up to what AOE brings to the Real Time Strategy genre. 

AOE 3 is superb. The campaigns are unique and the game has two expansion packs with added civilizations, maps, and features. The online multiplayer system run by ESO is still going strong and offers gamers the chance to test their strategies and skills against other in-game leaders (rulers, chiefs, emperors). 

This game lets you play god in your own little sandbox and develop it with your passion, expertise, and liberty.
A personal favorite feature is the unique and appropriate voice dialogue added for NPC’s by the game developers, which are in the native language and accent of the civilization being played. Great touch which adds authenticity to the experience.

As great as this game is, it's really not worth 37€, especially with the Definitive Edition coming soon for 20€. Wait for a sale or for the DE.

If you don't care about the price this game is a masterpiece though.

*Do Not Purchase This Game! On October 15, 2020, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition will be released for only $20! If you don't think your PC can run the new version, or you just want an in-depth review of the current one, keep reading.

If you still want this game before October 15, I'd say it's pretty good. It has 14 civilizations, a card/ability building feature, and really cool physics. If you're looking for a game like AoE2 though, this feels completely different, from the playstyle to the units.

-Card/Ability System: Each civ has tons of cards they can unlock, from free units, to new abilities. Each group has a lot of cards to choose from. You start out at level 10, and as you play more and level up, you can unlock more cards. You can also create multiple decks, like a deck comprised of eco cards, or a deck containing a lot of military ability cards. Overall, it's a really cool system that adds some pretty neat progression to the game.

-14 Civilizations: There are 14 civilizations currently in the game, each coming in a group. 
   -Europeans: The Europeans have access to the late game building, the Capitol, 
        containing some late game techs that have fairly large bonuses. They also have 
        access to forts, which are very powerful defensive structures, and they have access to 
        factories, which produce resources or artillery.

   -Asians: The Asian civs come with a wonder with each age, giving each civ unique 
        bonuses. They also have access to the consulate, granting them access for a few other 
        civilization's units. Each Asian civ has very unique bonuses.

   -American Civs: These civs tend to revolve around campfire dances, which grant unique 
        units and resources. These civs also have bonuses with building outposts with native 
        tribes.

-Graphics/Physics: In terms of graphics, this game doesn't seem too outdated. the Definitive Edition will definitely look a lot better, but for what this has it's not too bad. Cannon balls have hitboxes that send units, trees, and pieces of buildings flying. The physics of buildings falling looks awesome. Pieces of buildings are slowly chipped off as they are damaged more, and completely collapse once they are destroyed. This game is also 3D, so it is possible to rotate the camera (though I wouldn't recommend it - it's hard to move the camera in the default position once it's moved). 

-Gameplay: In terms of gameplay, this game is really cool. There are 5 ages, each allowing access to new cards, techs, and units. There are a decent amount of units to choose from for each civ, and all of them have a unique purpose. Each civ is different from the others. Each one has unique units, unique access to unit upgrades, and unique bonuses. There are lots of maps to pick from, and every experience is different. My only problems in terms of gameplay is the static population limit of 200, and the fact that there can only be 2 teams in a game.

tl;dr: I'd give it a 9/10. It's an overall awesome game with unique gameplay, awesome mechanics, and unique civilizations. Again though, I'd wait for the definitive edition unless you don't think your computer can run the new version properly (you can check at the bottom of the AoE3 DE page to see if you can run it). Thanks for reading!

Overpriced, but still a good game. A follow up to the 2'nd Age of Empires that everyone loved.

 Among many this game has some weaknesses that make it not so good. Some things were simplified, such as gathering resources - now there are 3 instead of 4 of them and your villagers don't have to come back to the lumberjack or the city center to store them. 
Many smaller tweaks and adjustments, and of course a heavy focus on musket fights, artillery and the transition from Renaissance to the Industrial Revolution and fatrher away into the 19'th Century.

 It's a shame that there weren't any additional elements added to the Steam release of the game thus far. Maybe in the future...
Controls being one of the more touchy ones. For instance, to change the hotkeys you need to manually go through each tab. There is also no Steam Cloud either.

Moreover, the persistence of the hometown leveling feels like a gimmick. It's useful in the singleplayer campaign for a sense of progression, but not so much in the skirmishes/multiplayer part. 
Also, it's a shame that the Steam release does not bring any unification of the multiplayer accounts. I always keep forgetting the login/pass for this game. Microsoft seems to focus a lot on AOE 1 and 2 remasters/remakes that it forgot about how bothersome online multiplayer can get in this game.

This game is 10+ old. But this edition is by far the best one yet (until GOG publishes it). You get all the expansions. Working multiplayer with a community that still lives. And of course that same old strategy many remember and honor as "one of the best".

The modest presentation of its ancestors passed away. I'd say that the magnificence of the soundtrack itself says a lot. The Musical score is composed by musicians Stephen Rippy and Kevin McMullan. 

If History is of any interest to you, if the New World conquests/Asian campaigns were something you're keen on, get this, especially when on sale!

There's also a great mod called "Wars of Liberty" with tons of new nations added. Very good.

As far as the Age of Empires games go, this is probably the least exciting, but it's still a solid RTS title. There are a number of voice acted campaigns which really failed to hit the mark for me, more a poor attempt at fan-fiction than accurate campaigns of great historical figures; but the skirmish and multiplayer modes are where the game finds its feet. Much like previous games, the game is enjoyable for its simplicity. The same resource management featured in previous games returns, alongside an interesting new feature of home cities, which allow you to request help from your empire in battle. It adds an extra dynamic to games to make them a little less predictable and repetitive.

I'd recommend the game to any RTS fan looking to expand their collection, but with a remaster of the game coming in October 2020, I would hold off until that point and pick up the Definitive Edition when it arrives.

Make your own custom battles pit people from different eras and culture against one another for your own twisted amusement. 

Play the campaign where you'll be treated to decent stories set in historical times, with a few cameos from actual historical figures. 

Play the skirmish mode pitting yourself against AI commanders. 

The expansion packs are well worth the money too as it gives you so much more to work with,

Before you buy, realize that there are lots of problems with this game. I recommend this game when it is working, but not in its current state on Windows 10. Right now the game stalls when saving, gradually loses unit sound, voices, and eventually music. You lose control of your grouping, selecting controls (like adding a person to the selection, etc.) and eventually the game can even lock up. Even when exiting and forcing Steam to close it can still make it so you have to reboot. I have fooled around and fixed some of the issues, but the game is still a dud in its current state. If you have an older OS you may be in luck. OK, enough warning, now a review.

This game, while not its predecessor, is still a great game. The single player story line is not historical, but is still a fun story that takes place over several generations of a family through a historical setting. The add-on War Chiefs follows the same family, but a different storyline. The Asian Dynasties add-on features 3 different Asian countries in their own scenarios. I didn't care much for multiplayer, so I won't review that. The overall game mechanics are decent. Path finding is decent, but units still often get stuck, twirl around, etc. It's easy to get attacked and not realize it. Sometimes there is no warning other than a small amount of "bad" color on your mini-map and you all of a sudden realize your base is being sacked. Difficulty is settable and I recommend Easy for people new to the genre as it is pretty easy for new people vs. many other RTS games. A last meh moment is when you realize resources are littered EVERYWHERE, and I do mean littered. You'll want to harvest stuff just to get it out of your way. Fortunately in this game the characters can harvest where they are rather than having to run back and forth to a building, so that's a big difference vs. many other RTS games. Overall a good game (when it works), but make sure you know how to get it working or that you have an older OS that it may work on before you buy it.

Even though I know through research that AOE2 is still the best of the series(bought the Definitive Edition too!), this third iteration of the franchise is my first Age of Empires game, and for me, this is a very, very good game. A good introduction, in fact. I don't play online, I just like messing with the AI, building my base until it's a fortress that I'm proud of and I'm not even going to attack until I'm deep enough in a skirmish or if someone goes aggro on me. But hey, that's just me and my preference. It's my way of having fun. And I recommend this to anyone with a similar taste. Some cons that it does have is that 200 population limit, maybe some other civilizations may have more, but I've yet to encounter it. Yeah, I just want more troops I guess hahaha. Also, maybe the camera can have the functionality to be zoomed out a bit more.

 If you like the Command and Conquer series, I'm definitely recommending this one. Not just this game either, but the whole franchise! I hope AOE3 does release more expansions and feature other nations/civilizations. Cheers!

I'd say that, despite simplicity of the plot, not the best dialogues and not the best cut scenes, the plot of each campaign has a sort of artistic quality which redeems it. 

I played single-player random maps, and liked them, too, which does not happen often with me, as I usually consume only plot-driven campaigns in RTS games.

 So, as far as my experience goes, I can definitely recommend this game.

This game has aged well mechanically. When it first game out, I don't think the RTS community was ready for many of its novel developments--at the time they seemed more like gimmicks than depth-builders. After a decent amount of multiplayer, I can say with confidence that Age 3 gets away from multitudes of redundant research and unit types, and that it instead hones in on a multitude of play styles that work well alone or in groups.

Pros:
+Strong campaigns
+Solid, highly replayable multiplayer
+Home cities give needed sense of progression/collection
+Games are easily (win or lose) doable in small chunks of time, perfect for aging or new gamers
+Most races play differently enough that you can choose how you want to win, build a strategy identity, and coordinate different styles and bonuses with human players

Cons:
-UI did not age well
-Graphics are okay as long as you don't zoom in
-Weird sound glitches that will blast your eardrums out periodically
-Can't build walls over trade routes
-Some units are highly overpowered, like horse guns (although all are able to be countered)
-Some friends on Linux have connectivity issues with Age 3's proprietary online system (ESO)
-AI does not do so well on maps that leave them landlocked sometimes

Highly recommend, even if you don't remember liking it years ago.

Classic

Not going to lie...this feels like a quantum leap backward from AoE 2.

Everything in the UI is oversized as if designed for the elderly or visually impaired - AH, but the icons themselves are convoluted enough that you really cant tell what you're building all too well.

Gone is the soft gridding system where you could measure your placement of objects in the world. Now things snap-to, which is great for building houses, but terrible for building literally anything else.

I like that my people, the Cree, have some soft representation in the game, but that would be it's only redeeming quality. 

The movement speed of all units is sluggish at best, and "light cavalry" on horseback hardly outpaced ground units. Conversely, mortar/artillery units move even slower and take up much more room on the screen.

Zooming is awful. You're pushed in about 50% further, removing much of the tactical advantage you had in AoE2. The weird concept of "receiving supplies from home" is bad. Just...bad. 

I'm highly disappointed that I couldn't return this game fast enough. I'd rather skirmish endlessly on AoE2 than play this game another minute. 

1 / 10 -  Wouldn't recommend to my enemies.  (They get one point for including the Cree)

For Windows 7: Using the shortcut will run age3.exe which is bugged don't use it. Launch Age3Launcher.exe 
and enter your product key then create your esos account for multiplayer and you will be able to play multiplayer. Once that's done you can launch the other ones like warchiefs or dynasties.
For Windows 10: It's the same procedure but installing direct play has to be done manually because it hangs during automatic install. Do a search for program features then in that menu look for legacy features tick direct play and it will install properly. Good luck!

Age of Empires III is a fine game, but in my opinion not nearly as good as the previous installment. The world looks good in the updated 3D aspect, and the factions are very interesting, but there's something missing here in terms of personality and efficiency of play. The setting is still a fantastic idea, however. The art direction is strong, and you get a pretty exact sense of where you are supposed to be and what you are supposed to feel, that being a sense of colonial adventure. The sound design is solid but not as tactile or well-placed as the last game. The gameplay itself is little changed, and the changes they did make streamlined gameplay somewhat. This gameplay is sometimes stubborn and unit commands sometimes unclear, but beyond that functions well. Overall, Age of Empires III is a respectable installment in the Age of Empires series, but not really quite as good as some of the other options available to the player. For the factors mentioned above, I give Age of Empires III a 6.5/10.

Brilliant addition to the AoE franchise, still a great game to play online to this day, with a large multiplayer community still existing. That being said, single-player isn't quite what it could be; the campaign is mediocre, and involves a strange fictional tale, as opposed to the previous instalment's memorable historical campaigns. 

There's a large selection of civilisations to pick from, all of which have a very unique playstyle. The graphics were amazing for the time, and still hold up well today. The lighting makes the game to appear far more recent than it actually is. 

Strong game overall, although lacking a bit in the campaign department where previous games did better. Highly recommend, particularly for the multiplayer scene.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#308 out of 612)... it's time for Age of Empires III.

Behold: a mediocre game dwarfed by the shadows of its predecessors.

I wish I could tell you Age of Empires III were an awful game. That would make things a lot easier, wouldn't it? But it's not quite terrible. Don't get me wrong--it's not a good game, either. It embraces mediocrity in a way that few games ever do. And in most contexts, that would be fine. There's plenty of room in this world for mediocre RTS games, after all. Just... not mediocre Age of Empires games. That's just sacrilege, really.

So, what's the problem? Half of it is Age of Empires being one of the greatest real-time strategy games of all time. The other half of it is Age of Empires II being one of the [i]other[/i] greatest real-time strategy games of all time. You can see why this is one of those games diehard fans like to pretend does not exist.

For me, personally, two things made Age of Empires II: Age of Kings such a memorable, standout experience. First were the incredibly engrossing combat mechanics, where you were given large, fairly open maps with free reign to tackle as you saw fit. Virtually any strategy could be accommodated, and particularly dynamic contests between equally skilled players could last more than an hour, with dozens of different tactics and counter-tactics being utilized. And the other thing? The brilliant single-player campaign, which taught an entire generation of players--myself included--to love history. Age of Kings' single player mode was divided between several different campaigns, each set in a different historical period (and, very refreshingly, many were set in non-Western histories which are usually overlooked in popular media). Each campaign typically focused on a specific historical figure, usually a great general, and served equal parts character study, military history, and cultural primer. The game took many liberties with the history in service of accessibility and gameplay, and while I may not, now, agree with all of the decisions they made... for the time Age of Kings' campaigns were very progressive, very unique, and--most importantly--very refreshing.

And you know exactly where this is going: Age of Empires III has none of that. The maps tend to feel small and linear, the available tactics at any given time few (a real-time strategy game with little in the way of strategy) and the campaigns, such as they are, go full Hollywood. There's no respect for the history being depicted here, nor (by extension) for the players. Where prior Age of Empires games used their gameplay to explore history and make the stories of our past come alive in a way that static text could never hope to parallel, Age of Empires III sees its historical settings as mere backdrop. Set-dressing. It's uninspiring and inconsequential and utterly, relentlessly intolerable from any game bearing the Age of Empires game.

Age of Empires III is a disgrace.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

I played this when windows XP was still mainstream lmoa.
It's a good starter RTS game for those who are new to the genre. It's simple and has straight froward mechanics which are easy to use and enjoy.
Compared to some other RTS games, I still come back to this because of how enjoyable it is and how how little I have to micromanage as well as not having to use massive brain tactics all the time. It's also more faster pace than most other RTS games, but fast as in not tediously slow where most other RTS games have very slow movement and less fighting.
It's also quite unique in the way that you get to build multiple structures all over the map and the treaty mechanic is really nice to have so you could build up peacefully until the treaty is over.

The sound design and animations holds up quite well for a game that is over a decade old as of this review in June 3rd of 2020.
There are many other features as well, not found in the regular game until it is open in the options, such as more HUD on production queues, detailed descriptions and advanced formations, which are really neat to play with, especially trapping enemy AI villagers who are deforesting everything lol.

I'm surprised that there's still a large community playing this outdated game lmoa.
There's even on going events as well as an Age of Empires IV in development as of this post, which I'm hoping to play with even more better graphics, mechanics and features on an already well designed game.

Overall, it's a great game that was well thought out, with a lot of unique nations to play and their own play styles, which is not common in other RTS games. Everything also comes with actual historical info which describes how they were invented, used and how they functioned in what era. It can be found on the description tab and clicking on the square on the top right of the description box during the game.

This review is a little lengthy, so if you just want to know why I recommend this game skip the Results and read from there.

Age of Empires III not only lives up, but pushes forward the great series that is Age of Empires. Most people compare it as being weaker than its predecessor Age of Empires II, but I find that these people tend to not see the greatness in this game. It seems in this Age of Empires the game became more realistic, in that the Colonial Era was a point in time when no longer were kingdoms limited in wealth by the amount of gold they could mine. Instead it brings in new Cash Crops, which allow each nation to produce Gold outside of traditional methods.

Campaign:
This is a great game with an in-depth campaign that goes through the stories of a Scottish Explorer and his sons/daughters. The campaign is interesting and introduces different styles of gameplay from macro-managing to micro-managing with scavenging and hording. Definitely worth the play through, for Age of Empires III and Age of Empires III: War Chiefs. Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties is fun, but the campaign has nothing to do with either of the other two expansions.

Gameplay:
Age of Empires III offers a brilliant combat system that no longer requires precise delegation of finite resources, but allows for macro-scale battle. Allowing some players to turtle and others to expand, depending on your gameplay you can grow or stay at home. Mining gold and gathering food will always garnish better results than farming gold and food. Not only can you focus different resource harvesting strategies, but you can also use different strategies in your combat choices. You can buy mercenaries which cost only gold, or even capture native towns and create tribal units. This can allow you to vary your tactics based on your environment as well as your team.

Teams:
This game introduces new challenges with Teams that are complex and highly differentiated, unlike in the predecessors where each team essentially was the same as the last minus a few shifts in upgrade options and one special unit (plus two special upgrades). Age of Empires III and its two expansions offer a variety of teams which include peoples of Europe, Americas, and Asia. Age of Empires III includes the Spanish, British, French, Portuguese, Dutch, Germans, Russians, and Ottomans. Age of Empires III: War Chiefs then offer three more teams including The Aztecs, Sioux, and Iroquois. Finally Age of Empires III: Asian Dynasties adds an additional three teams the Indians, Chinese, and Japanese.

Hints:
If you actually want to enjoy this game make sure you edit your cities in order to get all the cards, as earning all the cards takes more than one lifetime. I have owned all three of these games before they were on steam and I put over +300 hours into it still to not have one civilization at maximum level.

Results:
If you enjoy real time strategy games, enjoy managing an economy, epic large battles, and don't like excessive micromanaging then this is the game for you. It offers brilliant combat with amazing scenery. The unit mapping is rather brilliant and the variety of maps keeps you constantly wanting to play more.

Pros:
+Fun campaign with a rather interesting story (for a strategy game).
+High level of variability in teams
+Allowing for turtle or rushing player types
+Good difficulty curve in AI (allowing boosting resource harvest rates to find the best balance of difficulty)
+Each civilization is like a whole new game
+On map bonuses to give reasons for exploring and moving quick across the map.
+Brilliant strategy diversification with special tribal towns on each map type, and special mercenary units for each map.
+Many different types of gameplay which keep the skirmishes from seeming repetitive.
+Loads of cards to choose from allowing you to choose if you want to Turtle, Rush, or Support.

Cons:
-Leveling civilizations is rather dull (just edit the text file)
-You cannot select your AI team members’ cards, which means they will just use resource cards, villagers, and soldiers (not team cards).
-Some civilizations seem unbalanced. (figure it out for yourself as we all have our views on this).
-Rather than producing names for the map choices they are named after states (which can be really hard to guess what type of map you will get if you're not familiar with US Geography).
-You can only have two teams in skirmish mode, which is really annoying if you used to like playing 2v2v2v2.
-You cannot have repeat civilizations; this means there is only one England per map.

My favorite RTS of all time.
Takes elements of Rise of Nations and combines them with the classic gameplay of AoE2, add a customizable deck building element, and add a dash of Warcraft 3 style asymmetry.

The economy resembles RoN, where each settler provides some trickle rate of resources, this actually makes the difference of food types meaningful as the trickle rate of farms is separated in tech from the hunting and herding ones. This is exacerbated by some civilizations having different approaches to economy (subtle, but changes game play enough to make it a unique experience) for example Indians require wood for villagers and receive them with any card from the deck building element mentioned above, Ottomans have free settlers for the cost of a slow spawn rate, and the Dutch require Gold but have a building that generates free gold.

When it comes to unique units, this game has a unique spread that really forces meaningful army building and considerations when teaming up with other players to account for your weaknesses. For example the Ottoman tree is nearly unique, they only share artillery units with the rest of the European civilizations, each civ get unique techs and unit upgrades that further accentuates their strengths and weaknesses. This leads to some really interesting army compositions, the Dutch favoring Ruyters (Dragoons), Skirmishers and Halberdiers, whereas the Russian player might spam a crap ton of Strelets only to use one of their unique civilization cards to transform them into Musketeers. Even unit tactics are diverse, for example Musketeers range attacks are great against all enemies, but for maximum efficiency you actually want to set them to meele and charge them into Skirmisher lines or even after shooting cavalry. A historical nuance that is delightful to consider.

When it comes to the Native American and Asian civilizations there is a lot of unique offerings as well. The Sioux are like the Huns in AoE2, and provide a really interesting game play variation, they are banned from a lot of MP tournaments as they are be exploited extremely well.

That is another note, AoE3 has a vibrant community called ESO Community. They have a standalone installer for a patch and provides plenty of interesting tools to play with.

Mods such as Wars of Liberty add to the content and extend playtime by adding even a new Age to play with.

I hope I conveyed a bit why this is my favorite RTS of all time. Thanks for reading.

I want to be fair with this game. I waited for this game for 7 years. Had great expectations. Obviously, we were all excepting a great sequel to Age of Empires II. We wanted enhanced graphics, a better AI, more balancing and some new mechanics but all we got was a halfass game. 

I still remember the day it came out. New campaign, new graphics, it seemed that we were all happy to discover a new sequel to the old, but legendary, AOE II. It was comforting that the IP was still alive. 

Nearly 11 years after the game’s release, I was looking for a new RTS to play with my homies. Suddenly, because I was not using Steam back then, this game appeared on my recommendation list. Charmed by it, we gave it a shot. Oh boy how wrong we were. This game was and still remains a huge disappointment. 

The AI in this game is pure trash, no improvements. The graphics were okay for its release date but now, they are clearly outdated compared to the new enhanced graphics of AOE II: Definitive Edition. What about the campaigns? I haven’t seen such boring and unimaginative storytelling in a RTS. The game is set to cover the beginning of the colonial times between 1500s to the 1850s. Where did all the great storytelling go? Why imagine something new from scratch when you got plenty of incredible stories, dated from these centuries, that you can develop? Was it too difficult to take example of the highly successful storytelling of the previous title? 

There is no reason to play this game. If you want to truly experience nostalgia, go play Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition. It is really amazing how a game with mechanics conceptualized 21 years ago attracts more interest and attention than this halfassed game.

This was a difficult decision to make, but I would not suggest this game. I would suggest Age of Empires 2. The main problem with Age of Empires 3 starts with the campaign. Age of Empires 2 has a captivating campaign based on real live historical generals and battles. Imagine playing Montezuma, Joan of Arc and Vlad Dracul Tepes. It's amazing. Age of Empires 3 is completely fictional and they pretty much introduce the Illuminati into it. It's like watching a bad Nicholas Cage movie. The balancing in Age of Empires 2 is next to none. I doubt DOTA 2 is as balanced as Age of Empires 2. Age of Empires 3... Not so much. The completely different build orders, units, strengths and the card system lends itself to giving decade long players a huge edge (and incentive to spam the same civilizations and units). A lot of strategy was taken out of the game by  removing mining camps and lumber camps. One of the very best features of Age of Empires 2 was the midgame and endgame strategy based around harassing other peoples resource camps. Ya know... Killing their peasants that tried to sneakily build a commune stashed in the corner of the map by sending a few hussars. Age of Empires 2 succesfully manages to make each civilization unique for different types of gameplay.. Going to rush? Pick a civilization with starting farm technology and extra food. Going to boom economy? Build a civilization with an economical edge. Going to be defensive? Pick a civilization with stronger buildings and walls. Age of Empires 3 probably can't really be played this way because a few civilizations completely dominate the game, and a few players who have been playing them for years have full card decks for them. If you don't have the cards then I guess you have to collect them but competitive play shouldn't give long time players a handicap. It should give new players a handicap. At any rate, I'm hating the campaign. I'm playing it and I hate it. It's depressing in every way. I play Age of Empires 2 campaign and I get to live vicariously through the great Inca warlords. I play Age of Empires 3 and now I'm suddenly battling a secret organization controlling the great non-existent battles between the Ottoman empire and the Scottish. I mean......... Seriously?! 

If Age of Empires 4 turns out like Age of Empires 3 or Dawn of War 3 I will never play a Relic game again. Relic is still one of my favorite game publishers despite their attempt to use Dawn of War to break into the MOBA esport market. They will be my least favorite if they try to turn Age of Empires 4 into anything but an enhanced version of Age of Empires 1 and 2. Crossing my fingers.

There is hope for Age of Empires 3 Definitive Edition Microsoft. Give us new campaigns, and drop that awful card system.

As opposed to other RTS games, this one's addition of cards to gameplay creates a very unique theory crafting ability and brings an entirely different perspective to RTS games in general. I think all RTS games should adopt measures like adding cards that affect the game to change the one dimensional button-mashing mentality most RTS games only have (EG SC2 mostly micro'ing skills) whereas AOE3 has a whole strategy aspect that brings to life multiple civilizations and different reactions to each match up, something games like SC never achieve because there's no diversity.

Oh man I really love this game. There's something satisfying about how lines of riflemen attack each other in battles. A lot of the gameplay elements feel very crisp. The home system in this game does make the campaign quite a bit easier but in skirmishes and multiplayer, it adds an interesting dimension to your strategy.

Despite the good points, I would not say this is better than AoE II. Everything in AoE II felt a lot more polished. Graphics were better. Music was better. And the campaigns were better. AoE II was better made, and yet it's not as fun as this one. If you're looking for top of the line RTS games, AoE III probably would not make the list. But if you want to have a whole bunch of fun blowing up columns of infantry, sturdy ships, and cannons, look no further.

Of the 'classic' Age of Empire games I think AoE III is the 'worst'. Instead of recreating famous campaigns in history, the story is about...the fountain of youth and the DLC campaigns aren't much better. The worst aspect of the game though is the card system, where you are encouraged to play one civilization at the expense of all others for EXP so you can grind for cards. 

I do play the game from time to time, but not for very long as the game just doesn't have the same draw power as the previous games.

¿How hard is to properly develop a connection system? For this game it seems pretty hard.
It makes completely impossible to play with your friends. No matter how hard you try, it disconnects, it always leaves one outside giving trouble all day.
Being a group of 4 takes sometimes even 1 hs of retries to play once. Disgusting and dissapointing.

As a single player game?. Absolutely, it's brilliant.
As a multiplayer game? Hell no, it sucks balls. Seriously.
I've had thousands of issues while trying to host custom games with my friends, it just so happens that, if you try to play with someone else that's on the same network as you are, you won't be able to. 
It took a lot of tinkering with the router settings to sort-of-make-it-work, but even then, almost every time we want to play we have to restart the stupid client 5 times until it allows every player to join a custom game. 2020 and we're still dealing with AAA games with these kind of connectivity issues.

So, as long as you want to play with your friends, or if you just happen to have a roommate who plays the game with you, it's a solid 0/10, sort your shit out Microsoft.

Definitely a bit clunky considering the two expansion packs (War Chiefs, Asian Dynasties) are basically separate games (Asian Dynasties is the *actual* complete edition, since it was the last to be released of the three version of AoE3, with the War Chiefs expansion released second). The multiplayer platform is also not very well designed, and I particularly complain about how hard it is to look up your multiplayer username (if you've forgotten it) and reset your password. Also, when you're prompted to enter the game certificate/key to authorize multiplayer, there's no way to quickly copy and paste it; that is abysmally designed. The game itself is fantastic though, and this is certainly a far better port than the Mac version! The campaigns are interesting enough, but the best part has remained practicing with the skirmishes with AI on the numerous maps. It's remained my favorite RTS title. It has been a consistently rewarding, well-balanced game that has kept me coming back to it since it first came out. And playing team co-op or pvp games with friends has kept this game feeling fun and interesting.

Gameplay - 4/5
Campaign - 4/5
Story - 1/5

It's a good game, but nothing grand.

- The nations don't feel as generic as in the AoE 2 but the map and army scales are smaller. It plays more or less the same as the previous games, with some smaller tweaks. E.g. you can now train up to 5 soldiers at once. Graphically the game looks very good and the battle animations, especially when attacking buildings  or ships, are great. That said, the game feels mediocre in comparison to AoE2 or AoM.
- The campaigns have interesting scenarios but the story is very childish and historically inaccurate for the most part. Not to say that AoE has ever payed too much attention to historical accuracy. (Quite the opposite.) There are some scenarios that depict the historical events but even those are tweaked so they would fit the made up stories. Ensemble studios probably wanted to repeat the success of the AoM campaign, but that one was full of monsters so it wasn't that big of a dieal. While fighting russians in apalachians during the early 17 century, and selling it as history, goes a bit over the line. Or fighting the Ottomans in the Caribic. There are many idiotic things like this but these are the most notable ones. 
- The expansions are good, with unique playstyles for the new nations.

P.S. I can't undersstand why they have named japanese mortar "morutaru", as the japanese would pronounce it, but rickshaw, which is originally a japanese word is still spelled rickshaw.

I remember when this came out back in 2005. I begged my dad to let me buy it with birthday money I had saved up, and he agreed. I ended up playing it almost nonstop when I had a chance. As an adult, it still is a blast to play, and that's not nostalgia or rose-colored glasses talking. Taking control of fairly large armies and then running to your base to begin creating reinforcements as your current force fights it out is entertaining. The campaign takes you to different areas and challenges you to beat the odds while rewarding thinking outside the box. The price is fair for what you get, and with no remaster in sight, this is definitely a game you want to get now rather than later.

This is a very casual game. If you play more serious strategy games, this probably offers little challenge.
I reccomend AOE3 to anyone wanting a casual, colonial RTS with musketeers, cannons, forts, mercenaries, and so on. The original game includes 7 European civilizations and 1 Asian civilization (although is plays like the traditional Europeans), Spanish, British, French, Portuguese, Dutch, Germans, Russians, and Ottomans. The expansions also include 3 Native American civs, Iroquois, Sioux, and Aztecs, as well as 3 Asian civs, Chinese, Japanese, and Indians.
The game also includes the ability to ally with natives, and offers treasures which are guarded, but grant resources, units, and upgrades.
The campaigns, including 3 acts for the original, 2 from The War Chiefs expanding the story, and 3 for each of the Asian civilizations in The Asian Dynasties, are fun and have decent story to them, but have little in the way of challenge.
Finally, you gain experience from killing enemies and building units. Experience is used to increase home city level which allows you to pick new cards to add to a deck, and gain shipments which can send a single card per shipment. These cards range from near useless to game breaking, and it all depends on the civilization you play.

Great game, I've been playing this since it came out and just recently played through all of the campaigns and wow, I can't believe I waited 15 years to play them! Amazing stories, albeit a bit cookie-cutter as they all follow the same model of one main character who gets backstabbed by another main character, and you almost always have a companion of some sort. The fictional stories are told quite well though, and are usually intertwined with historical events like the Revolutionary War or India's fight against the British, and even speculated events like Chinese visiting the New World (I don't know why they would sail Westward through the Indian Ocean, under Africa, then through the Atlantic though instead of just going East through the Pacific lol). Some of the campaign maps are challenging and unique also, for example Valley Forge has you chopping wood and building houses in the beginning with your soldiers, but you have to make sure to go near a campfire to regain your HP as the "cold" will drain your units life slowly until you have enough houses built. All in all a great game, it's a shame that multiplayer has issues with it as I worked pretty hard back in 2006 to get all my home cities to lvl 100 or so to unlock all my cards in vanilla. The expansions are great though, Japan has a strong eco, India strong units, and China just masses tons of units cheaply. The Native American civs are probably the weakest though, but that's to be expected. Buy this game, whether it's on sale or not, if you love RTS you will love this! Also to the people saying it's MORE complicated than AoE2, this game is actually LESS complicated, 1 farm for 10 villagers thats infinite, 1 plantation (coin or gold) for 10 villagers thats infinite, I mean how much simpler can you get in terms of micro-managing your eco? The home city cards and decks look daunting and big but once you read through them all and know what they do you realize most of them you will never use, and other certain cards are must-haves, so deciding how to make your deck is easy, especially when you gradually level your home city and start replacing cards for better ones.

There is a divide between fans over which AOE is the best. But I would highly recommend this title over the oft-praised AOE 2. AOE 3 may not have as large a roster of civilizations; most notably European ones, which is why I believe there is such disinclination towards this one. I feel that AOE 3 introduces a unique spin to the series with the card system of home city management. Each civ has it's own respective units, passive abilities; as well as buildings. The two expansions brought three Native American tribes and three Asian civs, each with their own unique type of playstyle. I would also like to make mention that your worker units don't have to carry resources back to the town center, they collect right on the spot where they're gathering. 

If you're at all curious about this title I'd highly suggest you try it out. Though while it is pricey for a game of it's age (no pun), it's worth it.

One of many iterations in the AOE franchise, AOE 3 brings you to the 18th century. During a time of discovery and war AOE 3 is one of the best RTS games of all time. I've been playing AOE since AOE 2, this one not only boasts a roster of heavy hitting civilizations, but it also has fully destructable buildings that fall to pieces with a well placed cannon ball. Gameplay is pretty much unchanged, build vils, gather resources, defeat the opponent, repeat. 10/10 would recommend to a friend. Plus, it has one of the better storylines in an RTS game, and the online is still fully functional with a large community of players. This is a game I feel everybody should indulge at least once, especially if you like history!

I think this game's main selling point is its single player skirmish mode.
It's somewhat like AoE 2, where you explore and expand, and stop your foes from doing the same.
(no such thing as Wonder victory or Wonder race; you win only by domination.)
The game offers several "archetypes" of random maps, each of which is based on a geographical region in the Americas. In the beginning of a random map game, you are always informed what archetype is chosen by the game, so you know very well what geographic features and distribution of resources to expect, but still have to explore as you do in other strategy games to know how things are actually laid out.
The computer-controlled players can get pretty smart with their strategies. They don't cheat and manage their units on a per-unit basis, so in battles it's often possible to outmaneuver them when outnumbered. It's not easy though, because duh, micromanaging is kind of hard, and the game doesn't assist you a lot in this aspect. Also, computer players taunt you A LOT.
Since AoE 3 is based off the history of colonization, it features a "home city" system that supplies extra units, productivity or technology in-game for your colonial economy, via "shipments". Two elements in this system make it unique (not necessarily fun):
1. In each game, your home city can only supply you a prearranged, limited variety of things. You make the arrangement before the beginning of the game, and while in-game, you choose from within that arrangement what to receive. Each civilization offers a slightly different pool of "shipment cards" for you to pick and play.
2. The more you play as a certain civilization (and its home city), the further that city grows, giving you more options as it "levels up". As a useless bonus, home cities allow you to customize their cosmetic appearance as they level up.
The game does have some other features inspired by colonization, such as explorers (very weak hero units that don't really level up), controlling trade routes and befriending native American tribes, but those are rather inconsequential.
The campaigns are decent, especially the vanilla campaign, which gets quite engaging and somewhat emotional at times. The expansions, by comparison, are rather forgettable.
Didn't try its multiplayer gameplay, but most who have tried say it's well implemented.

I like this game and I've played a silly amount of hours. If you like strategy and beating up on people with armies, then it will do the trick. 
I mostly play the Age of series, so I can't really compare it to any of the Shogun or similar titles. Within the Age series, I do much prefer Age of Kings. I consider it's military leanings and more diverse unit types to be superior to III. One thing that III suffers from is the time that it came out. Computers were not that powerful when this game was released. The developers deliberately went for a 'realistic' look to the models and environments in the game. Sadly, this game is a victim of the times. The unit count is low compared to Age of Kings and to try and spice it up, there is a card system that tries to variate the gameplay. It works, and allows you to have different decks for different occasions/locations/opponents. Kudos to Ensemble for trying to give you a different game experience and not just ladling out more of the same.  it's a valid way to try and get away from some of the formulas of Age of Kings. I just don't agree that it was any better than that game, and the lack of military focus has weakened it further. 

Another problem is the time frame chosen. The Colonial period gives plenty of story and character examples to work with. The downside is that you don't get the full range of bizzarely entertaining units that occur in Age of Kings. There were never any gigantic crossbow elephants roaming around colonial New York, and the game feels more hollow for that omission. Thankfully the Warchiefs expansion adds in Asian and American Indian units to spice up the battles.

So, to sum up. AoE III is a brave attempt to expand the remit and tactics of your now standard 'Empires' game.  There are problems with unit numbers and a lack of variety in fighters due to the history period chosen and the technological limits of when the game was developed. Overall it's a win though and well worth playing. 

I've been bitching about the game, but it's still a lot of fun. The voice actors have a whale of a time with their lines. Cuauhtemoc sounds rather un-hinged, as he constantly chants for "Blood - MOAARRR BLOOD!!!!". The voices of the other generals are suitably dripping in scorn and contempt towards you, the player. Thus further motivating you to want to march across the map and cuff them across the back of the head with a Congreave rocket. 

Although I prefer II, III is still a great military strategy game and comes well recommended.

After 15+ Years of playing AOE3, i can truly and honestly say, that this is absolutely one of the best RTS games I have played. From the Graphics, to the interface, everything fits like a glove. The only thing i still don't like are some of the balancing issues like the artillery and monitor ships being OP, and the occasional minor FPS staggers. Otherwise, almost 15 years later, this game and its expansions, still get at 10/10 from me.

The best about this game is that they got rid of all the annoying micromanaging parts of age of empires II. You no longer need to make units one by one, so you don't have to go back to the barracks all the time to keep making units. They also got rid of lumberjack houses and mining houses so less annoying micromanaging which distracts you from the action, they added metropolis cards which lets you choose your own playstyle and strategy for the civ you have chosen. Also they have a great variety of beautiful maps like for example Caribbean, which is more centered in naval battles.

no introduction needed

Aoe 3 was the latest entry into the Aoe franchise up until recently with remasters and aoe 4 announced. Aoe 3 is set in roughly the 1500 - 1800s era and mainly focuses on European colonization of America. The maps are all set in various locations in America with some extra asian maps as part of the Asian dynasties expansion that comes with the complete collection. There are 14 civs in the game, 8 European, 3 Native American and 3 Asian. The gameplay has a big focus on gunpowder units and artillery and the game is generally determined on how well you can micro your gunpowder, cavalry and artillery. It is certainly the most different Aoe, it takes away alot of the past mechanics, mainly with economy management, but adds several new ones, it still feels like Aoe, but it is rather different. You have a home city that you can send shipments from as you gain xp in the game which include resources, units, upgrades, and building wagons. This system is fun and compliments the games era and gameplay really well. You can also build plantations which are like farms for gold so you can have unlimited gold. You can now train military units in up to blocks of 5 as well. These new mechanics and several other new ones really change the gameplay, its fun, but for the upcoming aoe 4 id rather go back to aoe2/aom classic gameplay. The campaigns in the game are pretty terrible and instead of being history based they are much more character based and fictional.

Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise?

I thought not. It's not a story the Jedi would tell you. It's a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life… He had such a knowledge of the dark side, he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying.

The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural.

He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

This is great game that I have played for years and I keep coming back to it because of the smooth graphics, fun and strategic game play and UI, as well as the unique aspects of each country. After years of playing I am always greeted with a warm feeling when entering a campaign or online match. The fighting in this game is very fun and you can win or loose based on how you control the troops while fighting and it isn't always about numbers. The combat is very balanced the vast majority of the time and each type of unit can be countered by another. It is a great feeling to build up an economy enough to afford many troops and or upgrades, you can also go straight for a rush if that's your style. This game is complex but not nearly the learning curve of AOE 2 for instance and is much more inviting for new players. The graphics are pleasant and still hold up even though its 14 years old. The expansions are robust but I normally stick to the main game but they are very interesting as well if you like to explore new types of combat and economy management. This is must have for any strategy fan and offers so much even after playing it for ten years.

Just the important things:
- There is progression. After each game, you earn experience for whichever "home city" you're playing, which allows you to buy new cards to customize your civilizations. This is possibly the games greatest strength, as it makes playing each game actually mean something.
- Each civilization feels different from the others due to their individual strengths and weaknesses, though many of their units are shared. The DLC civs are all even more different with new and unique unit/building types.
- The game's balance is off, so some nations can be better than others, which means PvP suffers. I don't play for PvP, though.
- The gameplay is different from AoE2, so don't you go into this expecting more of the same. It's still an RTS, and there are many similarities, but many things are different. (For instance, settlers instantly deposit what they gather, so there's no travel time.)
- This is a time period that is seldom represented in games (around the colonial era), so it feels fresh.
- Microsoft rarely offers this game for sale, so if it's on sale, and you're curious about it, you should pick it up.

At first I didn't like it as much as AoE2, but the musket formations and artillery effectiveness slowly grew on me.  The ship control is also much better IMO, Age 2 is all about massing fire ships and galleons, in 3 you have to control each ship... only to use the broadside attack but still.  Also I like the Asian Dynasties, the only problems are France and Japan are OP.  Online community still alive in 2020 and I think a little less hardcore than AoE2 players, good for casuals like me.

I don't get why this game gets such a bad rap. Yes, its not the masterpiece that AOE2 is from a pure strategy point of view but it still a very solid RTS that carries is its own to this day. Really good game but the price for the whole game is ridiculous. It should be no more than 20 bucks for a game that is nearly as old as steam.

In relation to what AOE3 provides that the previous titles don't, is the introduction of a 'build a deck' feature that allows you to customise your shipment cards as you gain XP and level up. A really good feature added in a nutshell!

Collecting resources is much faster in comparison to AOE2. Villagers/settlers now collect from the resource point. They do not have to walk to a mill or build a mine to collect various resources. The resources collected go straight into your total resources immediately. The market will substantially improve the pace of collecting resources. 
 
Advancement in era of focus means the units themselves are stronger but, much of the mechanics in AOE2 still carry over. e.g. Capitol replaces the improvements you found in castles etc. 

Ships are so good! They are big, strong, and very good at protecting water resources. Be weary as some units and buildings are very good against them! (Outpost and Fort). 

There are cannons that are deadly against infantry as long as you protect them, their high damage is crippled by their low HP to balance the game. 

Infantry are more formidable and get much stronger as you improve them. 

Different colony/factions have different strengths. British have superior navy and do get the extra settler per house built etc. 

AI is kinda dumb so dont expect it to be good enough to train you to pro level, you will need to master the hotkeys! For a game that is almost 15 years old, I can't really take points off for the AI.

Look at guides for each civilisation, but starting with the British civ is not a bad idea to get used to the game mechanics. Relatively easy to master.

Etc....

Though Age of Empires IV isn't out yet, making AOE III technically the latest main game in the series, AOE III radiates the awkward middle-child energy that a lot of games from the late 2000's seem to have (Civ IV comes to mind). And like Civ IV, I think AOE III is totally underrated. Its graphics are colorful and expansive, its gameplay is tight and loads of fun, and it manages to bring that AOE quality to a more modern era. My only two big criticisms are that I wish it had more civilizations (even with the expansions there's only like a dozen total civs, which seems odd given that the civs mostly aren't super different mechanically, unlike Age of Mythology), and that the main campaign is kinda hokey. I think AOE III would benefit from a Forgotten Empires renovation, but they're understandably busy elsewhere.

If you're a big AOE2 fan, I'd definitely recommend trying this game!

A good game but not a good Age of empires game as it feels like an entry in the series that was made by EA if they had bought the Age of empires franchise. Like I said the game itself is good as the overall gameplay is enjoyable and some useful changes have been made. However the story/campaign is utter crap. This is because it borders on sci-fi (when Age of empires is meant to be historical) and has some serious continuity errors. 

Basically the story takes you through three time eras: the late 16th century, the 1750s and some point in the 19th century (the story doesn't say but I assume its the mid/late 19th century). Across these time eras you follow multiple characters and the main plot revolves around a fountain that can alledegely provide immortality if drank from. This alone is stupid because as I said, Age of empires is meant to be a historical game. For example in the Age of empires 2 campaigns you get to follow some well known historical figures from the medieval era as well as take part in some famous historical battles from that era. Whereas in Age of empires 3 you follow the some forgettable fictional characters looking for a mythical fountain. The campaign barely gives you an explanation about the eras that your in so after completing it I felt like I had learnt nothing. My advice is if this is the first Age of empires game you are buying, don't buy it and buy the earlier entries instead as they are much better. Only buy this one if you are curious to see how dull it is compared to the other entries.

P.S Originally I wrote the explanation of the continuity errors in the campaign in this review but it was so long that it looked like an incoherent rant and you would honestly deserve a medal if you took the time to read it.

After playing this game for some time, on and off steam, I can say that it is definitely worth getting, especially if your a fan of the AOE franchise. This is the successor of Age of Empires 2, which is one of the best strategy games ever made. It lets you play as 14 different civilisations, each of which are unique in their own way (8 original and an extra 3 each in the two expansions). It also adds new features which the series didn't have before like:
+ Home Cities-from where you can send shipments
+ The concept of Experience Points(XP)
+ Trading posts and alliance with natives according to the map you play
+ Collecting treasures etc.
It also has other minor changes like five ages to advance through instead of four and each civilisation having more different/unique units. Although the new changes may take some getting used to, its still really fun to play and has lots of content. Still its best to pick it up on sale because the pricing isn't one of its plus points.

The best RTS for me. I don't get why everyone obsseses over AoE I & II, for me this one really does it. Lots of cool units, full 3D, interesting setting, challenging missions, expansions, awesome destruction physics and punchy sound design make for a really great RTS experience. It's way more fun to me than RDR2. Could use some remake or at least remaster, pathfinding fixes, full steamworks integration.

Some cons: pathfinding is pretty weird and buggy, it's way too expensive for such an old game that isn't well integrated into steam. Thankfully I got it really cheap with winter sale and additional 20% off with winter tokens.

Also note: the expansions are separate .exes, you have to go to the game's install folder in order to play. Theoretically steam should display choice dialog when you run it, but it doesn't always work the first time.

[I did have this game on it's original disc, but i now have it on Steam so take my review as you like]

A brilliant RTS with the main campaign covering anything from the Medieval Ages to the Civil War (including Pirates (Yar), with the  DLC Expansion's focusing on the Native Americans, Iroquois, Lakota (under the name Sioux) and Aztecs (The WarChiefs) and the Asian Civilisations of the Indian, Chinese and Japanese (The Asian Dynasties).

Gameplay is fairly simple, albiet fun and enthralling at times. Multiplayer is still functioning, although it's a smidge difficult to find a game at times if you're unlucky. Not to worry as there is Single-Player Skirmish which is pretty much the same as MP but with AI instead of actual players. Battles usually range from 20-40 minutes depending on how many players (2 to 8 being the min and max) and how good said players are

Cu.stomisation is fairly limited, with the only things being a Card Deck to use in battle and your Home Town which is purely for Aesthetic purposes

Regardless, i'd give the game a 8/10, would play again :P

Okay, so first of all I played this a lot more on CD. So I've got about 100 hours of singleplayer and 20~ Hours of multiplayer.

I gave this a thumb up because I enjoyed the singleplayer as the campaign is pretty good. This game requires the least skill from all the available age of empires titles and is pretty easy to learn, so if you are new to strategy games this might be for you.
But that's really about it, the singleplayer Randommap isn't all that interesting as the AI isn't really all that good and pretty easy to cheese if you try it.
And for multiplayer the whole Deck mechanic that they introduced for AoE3 doesn't really work out as a few civs are just way stronger than others. Also the gamehas very few players that play online and finding matches might be hard sometimes. That is my point of view after about 30ish matches.

-If you are looking for a campaign that isn't half bad pick this up, but also pick up the other age of empires titles since all of them did a very good job with their historical campaigns.
-If you are however looking for a competitive OR casual multiplayer RTS pick up age of empires 2 instead.

Remembering all the great times i had while playing Age of Empires 1 and 2 growing up, I came into AoE 3 expecting much of the same great content. I was disappointed. While Age of Empires 1 and 2 were all about advancing through the ages to achieve an edge in technology over your opponents, AoE 3 has you set in the same age throughout the game. You can still upgrade some technologies to get an edge but not nearly as much as you could in the other games. It honestly feels dumbed down and too easy. No need to set up mining or lumber camps to collect resources from far away, your villagers magically send them directly to your town center as soon as they collect them. There's also no need for mills for food or farms, now you have one big building that produces unlimited food as long as villagers are working there. Another thing that was added are trade routes, now you don't need to request resources from allies, you can get them for free by building a trading post along the trade route. This would be a good game for younger kids, but long time fans of the AoE series would find it to be far too simple and easy.

The Playtime displayed is inaccurate, I've owned a copy of this game for about 6 - 7 years now. 

This game is a work of art, and while it isn't the "Classic fundamental" that is in Age of Empires 2 it expands on the simplicity of Age of Empires 2, and makes it more complex and different based on the colonial era.

Age of Empires 3 introduces new features and styles of play, and can be fun year after year. the multiplayer service still runs and there's always 700 - 1K+ on, so finding a game is easy and even then you can always play against bots which feel satisfying to fight at all difficulties, and even talk to you during the game.

Some of my fondest memories playing an age of empires game come from Henry The Navigator or Queen Elizabeth shooting me a snarky remark then charging into battle with my army or into my city where my Defenses were thinnest. Deceptively smart AI constant challenges you with well balanced armies and sneaking around to hit flanks and weak points, or obnoxiously building a fort half way to your base and shortening the time between attacks by building up armies there before sending them.

All in all, buy the game. If you like Age of Empires, Buy the game.
