I bought this game hoping it would be made in the spirit of its predecessor, a timeless classic which is fun still to this day.

Well.

I quickly came to the conclusion it's rather a cheap cartoonish dumbed down version aimed at younger kids who can't affo- wait. This is actually not a cheap game. But then why is it so rubbishly made?

They had every single foundation there, lying in front of them. One of the most successful RTS games of previous decades. And what do they do? They throw the blueprints in the fire, hire some orangutans to point at random suggestions, and completely change everything. EVERYTHING.

It's so dumbed down. I can't even begin to explain it. You have basically ONE faction, with 3-4 different skins. You can build:

- 20 houses (no more, there are building caps! What the hell!) 
- 7 watchtowers (...), market (5 upgrades, all of them improve gathering speed by a slight amount, how creative)
- barracks (you can build cartoon ranged, cartoon spearmen or cartoon swordsmen. That's it.)
- stables (2 different units which... well... not much effort went in to differentiate them neither trait nor appearance wise)
- armory (2 units again)(you can upgrade units... with the same uninspirational boost you'd expect aftera hearing about the market, and the icons are just military ranks, saved some money on that too I guess)
- Dock (fishing ships, caravels and galleys. and "fire ships" which are basically eternally burning wrecks and make no sense whatsoever)

So yeah. That's it. Not kidding.

The diversity of the originals are gone, the 2.5 D nature of the old game has been replaced by poor 3D something that reminds of Populous or something (except that it's not as fun), it reminds more of Age of Mythology, but again without the diversity, and for some unexplicable reason, they chose to put the setting in colonial times. Not only colonial times, but what look as the same year even. There's no change to your civ. The only thing I noticed changing appearance is your walls (once, after an upgrade) and your towers (ditto). Your units will always look the same. Your enemies' units will look the same (there's differences when you zoom in, but the horrible 3D concept makes it nigh impossible to notice if you don't make an efffort).

Ok time to let the simplifying go for a second. Or not.

Because now I want to talk about "how to play" and the campaign. 
It will introduce you to how to use your mouse, as if you've never used a computer before, and that's it basically. The highlight was probably finding a unicorn rider easter egg in the tutorial while exploring (any effort to prevent the player from avoiding their "triggers" or otherwise cheesing or avoiding their intended linear objectives have been poorly implemented and borderline seemed to be done in a hurry).
Actual important information, like how to repair your ships and buildings, is completely neglected (there's a button on the lower right, and there's also a cooldown timer after having been in combat, and ships apparently auto-repair when close to the docks) Enemy armies will spawn at random places, sometimes right on top of you, if you don't pay extra attention to actually trying to follow what you think they intended (instead of playing your own game) or not spawn at all.

Unit pathing is even worse than AoE II (how is that possible?!?), "luckily" you usually won't have any interesting amount of units active at the same time.

Side objectives are an interesting add, but they are extremely poorly explained sometimes (missions regarding units can be particularly hard when the unit in question gets lost, or you never knew where it was to begin with, I'm talking NPC style, no name or indicator above, can be next to any amount of other NPCs, no pings, no nothing, no minmap markers except treasures and "tribes") The rewards are also extremely neligible, might as well had added an extra gold mine but I guess this is the one place they decided to implement some diversity and then made this too in a hurry. (Would it hurt to make them actually hard and have noticeable rewards?!)

Campaign is made in (now) generic WCIII/Age of Mythology style, albeit with even worse dialogues and incoherent settings and fantasy (WCIII and earlier was great in this regard, AoM not so much but still loved that game because at least it had a fantasy setting and not historic, and the rest of the functions of the game made it very enjoyable)

I don't know what more to say.

I tried to give this game so many chances, and I'm really good at always playing a game through, but I just can't see myself doing this. I regret buying this, and I feel extremely disappointed that they did this so half-hearted.

A few voice actors are great, others seem to be hired family members or overzealous first-timers.

I would refund it, but sadly I played this way too long after buying it. I feel almost a bit angry about the choices they've made, especially with the butchering of other great titles in the past 5-10 years.

If you loved AoE II, for the love of god don't buy this. Get one of the new AoE remakes instead... they're still great fun, have an active multiplayer base (which this game will never have for obvious reasons) and even though they are just that - remakes - at least you know what you will be getting!

Hope the rest of my day will be better than this....

Best regards

AOE3 Complete Collection has a great strategic approach. The player races to create resources, then forces, then decisive battles against other the other players. Each civilization has different advantages, and each map drives strategy. Additionally, the use of developmental cards and optional technological advances introduce additional layers of player decision making.  While it doesn't have the diplomatic, scientific, or economic complexities of CIvilization, it does compel a complex military approach, and it does it small vignettes rather than hours long campaigns. Also, the ability to control the multiplayer aspect allows for playing with friends.

This game is old, but still has booming player numbers. I logged on a Friday night, and there were 967 players online. To put that into perspective, Black Ops 2, a major success in the Call of Duty franchise in 2012 (which had over 100,000 players online at any given time in its heyday), now has about 700 players online on average. This game is from 2005 and it has more active players than Black Ops 2 currently does...

This is testament to how great the game is. From the panicking micromanagement at the start of the game, to the early rushes, to the late game cavalry charges, to the explosive finales within the enemy's base, AOE3 offers matches that feel accomplishing. You look at the clock at the end of the game, and you think to yourself, "No way that was 50 minutes, I felt as though I just started!". AOE3 keeps you engaged THROUGHOUT the whole game, if you feel bored, or are sitting around twiddling your thumbs at any point, you are probably going to lose the match. The graphics are outstanding for their day, and still hold up today. I have never gotten a headache from low quality graphics while playing this game.

This game is also an absolute blast if you are playing with friends, you HAVE to work with your allies in order to win. You will likely have to send reinforcements to your friends' towns against raids, and may have to share resources with each other to keep your team afloat. In my opinion, nothing is better than fighting a losing war and having your comrades literally send in the cavalry to save you, then counterattack with hundreds of troops into the enemy's town... In conclusion, AOE3 is a brilliant, masterful, real-time strategy game that I would 100% recommend to everyone interested in the genre.

TLDR; AOE3 is the fun, engaging, and popular. Why haven't you bought it yet?

You'll need a lot more than three musketeers to win a typical skirmish in the New World in Age of Empires III. Home City shipments, trade routes, allying with native tribes and more - make AOE-3 much more engaging than its predecessors. One of the standout features of AOE III is its looks - the game looks stunning, with the environments and troops featuring plenty of detail. The in-game environment also boasts an impressive physics engine. Buildings and trees break apart realistically when under fire, while soldiers have rag doll animations which are fun to watch. Few games have looked this good. For a game older than a decade, it has aged really well and exceeded player's expectations.

Age of Empires 3 is quite fun and it doesn't nearly deserve as much hate, as it so often receives. The game is based during the period of exploration, which means you'll be presented with the historic and technological experiences, that you might expect during that era. From guns, to cannons, to industrial trains and the more ingenious hot air balloons. Each component is cleverly intertwined into the game, with historical hits and misses, depending on the faction you choose to play.

Now, whilst most of the game is quite fun and intriguing, there does exist a very big hit or miss, surrounding one of the core game mechanics; where' by you'll either absolutely love the mechanic, or you'll absolutely hate it. That is, the leveling up gimic, which places a Yugioh-esque - build your own deck card system into the game. The card system in this case, is tiered and each player is allowed to choose upwards of 21 cards, to put in their deck. Now, based on the cards you choose, you are rewarded different benefits, within the game, depending on what Era your Civilisation is currently in and how much Experience you have been awarded. Now, the problem with this mechanic, is that certain cards are hidden behind a level requirement, which means, assuming you are a Level 20 and the requirement, is Level 45, you naturally would not be able to obtain the given card.

All in all, regardless of where you stand on the card gimic, the game is quite a solid and fun experience, that can be enjoyed, both by yourself, with your friends, or even online with the mostly positive AoE community.

I'd definitely recommend this to any RTS or historical fan out there.

Like, wow, nostalgia. I will always hold this game to be my favorite over AOE II, with all due respect for it. The diversity of gameplay is fun. Most civilizations feel different enough to actually matter, in content and aesthetic. Relatively well-balanced. If you wanna do online multiplayer, there are still games daily. I played the heccccc out of this game as a kid and now I play it almost every week. Easy to sit down and play a skirmish for an hour or two. There's a sense of progression with skirmishes because your home cities can level up. Deck-building is also a component with your home cities that I find really fun. Also, with the add-ons, you can play as the Iroquois (Haudonausaunee), Sioux, Aztec, Chinese, Japanese, and Indian. I don't remember the last game that let me play as these civilizations with unique gameplay and styles. Also there's a fun little single-player campaign, if you need an introduction to the gameplay. Lastly, there is a huge backlog of custom maps, scenarios, and mods from the community over the years.

If you're having fond memories of AoE2 and think "oh hey here's the sequel, surely it's even better" OH BOY do I have bad news for you. It takes the streamlined formula of AoE, AoM, and AoE2, and decides "nah we have to make it way more complicated for no particular reason." It's not nearly as good, and I'd recommend waiting for AoE2 definitive to come out. Sure, the graphics are nicer, but it's somehow also a deck-building game? And a city-building game? As well as the base RTS. Will I continue to play it? To get my money's worth until I get AoE2 DE. 
TL;DR It's AoE2 but worse, and in the colonial era.

Good game, and holds up well over time.  The only thing I changed was the zoom out/in distance which makes the game much more playable.  You can read about how to do that online, it's easy.

To make the zoom fix work you need to edit the files game.cfg, gamex.cfg, and gamey.cfg, and then restart a campaign. If you then create a new save file it will remember the new zoom settings.

I use these settings with a mouse-wheel:

limitPitch=47
maxZoom=140
normalZoom=140
minZoom=10
extraZoomPercent=1
zoomSpeed=5
zoomWheelDivisor=20.0

Having played this since release, it's safe to say Age of Empires 3 holds a special place in my heart (as do the previous iterations). Age of Empires 3 moves away from the "jump right in and play" setting of it's previous iterations and introduces a card and deck system through something called your "Home City" that allows you to send "shipments" whilst you're in a game. These shipments can be anything from extra troops, special buildings or even resources that will help give you a leg up against your enemies. 

Age of Empires 3 only got better with it's subsequent expansion packs; War Chiefs, which introduced the Native American tribes as playable civilisations and The Asian Dynasties which reintroduced classic civilisations such as Japan and China and also introduced a brand new one: India. The introduction of these civilisations increased the playability of the game and also brought in a number of new campaigns.

If you enjoyed Age of Empires 1 & 2 but are wary of the changes 3 brought, I recommend you give it a try anyway. You won't be disappointed.
The game is fun to play, though you will have to enter its root folder if you want to play the expansions.

This game is certainly not new, so I'm not sure how much point there is in this review, but for those of you out there who haven't yet had the experience and think you might, I would recommend going for it if you like medieval-themed RTS / light strategy games.

The graphics can still be made to look nice, and while there isn't really proper mod support there are unofficial mods which can improve things and add content. In fact, the graphics is one of the stronger selling-points of this game I feel, as the satisfaction of blowing my opponents' buildings apart -piece by piece- with cannons and other heavy artillery is just SO very satisfying. More so than in any other game of its type I have played.

Game play is easy enough to learn, but has enough depth that it's not something most players will master in a day. There are important choices to be had as far as which units to make in order to counter the units your opponent is making. Yet it's not impossible to win a game despite not knowing the counters, especially if you're particularly good with the mouse and can anticipate your opponent in terms of troop movement and general strategy. There's not as much micro-managing of non-combat units as there were in previous Age of Empire titles, which I personally appreciated immensely. The included map editor is fairly versatile too.

There are, however, things that will annoy some players -- a lot. For example choosing which cards to put in your deck (yep, it's a light card game too), and unlocking new cards, was not an experience I enjoyed. It felt out of place in an RTS like this, constantly drawing me away to a completely different screen to pick what card I wanted, during which time I was not watching the battlefield. It also somehow feels like there is less to do in this game than its predecessor, and although there are numerous different societies to play they (for the most part) don't feel as different as they do in other RTS games. Having more than two teams did not seem to be allowed without an unofficial patch - something allowed by the previous title in the series as I remember it. Also, while you can have the computer randomly pick a map for you, there is no option to dynamically generate maps, which would have added something at least uncommon to the genre. All in all, it is more of a trade-off, rather than an improvement, when compared to its predecessor - doing some things better and some things worse.

I almost only play alone, facing off with the AI.  I love the game, it brings me back the my childhood days.  I would play it for hours, which I guess I still sometimes do.  That said, I think the game is better than AOE2 personally, I like the combat and city building way more.  That said, I wish there were more AI options and that there were much bigger maps with larger population caps.  Also, there should be a way to have more than one of the same type of Civ fight in a personal game, I know that may be off given the leader personalities, but just make their portrait match their unit color or something.  This would also mean there would need to be some tweaking to unit limits, but it would be worth it!

From there, I would like to say that the game holds up well, even if it's in the shadow of AOE2.  I like that the Civs are much more unique to each other, and the card system even makes two of the same Civs have a chance to play very differently.  This is one of its best aspects.  No two of the same civs feel too alike, even when you face off with with people all using the same civ.  I hope they find a way to keep this idea going in the next game, even if they drop the card/home city system.  Maybe make a special tech tree that opens and closes unique paths, allowing people to "steer" a civ.

At that rate, I also love the era and the Native Americans have always been me fav to play as.  They get little representation in media, and here they are not only playable, but so much fun!  I hope they make it into the next game as well!

Age of Empires® III: Complete Collection Review.
I LOVE THIS GAME !! I love this game so much that I took a forty dollar risk in buying this game. When I bought this game on 10/14/2019, The steam requirements for this game said OS Windows XP , and I have windows 10. This game (( WILL )) work on Windows 10 with some very simple configurations of Windows 10 ...............
THIS IS AN EASY CONFIGURATION!!! ..... On windows 10, all you have to do, is go to the Control Panel >> Programs >> Programs and Features >> Turn Windows features on or off (this should be on the left hand side of the window) >> Legacy Components (make sure this is checked, and the DirectPlay folder inside of the Legacy Components folder is checked as well). After doing this, the game will run perfectly fine.
I would also suggest that you download DIRECTX 9 .... It is an older version of DIRECTX, but it has always worked the best for me !!
My risk paid off, and now I am playing this game on Windows 10, and having a blast !!
I VERY HIGHLY RECOMMEND Age of Empires® III: Complete Collection !!!

Age of Empires 3 is a great take on a classic Age of Empires. The complete edition comes with both DLC which is great as the main campaign is only about a third of the game making the DLC awesome to have. The graphics were pretty good for their time, path finding is a bit buggy at times and occasionally siege units don't fire and reposition when they have perfect view of their target. The Campaign has a pretty decent length taking about 10-15 hours per campaign sometimes longer depending on skill and what difficulty. The skirmish mode is great and the diversity of units and playable factions is something that is enjoyed in most Age of Empires games. The story is pretty decent, I mean it follows a historical path for a good deal of it with some changes here and there to make the campaign more interesting. All in all I would rate the game a 8/10.

It looses 1 point for the path finding and other handful of bugs in the game, and it looses half another point with the slightly outdated graphics. The other half a point is taken off because of the length of the campaign, I personally would have liked more campaign, coming from Age of Empires 2 there was a lot more campaign, with the prologue being just as long if not a little bit longer than the main campaign for Age of Empires 3. 

All in all I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good RTS with diverse units but would advise you wait for a sale to occur as the game is fairly pricey for anyone who may wish to play this solo.

A true multiplayer classic and probably my most played game from 2009 to circa 2013 (before Steam logged my playtime, obviously). So many fond memories of afternoons and weekends just going by, so many battles won and lost, together with far-away friends. Even though I understand why many people still prefer the predecessor, AOEIII has always been my personal favorite of the series, mostly because of the time period (Age of Exploration/European colonization) and the setting (New World/Asia). I still love the game’s detailed 3D graphics, huge maps and the inclusion of the Havok physics engine. In terms of gaming experiences there just isn’t much else that feels as satisfying as controlling a group of cannons and shooting enemy bases to shreds (the accompanying sounds are pretty great, too). Unfortunately, the singleplayer campaigns are rather average and the story is mostly forgettable.

When I was a kid- like, elementary school age- I had five games that I absolutely loved to death. They were Civilization V, Anno 1701, SimCity, Spore, and Age of Empires III. I'm glad to say that my childhood love for this game still holds up (and that the game is on Steam, given that I lost my CD copy years ago).

A lot of people will tell you that Age of Empires II is the peak of the franchise. I didn't play Age of Empires II until high school- where a bootleg copy was being passed around as shareware- and while they're both undeniably good games, speaking honesty, I actually prefer III to II. There's just something about III, I'm not even really sure what, that grabs me in a way that II doesn't.

The graphics aren't anything to write home about, at least nowadays, but the game still looks good. It runs smoothly. The unique traits, buildings, and units of different leaders and cultural groups are enjoyable, and make it so that playing as different leaders legitimately feels different. There's enough challenge that it's not a pushover, but not too much to make the game more frustrating than fun. The gameplay and unit balance are solid as well, and the average game time is neither too short nor too long.

The one main problem I have is the price tag; this is a decade-old game, it should not be priced at $40. It should be half that at most. I'd advise waiting until it goes on sale, speaking frankly, but nonetheless I do absolutely recommend this game.

How is it different? What stands out?
The home city system: you can name your explorer, name your city of origin, choose what shipments to unlock, and which to bring with you on the skirmish. There is a rpg element in this.
Colonists, native americans and asians have different play styles and gameplay mechanics.
Units of different nations look different. This is a minor thing, but is major to me. I detest playing as asians or arabs, then training a swordsman, and it comes out of the barracks looking like a european in chain mail, kite shield and broadsword. It feels lazy, unrealistic, and reduces immersion.
You can hire strong and expensive mercenaries for coin.
You can hire cheap and expendable bandits for food and wood.
You can train native allies that don’t consume your population size.
AI leaders speak to you (with voice acting).

I do wish the hud was adapted for widescreen resolutions, without being so big nor the icons on it stretched.
Also wish the AI was a little better, a little more variety in their shipments and tactics would be nice.
I also think they should have added a south american natives nation.

There are some very frustrating mechanics with this game. Each time you play you will do the same things over and over again. It is a very repetitious type of gameplay and there is not much variation. In shorth, the depth of play is very shallow. Visually you can only go back only a little bit when looking at the screen. The game will not allow you to zoom out enough. Look at the screenshots. That's as far as it goes. This means things like ships remain huge and hard to control. Troops and settlers get left all over the game screen. Forget about trying anything tactical. This game is meant to be simple for the casual gaming type of person. The fact you can't move around easily and the weird setup of left-click, right clicking means you will do it again. If you guess wrong the game clears the selection forching you to redo-it again. You will beat back the enemy, and then have to rebuild yourself but then face a rebuilt enemy again. The AI is based just on overwhelming you which forces you to do the same thing. Do not buy even if on sale. Get a much better and newer game instead.

Okay, so, I've wanted this game since its release, ten years ago. All my previous PCs and laptops were too basic to play this game, so I spent a lot of years playing only Age of Empires II. I got so used to it that I was afraid that I wouldn't like AoE III, which was like a total mystery for little me. Now, I've finally bought it and... it's even better that I thought it would be.

First of all, this game is NOT Age of Empires II, so don't expect to play the same game with different eras and civs. It's got some recognizable aspects from every AoE, like the overall style and basic mechanics, and the design of many buildings. However, it's also got TONS of new content and improved mechanics that will make you realize how old AoE II actually is - not that it's a bad thing.

Although Age of Empires II feels grander in comparison, Age of Empires III is way more complex and detailed. It's got less civilizations than the previous installment, that is true. However, each civilization is different and completely unique... and also kind of customizable in terms of bonuses, which is cool. Also, this game has a new "deck card" mechanic that gives stuff as you gather experience during each matcch. All civs have some military units as default deck cards, which helps making matches faster and more entertaining. Some other deck cards include resources, forts, ships, towers, town centers, and especial bonuses like faster house building time. The DLCs add tons of new units and mechanics as well - way more than AoE II DLCs used to offer, honestly. You'll have to learn quite a bit of new stuff to understand the game (if you come from AoE II), but once you do, the game is a lot of fun, and it turns into the classical RTS experience.

If you love RTS games in general, like Rise of Nations and... well, Age of Empires, then you will not be disappointed with Age of Empires III. It's the perfect mix between classic gameplay and modern mechanics.

Age of Empires III offers gamers the next level of realism, with advanced battle physics and unparalleled visual detail. The new game picks up where Age of "Empires II: Age of Kings" left off, placing gamers in the position of a European power determined to explore, colonize and conquer the New World. This time period features stunning scenes, from towering European cathedrals to courageous tribes of Native Americans, and spectacular combat with Industrial Age units like rifled infantry, cavalry and tall ships bristling with cannons. Age of Empires III excites strategy gamers with new game-play elements, including the concept of a "Home City," new civilizations, units, technologies and an immersive new single-player campaign that will span three generations.

A real time strategy and base building game.

Pros:
>Graphics, still hold up well by today's standards (released 2005)
>Controls, simple and easy to use
>Campaign modes have really good story lines
>Voice Acting is top notch

Inbetween:
>Gameplay very smooth but different from Age of empires 2 in some ways which might not be suit die hard fans of AoE 2 (Gathering resources is different and amount of troops)
>Camera - reports of some players finding the camera too close?
>The menu to choose the expansion packs sometimes does not load but you can right click the game in your library to select which expansion to play.


Cons:
> Online mode seems to be a bit of a head ache (especially regarding cd keys)
> Price seems very expensive for how long the game has been out (On sale it is really cheap, i think i got it for £5 in the sale)

Overall - A great RTS game that i enjoyed but some fans of the series do not like the changes to the gameplay from the previous game.

I can only recommend this game to anyone I know, especially those who enjoy history and strategy.

Bought this game to play multiplayer with my friend who played this when he was a kid. After going through the tutorial while he refreshed his memory on the game, we decided to go 1v1 each other. This didn't happen; before we were even able to play online, we encountered an error that won't let us create an account. This error is "Error 100: Bad CD Code". We don't have bad CD codes, as the game let us use the CD codes Steam provided to start the game in the first place. We spent a couple hours looking for fixes online only to find time and time again that people hadn't found any fixes outside of one guy who was able to use a physical copy's CD key, meaning he had to buy the game twice.

Cannot recommend this game, even though I'm sure it's great, if the multiplayer is so broken that it won't even let you create an account. Disappointing, and I'll probably be refunding.

Definitely an underrated RTS, I find AoE3 to be a lot more enticing than AoE 1 or 2 (or HD versions) - while they were great games when they came out, they haven't aged nearly as well as AoE 3 has. The card/deck and home city mechanic makes replay value and customization high, something I truly appreciate (and a meta-perspective is something I'd love to see in more RTS games).

In addition, mods and tweaks make it even more playable, even in 2019.

As a classic-style RTS, it also features a lengthy campaign with unique units and rules. The writing isn't fantastic, but it's still a lot better than just having basic skirmishes. (I despise PvP, so wont go into it at all.)

I've seen a lot of butt-hurt reviews about how this game is not like the previous AOE games. What most people fail to acknowledge is that the amount of development and progress in terms of game mechanics and progression has been made. Yes, it is different from the previous versions and isn't that the whole point of a new game? Yes, some mechanics make a lot of levels and skirmishes feel like a piece of cake, but that's not all there is to it. It accommodates fairly new users to the game mechanics while the veterans can just amp up the difficulty to make it more challenging and fun. And the adversarial strat processing and AI of AOE3 is WAY better than that of its predecessors. It's a unique experience of it's own for those who choose to have a more adventurous and challenge driven mindset and are not bothered by getting hold of new mechanics. It is a great strategy game and has earned its credit. Both new players and old players can have fun. 10/10 would recommend!

A successful sequel in AoE series.

First of, what is Age of Empires about:

You build and manage your own empire by sending settlers to gather resources and build
different buildings for improvements. You also build your army because there is only on empire at the end of the war.
Or you cooperate with others to win.
The best for you would be to check out some gameplay video.

And what AoE III offers?

- good graphics
- Trade Routes and Native Villages to work with
- heroes don't die, they stay downed at ground waiting for friendly to come 
- shipments from home city - a very great feature
- treasures - small amount of something guarded by 2 or 3 enemies
- special attacks (heroes)
- much much better terrain than II
- forts and factories

In conclusion, AoE III is a fantastic game which I highly recommend.

Although it falls short of its' predecessors, AoE3 is still a decent game on its' own. Single player is relatively fun and the adding of cities with cards gives the game some longevity and reward for committing to a nation and playstyles.

However I think it loses it's polish online. I wonder if it would be better if it had a larger community, but it is small overall. Skill levels are in great disparity which makes finding a balanced game difficult.

Community size is not the biggest fault however, gameplay is just a bit imbalanced. And any imbalance in a franchise that produces such competitive players will understandably be exploited.

It is still a fun game but it is unlike Age of Empires II which is well polished, has a bigger community, and is overall balanced. If you're seeking to get competitive, I would suggest the second entry of the franchise. But if you're just wanting to kill some time in Colonial Americas, then by all means I recommend it.

Age of Empires III is every bit the fully featured game you'd expect it to be, featuring a lengthy single-player campaign in three interconnected acts, each one a generation apart. There's a fully customizable skirmish mode with five difficulty settings for the computer opponent; there's the ability to play over a network; and, of course, there's the ESOnline player-matching service, where you can compete in ranked matches over the Internet, chat with other players, and more. There's also a scenario editor, in case you wish to create your own maps or campaigns, plus some encyclopedic information about all the game's units, structures, cultures, circumstances, and more. A tutorial is there to teach you the basics, and you can also play a practice match in which a fairly helpful narrator will gently remind you of the stuff you're basically forgetting to do. Cheers!

I am surprised to see that the game has decent physics. I played a lot of RTS games in the past and the units destroyed buildings by simply hitting the building with a sword and it would collapse. However, in age of empires, units throw torches/grenades at the building. The game itself is also more fun than I expected it to be. One thing I don't like about the game is spawning next to trading roads because I can't build walls around my base.

It's a great game.
Wait, you dont know what this game is about? I will shoot an arrow in your kn... 

It's a real time strategie game. You farm, build, attack, get killed, farm more, build more, attack more and win... that's it.

Story is actually pretty fun to play. You get to do many diffrent kind of things, not just the simple "destroy there base"-quest. There is for example one mission where you need to explore a cave and rescue some dudes and the only possibility to get soldiers is by bringing those dudes back to the begin of the cave. Dosn't sound like fun? But it is, trust me.

But the best thing about this game is the "AI vs Person"-Mode. 
I've spent tons of hours (had the game on a CD, game hours on Steam dosnt show my real hours) just by doing that, you can do 1vs7...4v4...1v2...1v1, just as you like and it's great.
There are also cheats, like "truck truck truck", you spawn a giant monster truck and can kill your opponents really, really fast. 
It's also a bit like rock, paper, scissors (most of the time). Canon gets killed by dude on horse, dude on horse gets killed by normal dude and normal dude gets killed by canon... or you be like me and spam musketeer because they look cool.

Oh, there is also an multiplayer. Never really played it. Played like two rounds, one match with a friend and another one against a randome opponent. 
Spamming musketeer dosnt work.

This game is superb! Definitely an improvement from Age of Empires I and II! There's lots of maps you can pick with beautiful scenery, different nations each with their own leader that automatically quote funny taunts at you in-game, as your enemy or ally (for instance, if you destroy the Portuguese's town center, their leader, Henry the Navigator, will say,"You have razed my town center, you filthy swine!"), and, unlike, Age of Empires 1 and 2, there are only 3 types of resources in this game: Food, Wood, and Gold. In Age of Empires 1 and 2, the resources were Food, Wood, Gold, and Stone, but Age of Empires 3 doesn't include stone in this one. If you've played Age of Empires 1 and 2, you'd know that you have to build a mill at food, a lumberjack at wood, and a mining camp at stone and gold, just so your villages can drop off the resources. But in this game, you don't have to do any of that! You don't have to build any annoying buildings at resources just so your villagers can drop stuff off, you can just tell your villages to harvest the resources, and they'll just simply do it, without needing any building to drop off their resources! So much better! :) 

And not only are the graphics in this game much better than Age of Empires 1 and 2, so are the campaigns! In Age of Empires II, just about all of the campaigns require you to be an enemy of Jerusalem, which is just shocking. But in this one, the campaigns have extremely exciting, fictional stories. I don't like the Japanese, Chinese and Indian campaigns, but the Black family campaigns are awesome! There's 5 parts to the Black family campaign (each part has a bunch of levels), and each part stands for a generation of the Black family:

Part 1 is about Morgan Black, a Scottish Knight, in search of the Fountain of Youth. He runs into enemies and friends along the way, like Elizabet Ramsey, a pirate, Sahin, an Ottoman general, Alain Magnan (who Morgan takes orders from), and Spanish conquistadors. 

Part 2 is about Morgan's grandson, John Black. A villain called Warwick kidnaps John's uncle, Stuart Black, because he knows Stuart is one of Morgan's Black's sons, and might know the whereabouts of the location of the Fountain of Youth's water. So John and his best friend, Kanyenke, set out to try to rescue Stuart, and hunt Warwick down. Along the way, they meet George Washington, the United States' first president, and receive his help. John is married to a Native Indian, Nonahkee (who is actually Kanyenke's sister), and at the end of Part 2, she has a son, Nathaniel Black, which leads into Part 3. 

Part 3 is about Nathaniel Black and his army of natives fighting back against the British and especially the vicious Hessians, who take their orders from the cruel Colonel Kuechler (pronounced Kooch-ler). Kuechler even kidnaps Nonahkee, Nathaniel's mother, and Nathaniel and his uncle, Kanyenke, set out to rescue her. 

Part 4 is interesting, because the protagonist is not a man this time, but a woman - Nathaniel Black's daughter, Amelia Black. It starts with Amelia Black owning a railroad company. She meets a sinister Frenchman, Pierre Beaumont, who says he knows of a cave with gold, and will let her have a share of it. Amelia agrees, but, unkown to her, it's a trap, Beaumont is only leading her there to kill her. Kanyenke, the native from Part 2 and 3, knows this, though, and gets there in time to reveal Beaumont's plan to Amelia, and who Beaumont really is - the leader of the Circle, who wants the Fountain of Youth's water. Beaumont flees into the caves, and that's what Part 4 is about - Kanyenke, Amelia and her friend Cooper chasing Beaumont down, to bring him to justice, find out if the Fountain of Youth is real (only in a game :D), or just a myth, and, if it's real, get to the water before Beaumont does (Amelia says at one point, "What will the world be like if Beaumont lives forever?"). Along the way, they run into Simón Bolivar, who agrees to help them with Beaumont if they will help him and his people be free of the Spanish.

And part 5 is my absolute favourite, every single level is really fun to do. The story is about Chayton Black, Amelia Black's son. Amelia Black married a Native Indian (you never see him in part 4 or 5, Amelia just mentions him when she visits Chayton, in Part 5), so Chayton has native Indian blood in him. Amelia has retired from the railroad company, and Chayton takes over. He meets an old man, Billy Holmes (who becomes Sheriff later on), and they work together to defend colonists from Sioux attacks. The Sioux attacks deeply concern Chayton, so he goes up into the mountains to meet with the Sioux's leader, Crazy Horse, to find out what is going on, and try to stop a war from starting. As you go through this story, you find out why the Sioux are attacking, and who really started all this fighting. Eventually, Chayton is faced with the choice to either ally with the Sioux, or with Sheriff Billy Holme. What will he choose?

Age of Empires III and it's expansions are classic strategy gems, and in the post Starcraft 2 RTS drought we find ourselves in, are absolutely still worth playing today.

-----

[h1] The Good [/h1]
AoE has always had a strong focus on economy and base building, and nothing since has done it quite so well.

Between the three expansions, there is a ton of single player campaign content with interesting scenarios to play through and a few different civilisations to play with distinct units and buildings.

The graphics are old, but the low poly models and sometimes amusing animations are generally clean and visually distinct, and it stands up surprisingly well at modern resolutions.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
The stories in the campaigns are pretty awful, but at least give some context to the action.

[h1] So should you buy it? [/h1]
If you're an RTS fan, Absolutely!

So what's the deal what is this game, who are you, where am I, what's going on here?!
Well it's Age of Empires III obviously. It's a game, third one in a series to my knowledge. It's pretty good. If you like brief reviews here ya go:
It's a city / civilization RTS resource managing game. Basically you get a town center, train townspeople / citizens, build buildings with them, use them to collect resources like wood, stone, gold etc. Of course you spend the resources on building stuff but you also upgrade things like unit health, armor, building weapon range etc. It's a pretty solid game, good graphics, good sounds (though not the best), I think my personal favorite aspect of the game is the difference structure wise of all of the buildings from faction to faction, Portuguese number one!

That's about it really, it's a good game, nothing much to it. Give it a shot if it's on sale!

An adequate sequel to a brilliant game. It innovates and many areas both aesthetically and game play wise. It addresses many issues that players had with the last games and improves the graphics and soundscape to incredible standards. It also produces a more cinematic and story driven campaign compared to the previous iterations which simply involved various pre-built scenarios that used narration to tell the story. However with new advancements, new problems arise. For instance, the first that comes to mind is: the home city feature, which is an excellent in concept and quite enjoyable in execution becomes a novelty and eventually can become fairly unbalanced.

I owned the base version of Age of Empires 3 without expansions before and get a very nostalgic feeling when playing this. The cards for sending reinforments, resources or upgrades and the trading posts for additional resources or XP build good strategic elements. I only played it in multiplayer when it came out, but I remember the factions as balanced. Graphics are not as detailled or effectful as in modern games, but still look beautiful. The only part I find mediocre is the story, but the first expansion (haven't played the second one yet) improves on that a bit. After all, 10€ (the price for which I took it) should be the base price for a more than 10 year old game no matter how good it is and offering it "70% cheaper" is just marketing.
Although it's not a bad game, especially considering that it's from 2005 and still runs properly, it isn't worth the current price tag in my opinion.

Age of Empire 3 is an old real time strategy (RTS) game that didn't quite live up to spirit of Age of Empires 2. The key being the lack of coherent empire building and too much focus on the Wild Wild West. It is very evident in the trade routes and the constant use of Native Americans as some side race.

Gameplay-wise, it's similar to Age of Empires 2. There are a few odd additions that spoil the empire building process like native camps and trade routes. The focus of the maps are very much on the Wild Wild West. 

While in the game, you can open a separate screen to access benefits from you empire. This is very silly as you have to open another screen that blocks your strategic view just to send additional bonus goods to yourself.

Conclusion, Age of Empires 3 is worth playing but the experience is less about empire building and more about playing a Wild Wild West RTS. I am hoping that Age of Empires 4 will be more exciting.

Note: I saw the AOE 4 ad with the "New Zoom Levels" feature. I want to slap the idiot that tried to pass that off as something innovative.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Age of Empires Style RTS
This is what drove me to play it.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. The Trading Route. 
It's an eyesore. 

2. City Deck
Is it necessary? Those cards build units for you bypassing the need to build a building first.

3. Too Many Settlers Required
This is a relic of old strategy games. Having to micromanage additional groups of SCVs, settlers or resource pickers. There are too many Settlers required to gather resources. i.e. 20+. It is not fun to have to micro-manage cherrypickers.

4. Gun Saloon
This really ruined the whole concept of Age of Empires for me. This is not a Wild Wild West game. It says Empires, not 

5. Too Much like No Man's Land (2003)
I assume AOE3 and No Man's Land shared a few programmers? 

6. Ship/Naval Combat
If the ships can't be built to the correct scale or you can't balance the damage of the ships, don't bother adding them in. AOE is fine without ships.

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. No Delivery of Resources
Settlers no longer deliver resources, unlike Age of Empires 2. This is both good and bad. Good, because there's no delay in resource collection. Bad, because it removes the strategic element of reducing resources and forcing the player to extend further beyond their borders. It no longer squeezes the players to make the map smaller to increase the chances of conflict. There is very little risk to your Settlers and it removes the illusion that it simulates real settlers collecting and delivering resources.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Age V: Modern Era
I think you need the Age V: Modern Era with tanks and planes. This is the military end game where you blow up the turtle players and destroy their town hall, ending the game.

2. Upgrade Your Settlers
Provide techs that improve worker speed and make them visual. You already have it for German wheelbarrows. E.g. Loincloth Settler -> Fully-clothed Settler -> Wheelbarrow Settler -> Horsecart Settler -> Truck

3. Design for Turtle Play
The majority of players love turtling for some reason. Make it look like you can turtle for early game and then make them lose for choosing that strategy.

4. Historical Lessons By Empire/Kingdom
Every nation used to be part of some old kingdom. Like how China changed from Shang to Tang to Ming to Qing to the People's Republic of China. Or how Iran changed from Persia to the Sassanian Empire to Umayyid Caliphate (Islamic Iran) to modern day Iran.

This is more of a comparison and explanation than a review, however I do have to say this is an all time great regardless of your opinion.

AoE 2:
- villagers need to carry resources to and from their corresponding depots
- the shift-click AI is extremely rudimentary at best, which means you have to be more attentive to explorational or multi-tasking efforts
- steam workshop to work all the kinks out of the game (because, yaknow, skybox is objective trash)
- 4 resources
- the replay value is in massive armies and multiple battles, but very little meta of any kind outside of the stock team bonuses each civ has

AoE 3:
- villagers generate resources the second they're tasked to collecting one
- you can very effectively multitask
- you can rotate the map, although it does look incredibly awkward outside of the stock perspective. It's nice for seeing why you can't build something somewhere, though
- card system instead of team and civ bonuses, but the cards can be team or civ bonuses (which leads to a really sweet meta afaic)
- 3 resources instead of 4
- AI is kinda soft. Expert is like the only reasonable setting. In age2, just Hard is really challenging and will occasionally floor me.


Both:
- audio, music, and graphics go together incredibly well and stand the test of time (which is super rare imho)
- the balancing dynamics between all the units and classes, and the artistry that goes into the architecture, etc are all spot on in terms of feel
- both get laggy the more walls you build (lol)
- both have AI which gets stuck trying to understand it can't make a beeline through an area with no immediate way through
- both have AI with a weird infatuation with focusing on destroying pillars, but AoE 2 hardest has really damn smart AI.


Are there things I wish for both? Of course! Will they happen? Very unlikely. Have I been playing each before their official release dates going as far back as the 90s? Oh my god yes.
Will I keep playing them for as long as sanely possible? Not solely, but also my god yes.

This is an INCREDIBLY fun game to play, moreso over Age 2, as Age2 has very drawn out and less visually and aurally dynamic gameplay, for LAN parties.

The PvP scene is incorrigibly scalding and childish in both as well, but PvC is lots of fun in both.

Awful and a rip off for it's price, I was raised on Age of Empires 2 and I feel that this game took away aspects like resource gatherers now don't have to return to camps. But then they would take out combat options like having being able to make units stand still without having to go into setting and set it yourself. It took me 3 games to figure that out, I was so angry.
They have just made so many decisions that were just unnecessary.
Walls are useless because now every unit in the game can destroy buildings easily, outposts are okay.. use them every now and again and forts are pointless. Even ship battles aren't even that great because nearly every building has massive damage against ships.
And I hate that artillery automatically sets up when you click them to go a fair distance away from them.. There has been so many times where I have set them to attack but they decide to unset then move an inch then try to set up again even though they could've just moved without unsetting, this of course led them to their death by a single horse many times.. I wish that this was an option.. They wanted to make it easier and simpler but taking out things but it just ended up making things way more complicated as I had less freedom. I can press the set up button myself, it's one click.

Don't get me wrong, I like some change.. but this was way too much for me and don't get me started on how much this game cost still.
I still play this game in hopes that I'll actually finish a match without getting angry and shouting at the screen but I doubt it.

It was also good to see the official expansions ported to Windows 10 that were too expensive for my younger self back then. It's a pity the game is set up as three "Act"s that teach you to 
suck Overall this has been fun for the money and a good trip down memory lane!

This is a great game, but there are some points i want to mention to new players.
When you launch a game, do not choose "complete collection" because this is a vanilla game. Always choose Asian Dynasties (TAD), which includes all campaigns in the series and offers better UI and updated gameplay. You can also go to the game directory and choose "age3y.exe" and make a shortcut. 
For the skirmish game mode, you will need high Home City level for the full experience. For offline game play, you can create all home cities and easily edit some data to change your HC level (google it). For online gameplay, you can google "ESOC patch" and install it. This patch includes HC insta-leveling tool called XPMOD, but you need another player to use it online. It is therefore the best to buy this game with your friend, but you can ask for the help on steam and ESOC forums.

Ive been playing this game for 11 years now, and it is simply amazing. The campaigns are a good introduction to the mechanics of the game, and provide a great storyline. 

The real gem here is the competitive multiplayer aspect. The game was released in 2005, and still has a very active online community. In a few months the first ever competitive esport competition is being held. Age pf empires sets the bar for real time strat games. 

Also, this edition DOES contain both the Asian Dynasties and Warchiefs expansions, and to access them you need to right click on the game in steam. The AS expansion and vanilla game are usually only played, as the warchiefs was a little unbalanced for competitive play. 

If you are into RTS games, [strike] and enjoy using your brain instead of fortnite. [/strike] then get this game in the sale and see for yourself. 

Just buy the game, play and see for yourself, it is simply amazing.

It is literally the best game I have ever played!!!
I recommend it to anyone.
Had this game for about 4 years now, I still come back to this game all the time. This game is very much alive still due to loyal fan base.

The Good:
Visually the game is stunning. The graphics look good and the animations are just a delight to watch especially when building come crumbling down. The buildings now actually look like they can fit people inside them.
Gameplay wise there are few changes such no resource dropzones needed, Home Cities which are some nice additions for the AOE series. Personally I found this to make the game more fast-paced.
Although AOEIII is not as popular as AOEII with respect to multiplayer the campaigns are really fun to play. The cutscenes and the writing make the story very engaging.
The music and sound effects are nice to listen and unique to the gunpower theme of the game. However I would rate AOM my favourite.
The expansions are fun to play.

The Bad:
The pathfinding is good but at times bugs out during combat when you target an enemy.
No grid based hotkeys. Since there is so much variety in units and buildings it is a bit difficult to remember the different types of buildings and units in each civs. This is simpler in AOEII.
It does not support Steam Workshop neither has Steam Achievements.
Those annoying confirmations when launching the game on Windows 10.

Overall a fun addition to the AOE series.

Age of Empires 3 is one of my favorite games of all time, and indeed my favorite strategy game there is, the graphics are stunning for a game almost 15 years old. I love the gameplay, it gives a lot of freedom in my opinion, great civilizations, great music, great maps and the home city customization system and the whole card mechanic is really fun and keeps the player wanting to battle and level more to get those juicy cards! The campaign mode was different from the typical Skirmish Mode but it was really nice! Now for a few of my problems with the game, Skirmish Mode although fun and can provide quite the challenge on a higher difficulty. But the AI can be pretty stupid sometimes, then some really simple things are missing from the game like at the Market why no food for wood trade and vice versa? Why no Imperial Besteiro upgrade for Portugal and the list of small things goes on and on. And for last the glitches, the game can have so pretty annoying bugs, that till this day haven't been fixed. As for the amount or civilizations and maps, I am satisfied but maybe a bit more options in terms of games rules and maps would've been nice. But overral AOE3 is a fantastic game, and has been one of my favorite games since childhood.

After more than a decade since the game's initial release, I finally got the chance to play it - and boy did I like this game! Sure, it changes many things which were core foundations from the previous two AOE games but it also enhances, expands and re-invents the series!

I love the concept of home cities as well the overall historical setting of the Discovery Age. More so than any other AOE game out there, AOE 3 (and all expansions/dlcs) provides me with the feeling of a dynamic game, which doesn't necessarily end up as a resource grinder (like AOE1 and especially AOE2). The graphics are still honestly quite beautiful to me, the music is great, the civs are awesome. Age of Empires 3 may have been the end of the old AOE series, but at least the series went out with a bang....or did they?

I loved the simplicity of Age 1, hated the upgrading festival of Age 2, but Age 3 I like.

It is a very functional little RTS, and it "plays" well, like a good RTS should.

You can group 50 units in one control group, unit limit 200, 50-99(+boats) of them are settlers.

The civs are all very different, which is refreshing.

The most annoying bugs are the following:
1. On "attack move" some units stop just beyond range and get bugged there.
2. After units kill a hero, they also gather around it and end the attack move.
3. AI does not repair buildings.
4. If AI main towncenter is destroyed it gets very paralyzed.
5. Ai hero does not build a new TC. If his TC is razed the hero will just stand there if he is revived.
6. When adding units to a control group, the front units ahead will slow into an intolerable crawl to "wait" for the rear to catch up.
7. Only elite AI will use wagons to build anything other than a fortress.
8. Allied hunter gatherers get bugged into shrine animals.
9. Sharing resources is only 100 per click.

Still the game is very playable, and AI modding will repair many things.

I do recommend this if you like to play a nice RTS.

Thank you, Steam, for putting all three AoE IIIgames on sale for $9.99! I was so happy. I couldn't afford the $40 price tag.

I played this game for hundreds of hours on Mac (pre-Intel chip era). I find the key commands and unit control of AoE III much more intuitive than the previous Age of Empires releases. AoE III only requires three resources (food, wood, stone) rather than four (+gold). This allows users to focus on the end game: building an army and smashing their opponents into oblivion! Watching enemies scream and cartwheel across the map when blasted with the Imperial Cannon never fails to bring joy!  

The learning curve for AoE III takes several hours (if you've never played Age of Empires), but the tutorials and single player campaign are engaging so learning isn't a grind. The first time I played it, I stayed up all night to finish the campaign. The Warchiefs campaign was also intriguing.

The card system is cool. For each XP level your civilization gains, you earn a new card for an in-game bonus (e.g., 12 Musketeers for free). There are over a dozen different civilizations in the game, plus six more with the two expansions. The card systems adds replayability to the single player aspect of the game that previous AoE’s lacked,  allowing your hand of bonuses to become stronger the longer you play a particular civilization. I didn’t enjoy being pwned in online multiplayer, so this was a fun way to relax and beat the computer on the Easy setting while still leveling up my cities.

Shortcut Keys

The following keys can be very helpful during gameplay.

HOTKEYS
SPACEBAR – Center View on Selected Unit
ALT – Display Details on Selected Unit
H – Toggle Home City Screen
/  – Cycle Explorers
'  – Cycle Ships
.  – Cycle Idle Villagers
,  – Cycle Idle Military Units
;  – Cycle Wagons (Covered Wagon, Fort Wagon, Outpost Wagon, or Factory Wagon)

FIND
T – Town Center
CTRL+A – Artillery Foundry
CTRL+B – Barracks or Blockhouse
CTRL+C – Church
CTRL+D – Dock
CTRL+E – House or Manor House
CTRL+F – Fort
CTRL+I – Mill
CTRL+K – Bank
CTRL+L – Plantation
CTRL+M – Market
CTRL+O – Outpost
CTRL+P – Trading Post
CTRL+Q – Field Hospital
CTRL+R – Arsenal
CTRL+S – Stable
CTRL+V – Livestock Pen
CTRL+W – Wall
CTRL+Y – Factory
CTRL+Z – Capitol

Use the following shortcuts to create new buildings when a villager is selected. For example, to create a Dock, select a villager, and then press the D key.

VILLAGER BUILDS

A – Artillery Foundry
B – Barracks or Blockhouse
C – Church
D – Dock
E – Town Center (this is for the Explorer only)
E – House or Manor House
F – Fort
I – Mill
K – Bank
L – Plantation
M – Market
O – Outpost
P – Trading Post
Q – Field Hospital
R – Arsenal
S – Stable
W – Wall
V – Livestock Pen

Age of Empires III is a game developed by Ensemble Studios and published by Microsoft Studios and is the third game in the Age of Empires series

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

Age of Empires III overall, however, is a fun game to play, yet sometimes flawed, but is a great strategy game to play in short bursts!

I didn't really care for this game back in the day when it came out, and replaying it now, I still don't really like it. It holds none of the charm of the other games that came before it, and I don't know why, but I just don't find playing it fun. Then there are the problems with unit pathing and the camera. The camera is zoomed so far in that I find it not just annoying, but almost impossible at times, to play. Meanwhile, the units constantly organize and reorganize themselves; finding it difficult to get close to one another. While I like the idea of melee units being able to throw flaming torches at buildings to burn them down, rather than just hitting them with sword or pike, it causes huge pile ups that badly disrupt your attacks.

I don't know, maybe I could have recommended this game to die hard fans of the series, or new people looking for a good RTS to play, but I just can't, especially with the unbelievably high $43.99 price tag. This is just insane, especially on a game this old. I am glad I waited to retry this game and got it on sale. Don't buy this one, buy Age of Kings or Age of Mythology, they are much better games.

This game is good. Not great but good. Campaigns aren't that interesting and main one (not expansions) follows some fantasy pseudo-historical plot. The game shines in good old comp-stomp battles.

The game is wild and unbalanced. It's a traditional empire building formula you see in similar "Age of" games but with some twists. Random maps are full of stuff you can control and exploit, like local tribes with unique units and economy upgrades. Factions are much more varied than in similar games, it's more similar to Age of Mythology in that regard. Even Europeans that are similar have some very big twists. 

But most importantly it has an interesting Home City mechanic. While other complex RTS feel like a Civilization game in real-time this one is a Colonization in real-time. You have a city for every faction you play and it grows in "level" allowing you to buy new "cards" you play during the game. Those cards may be a unique bonus for your economy, a free building, resources and so on. You can choose a different game before each game thus customizing your faction. During the game, you gain XP for practically everything and it allows you to get new cards and after the game, it can level up your city allowing for new cards.

This system is abused in multiplayer as there was easy to cheat. Having a higher city level doesn't make you flat-out stronger but it certainly makes things easier. So this system works best in singleplayer. AI is decent and interesting to play against. It knows when he's lost and has a lot of entertaining taunts giving personality to every opponent. You can train on lower difficulty settings against a passive AI to learn the ropes and then go higher using new cards and tactics. It allows for a nice progression as you get new tricks even if you lose a battle. Surprised few RTS ever used similar mechanics. Company of Heroes has similar system in-game but it doesn't have a progression between fights. C&C4 was similar but it had hidden basic units behind progression wall.

There are problems with the game, of course. UI didn't age well, it will look stretched on your widescreen monitor. Battlefield view is too small, I want to zoom out all the time. Fonts are pixelated too. But the game itself looks and sounds great, graphics are at a perfectly acceptable level even in 2019. Controls feel modern and comfortable unlike, say, AoE2 HD.

TLDR: Don't expect this to be a game to play forever in multiplayer and you'll be fine. It's fun, it's interesting, it's often sold at -75% and you won't regret buying it.

Age of Empires III deserves far more attention than it does. The Complete Collection is made up of three games, the original AOE III, War Chiefs, and Asian Dynasties. (After installing the game, boot up Asian Dynasties for all the content, though boot up the other two to see the different game art.)

From a setting standpoint, AOE III focuses on the 18th and 19th centuries, and you play civilizations through the telling of lost legends. From a gameplay standpoint, AOE III plays very similarly to predecessor Age of Mythology, where there is more emphasis on macro decisions. Most of your micro will probably focus on your heroes and their special abilities. Like other AOE titles, there are plenty of civilizations to play. Each civilization has entirely unique unit compositions and build orders, so there’s a lot to learn and remember. The campaigns include a number of cutscenes along with the scenarios for added entertainment. Don’t expect a challenge from the AIs in any aspect of the game aside from scripted events in the campaigns.

The expansions include shorter campaigns but have interesting stories to play along with. The biggest additions are the added civilizations that certainly diversify the possible play styles.

The music is awesome and should be its own soundtrack if it isn’t one already.

I have two misgivings about the game. One is that the Tab key is reserved and can’t be remapped for whatever reason, so my idle villager hotkey for AOE III is, well, the far-away tilde key.

The other strange thing, although I like the concept, is the card-playing mechanic. During a match, you can level up by killing enemy units or exploring the map, and when you accumulate enough experience, you can “play a card,” or call upon your “home city” to grant you upgrades, resources, or units. In addition, outside of the match, you can construct your deck by choosing with cards you want to have available in a match, and your home city level carries over between matches. Being able to carry abilities between matches seems unbalanced.

Microsoft might be Remastering AOE III like they did AOE II, but AOE III is a great RTS title on its own as it is. If you’re coming from other AOE titles, don’t let your experience with those games prevent you from enjoying this one.

I've been playing Age of Empires since the very first title. By far the furthest leap in the franchise, and with the addition of Home Cities, the gameplay is more dynamic than ever. I did notice that the AI is a bit weak on certain maps, and will tend to overbuild themselves out of resources without expanding. I appreciate the fact that workers no longer needed to return to a settlement with resources, which cuts down on the need for a ton of collection points scattered across the map. The ability to diverge from the normal Age advancements is a really neat feature that throws a curve ball in late game skirmishes. The singleplayer storyline is well done, and continues across the origianl game and first expansion.

By far the weakest entry in the series, though still a passable RTS. Devs broke everything that made AoE great however.

- maps are too small
- hard caps on number of most buildings and units
- no gather points
- infinite resources
- homecity 'level-up' cancer
- homecity cards favour predictable 'all-in' strats
- any defensive play is no longer a viable strategy
- raiding is no longer a viable strat due to astronomically high villager health
- all strats now revolve around homecity 'cards', either all-in booming or rushing
- no Persian civilisation
- nations are EXTREMELY inbalanced (Japan, Britain, France, Germans OP AF)

The game still looks and sounds good however for casual players. But don't expect a good MP experience.
(This review is for 'serious' RTS players, casuals should still find this game just fine)

Unfortunately, given its normal price ($48 for a game that came out a decade ago!), I can't say this game is worth it for what it has.

Why? Well...

1. While the maps are very creative, the circular world doesn't really work and makes some maps feel smaller than they should be. Although when compared to the other AOE games this is out of preference, you can't create your own maps either so most of the maps aren't great to play on.

2.  IF YOU ARE GETTING THIS GAME FOR MULTIPLAYER, CONSIDER MY ISSUE! I've had past trouble with the SOE servers which periodically disconnects on me resulting in a ragey loss (not due to my lack of skills in the game!). From what I've experienced, if you don't live in the northern hemisphere then you'll struggle to find a game that doesn't lag horrendously, assuming you're not playing with friends from the same world region. This might've been fixed since I last played (many years ago), but judging on the amount of people who actively play - I highly doubt they would bother!

3. Singleplayer is good, but may not be particularly challenging for some. I enjoyed it, but having played it years before I'm not as impressed with the high price tag.

4. Graphics were a good upgrade from the other AOE games, but both predecessors have just as much in terms of content and playability.

5. Units are created in batches, instead of the old one for every click method. This works for some civilisations/units, but otherwise seems unbalanced in some instances.

Therefore: get it on sale if you really want to have a go, but I don't think this game has aged well in some cases, and other games give IT a run for its money in terms of playablility and quality.

It gets a lot of hate from AOE 2 puritans but it isn't fair. yes it's not like AOE 2 in the sense that AOE 2 is just an upgraded version of  AOE 1. AOE 3 is it's own unique game and it performs pretty well. I recently got it on steam and only have a few hours currently but I also played it many many hours when it first came out on hard copy years ago. Whether it's better or worse than AOE 2 is for you to decide, but on its own:

Good things: AOE 3 is a faster paced game than earlier AOE games running only around 1 hour for a 4 player game (I've had AOE 2 games that would run 4 hours sometimes). It's pretty easy to get the hang of the game and it doesnt require much micromanaging at all. the home city shipments is an interesting way for you to costomize how you want to play a particular faction and is for the most part, pretty balanced among all factions (except iroqoise, they're garbage and don't add much content from the minor tribe that they were before the warchiefs expansion). the asian dynasties expansion was a great expansion that added lots of content and new ways to play.

Bad things: if there were things they got wrong with this one, a big one is the massive loss of control over your custome games. no longer can you have 3 seperate teams or choose the map size andces resources and victory conditions. you also cant set computers or yourself to be a random faction in multiplayer anymore. they also lost all the fun and creative game types that they had before (king of the hill, regecide, that super fast mode). another downside is that because you cant create a faction without starting a new home city, it discourages players from jumping into a game and trying a new faction out because they want to level up their old one.

It has problems but this game is definitely worth the time if you are a fan of the RTS genre. its good for multiplayer and single player and i highly recommend trying it out.

This was by far my most favorite thing I picked up of all time.
I had just loaded in my first game, as Germany because of Prussian Space Marines, which I know aren't in this game but I was in it for the meme to be honest.
I spent the first 30 or so minutes just calmly building up my first city, and fending off a few attacks, but then, god forbid, Henry the Navigator dares to kill my favorite settler, who I had mining outside my city walls. I quickly pulled a Reich and made a massive military in around 4 minutes, using it to completely slaughter his colony. It was a long battle, and we were about the same strength at the time, but luckily Ivan the Terrible(who basically was my best friend) came in with some cannons and helped crush the resistance in the town.
I made a little colony over it, getting some wooden walls and continuing to live in peace.
But that didn't last long, as I eyed Britain, who would quickly take apart my new little town within 20 minutes of it's existence, murdering it's inhabitants.
For some reason Suileman surrendered around here, I think Napoleon was able to destroy him, but this was literally his only action.
I knew what I had to do, I quickly built up a massive army, one that would rival the strongest of all time, and marched into the English colony.
I ran my Uhlars in, slaughtering it's inhabitants who were working the farms, to prevent further growth of their military, as my cannons and infantry chipped away at the outskirts.
Eventually, we made it into the main part, as Ivan and the Dutch came in and helped me crush the English resistance.
We came out victorious, but already I eyed my last target, Isabella of Spain.
I quickly rebuilt my army, as I had taken some heavy losses, and rushed into the colony.
The battle was short but bloody, but I came out on top.
I smiled as the "Victory is Yours" text popped up on my screen. I had won my first game.
I know one thing now, this won't be my last...

My thoughts after playing a game of this for the first time? 

It's okay.

The graphics are VERY dated, but that's to be expected with a 9 year old game. 
The mechanics are challenging to master but not so complex that you have no idea what you're doing when playing for the first time, especially if you've played an RTS before.
The games themselves can be quite long, but there's always something to do or work towards to keep the player occupied and not become super bored. Maybe you need to save up coin to upgrade something, maybe you have a bunch of units you want to build to wipe out your enemies, who knows.

That said, the mechanics for this game feel slightly less complex than the first Age of Empires, and the combat feels quite unsatisfying since ranged infantry and artillery style units are just so powerful. Couple that with a system that grants bonuses to players just playing the game that lets them get various "shipments" and it feels much more simple and as a result less rewarding compared to other installments in the series, at least in my opinon. It's still an Age of Empires game, but not exactly the best one to play.

No where near as good as Age of Empires II, but alot easier to pickup and play.

While I was not a fan of the gunpowder era as much as Ancient Times(AOE I) and Medieval Times (AOE II), the variety of units from European and Asian units are pretty cool, allowing some Ronin vs Musketeer type battles.

However, I don't know how much I like the progression and deck system in terms of multiplayer, as low levels are disadvantaged due to not having as much cards and call-ins as other higher level people(Think of the Company of Heroes 1-2, Dawn of War 2-3 type commander systems)

A crap ton of more restrictions are in the game compared to AOE II however, such as a limited amount of Castles/Towers/Town Centers/certain units you can build, almost limiting on what strategies are viable (but still plenty compared to other RTSes)

I could talk about AoE III really long, from many diffrent views, but because it would be too long, i'm just gonna make it short:

In the game, there is a yet nowhere unseen combination of the genres RTS and RPG in the form of HomeCity, which can make players to play the game longer, especially in the use of infinetely variable multiplayer. Age of Empires 3 is for me one of the best real-time strategy game of all time and I highly reccomend this game.

Great solo player game! Only way that I can really relate this to anything is just an RTS (Real time strategy) Clash Of Clans. Ive tried the online a few times and?? Very delayed when clicking on stuff(I assume LAN would be great though). Building your village with only a few settlers  Of your colony to almost 200 people including soldiers, villagers, cannons, dogs, bears, and a whole bunch of other units.  I don't really play the campaign. However they have a "skirmish mode"  , this is basically you choose the settings and how many AI players are included in this.  This game can be at 1 versus 7 or a free-for-all Or even even 4 versus 4, There has to be a minimum of 2 players, you and an AI. So there are lots of different teaming methods you can play with. Each game(of a 4 versus 4) lasts me about an hour and a half or so on the hardest difficulty. This game also allows you to save your game, so you can come back to it?? 6 weeks later if you wanted. Not only that, but there is mod support for this game. Allowing for custom maps, custom units, pretty much everything! I do reccomend buying this game as a whole! 

(Ps: the game defaults the resolution to like 480p, I figured this out on my 35th hour of playing. Make sure to turn it up to 1080p! It looks really nice!!!)

Age of Empires III is a real-time strategy video game developed by Microsoft Corporation's Ensemble Studios and published by Microsoft Game Studios. Is the third of the saga wich portrays the European colonization of the Americas, between approximately 1492 and 1876 AD. There are fourteen civilizations to play within the game. Age of Empires III has made several innovations in the series, in particular with the addition of the "Home City", which combines real-time strategy and role-playing features.
One more fantastic strategy game remembering the old times :)

My personal favourite RTS game ever, to the people who say AOE2 is better I say this.
AOE 3 is better becuase
-It has a leveling up system so you feel like you've done something
-You don't need to set a "gather point" for your villages to collect resources, it just comes to you
-Builing takes 1 minute not 10 minutes
-Nicer graphics (doesn't matter gameplay wise though)
-A map customiser which I feel is better than AOE 2
-No DLC (you get it with the game)

Anyway on to the actual game:
Pros: 
-A leveling up system
-Great fluid graphics and several maps
-Loads of different countires and units
-Extremly easy to play (far easier than AOE 2)
-Get to customise your home city when you level up
-Your own explorer who is pretty much your captain but he's very intresting 
-People actually play mutliplayer
-Great difficulty levels ranging from beginner, which teaches newcomers how to play to very hard which is "very hard"

Cons:
-Some units could be seen as overpowered *cough*cough* Imperial Bombard
-The campaign is fairly boring
-You can just cheat and gain high levels in single player skirmish

If you enjoy RTS games like the Total war series or Age of Mytholy then you have to give this one a try becuase it's one of the best. 10/10
