 As far as the campaigns go, Age of Empire 3 is both silly and dull. All 3 campaigns are bland bits of silly historical fiction. The home city gimmick is cute, but far too forgettable and there is a shallow hero mechanic. You can find treasures using heroes, and you have little hero abilities but there is no deeper mechanics involved. All the makings are here for a subpar rts, but AoE 3 doesn’t even manage to be that: nothing makes the slog of the campaigns exciting or enjoyable. 

Age of Mythology houses the much better campaigns, narratives and abilities, and even the previous AoE fairs better on every front imaginable

Age of Empires III isn't a particularly bad game, but it is not as good as its predecessor.

Overall the game feels more cluttered and its only advantage to AoE2 are more modern game mechanics.

AoE 3 has great sound effects, songs and it is fun to play. However, don't expect anything if you are coming from AoE2. Maps are waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too small compared to AoE2 and pop-limit cannot be higher than 200. So, don't expect huge battles and prepare to "invade" your enemy with a few artillery & infantry. 

This game doesn't have workshop integration, however you can get mods from external websites. Mods include bigger maps, more pop-limit etc. 


Overall, AoE 3 is worth investing your time and money in; if you're into RTS games.

Don't buy this game if you want to play online. There are several issues with CD-Keys with the Steam-copy of this game going on. You need an ESO-Account to play online, which you can only create one with each copy of the game. I was not able to create an account because there seems to be an account using my CD-Key already, altough I never gave it to anybody. I tried to contact the ESO support because of that, but there is no support anymore. Steam support only displays me an e-mail adress of ESO saying that they can't offer support for this game. Mails sent to this adress will not get anywhere, as I already said. So I tried to refund the game. But Steam says I played more than two hours so can't get any refund. I made the suggestion to get a new key but Steam only ignored it. Regarding that I do not get all the functions of the game, that is not really fair. 

I am not the only one having an issue like this. When you research on Steam- or ESO-Forums, you'll see that many steam-customers can't create an account due to an error. 

The game for itself is great. But with this policy from both ESO (Microsoft) and Steam is a reason that this game should not be bought anymore. The current price for an over ten year-old game can be another reason.

Following on from the monumental success that was Age of Empires II, this third installment brings the franchise into the light with jaw-dropping graphics and a style of gameplay that is a dream to play. The attention to detail is astounding, from everything to cracks in a townhouse just about ready to crumble, to the wide range of sound effects ranging from hilarously stereotypical comments from Isabella of Spain to Frederick the Great of Germany, to the sounds of cannons such as the Falconets. Even the different environments manage to evoke a sense of belonging, as if one is truly standing in the snow in Siberia, or sweating bullets in Caribbean - not an easy feat for a strategy game to achieve. The fact that no major installment have been released since (Age of Empires IV anyone?) is simply a testament to the replay value and endurance of one of the all-time greatest strategy games released.

VERDICT: 10/10

That's one very impressive game we have here. Age Of Empire 3 is taking the whole series into an entirely new level. I have to be honest: I felt lost at first with the new management system. An Home City to support you? Where's my castle? Wow now the ships can fire cannon balls instead of flaming arrows! 
The campaign has changed too as now it's not about the story of a civilization but more like a story of a Family. You don't play anymore the great leaders of our long history. Now you're following the story of the Black family from the great great great grandfather who was sent to the New World to his great great great grand daughter trying to expand her railroad company throughout the US and their feud with a powerful secret society willing to take over the world.
But you should not worry, once you taste it, you don't want to get back! I just love that game as it's such a nice breakthrough. Of course some things doesn't change: the AI is still throwing soldiers at you waiting to be massacred by your awaiting army as it never changes spot, you can still use cheat codes to get improbable but very efficient weapons (Gee that cannon firing explosive pigs is top notch as not only all your enemies are wiped out in a single shot but there is also that yummy smell of bacon all over you as well! Yum yum!)

Age Of Empires 3 was a very good game. I had lots of fun it should have only taken me 10 hours to finish, but it took me 30 hours. All in all, it was very fun. Act 1 and 2 were by far the best because it was just fresh to my mind. Act 3 was also lacking in a good story because by then it was obvious that Beaumont was going to betray you.S sadly I cheated half of the missions in the game. I  mean I did feel like I hadn't finished it properly; like it was cheated (because it was). My favorite act was act 2 because I sort of knew how to play it by then and it wasn't too hard (i still cheated though) But then I started the war chiefs. Act 1 was just a breeze but act 2 was fun up until then the second and third last mission I must have been stuck on them for a good 10 hours. I  remember a betrayal by Holme a bit because it was so obvious that he was going to betray you. It just felt wrong killing the Sioux though, because at the start Chayton said that he was half Sioux, but you spend half of the act killing the Sioux, but suddenly Chayton goes "oh I don't want to burn down a tiny village" and ends up destroying a massive one. So in the next mission, you kill Holme but straight after that this other dude comes along and says "I don't like you, and know I'm going to kill you".This leads me onto the final DLC. It was one of the best DLC's I ever played. It's mission's were so fun. I only struggled on like 2 or 3 missions. In act 3 though most of the victories didn't actually feel that good because I finished them so fast(only took me like 3-5 hours). But I made sure in the last mission that I did all the secondary objectives just so it would last longer because I really did enjoy this game. It should have only taken me 40 hours or so but it took me closer to 80 hours to complete. My most joins memories were when I used cheats because i was so overpowered and it was just funny, or when I would be on a mission for more than 2 hours and I would finish it, and I would shout in a proper British accent "YOU ARE VICTORIOUS". Overall it was one of the best games I have played all year, and if it were to come out this year it would be hated because the graphics are sooo bad, but it was just so fun

I honestly have always had a soft corner in my heart for any game from the Age of Empires Franchise as I literally grew up with this franchise. I've played all the games and have enjoyed them all as well.

This game is no exception. It's visually pleasing and still offers all the familiar control mechanics and gameplay as all the other AOE games. All in all a great game that should have offered a great experience. Alas I've gotten it refunded.

Now the reason I'm not recommending this game and requested the refund, is the mishap everyone suffered with online play. Steam and EOS (Ensemble Studios Online) have kinda screwed over everyone who bought this game midway throught the summer sale by issuing [b]unauthorized[/b] CD Keys that don't work when setting up an EOS account for online play. 

Obviously online play is a major factor when it comes to buying this game so I would recommend you wait for the issues to settle and perhaps buy the game during the next sale. Except [b]AS SOON AS THE SALE STARTS[/b] so that the CD Keys don't run out again.

[h1] Reasons to buy/avoid: [/h1]

[u] Buy: [/u]
- Great graphics (considering it's an '09 release)
- Easy Game play
- Storyline - Personally, I adore it. [spoiler] The journey with Morgan Black through the isles of Malta, the close bond of friendship with Kanyenke and the betrayal from Alain Morgan. [/spoiler]
- Not too grindy - I like games where I can invest a few hours and get something out of it. AoE III is one of those games where you can probably complete the main quest within 10 hours or get a single player civ. to at least level 25+.
- Level up - I love games where there is something to play for, in this case, there is Home City shipments. You level up your city to gain cards, each card grants unique upgrades and troops.
- Music - I'm a fond believer of "Good music = Amazing game". AoE III doesn't dissapoint. All through my childhood. and even to this day, I am singing the main tune. *baa baaaaa bee noo noo baaaa*  \^o^/

[u] Avoid?: [/u]
- Not too disimilar
- Less civilisations compare to previous games. If you don't own the expansions, you only get to play 8 Civilisations (6 more with expansions, 3 each)
+/- Resource Gathering - As we all know, in the previous Age of Empires we had to locate storehouses near economic points so we could gather resources faster. Well in AoE III they completely scrapped that idea. All resources collected now go directly into your economy. This is a positive as it makes the game less reliant on storage locations but a negative as it removes a reasonably big tactical element.
- Too little gamemodes - This annoys me a bit as I love to mess around on games and try new ideas and tactics but how can I when there's only two gamemodes? Deathmatch and Supremacy, both good in their own ways, but I want more. *Bear in mind that this point applies directly to Home Cities*

All in all, I [b] 100% Recommend [/b] this game. It's almost always on sale during winter/summer sales so keep an eye out. Honestly don't think there's much point in buying it full price.

-Please bear in mind, this is my personal opinion and others will disagree-

Severly Underated RTS Classic

On release, AoE III was an innovative game that failed to meet the expectations of the franchise's fanbase. Some of the mechanics of the original games were abandoned, and while there are still many similarities, the original game did have a very different feel from the earlier titles.  Additionally, while the singleplayer gameplay and campaign were fun, the limited number of civilizations made multiplayer predictable and unbalanced.  Some of the ensuing criticism was well deserved, but many of AoE III's shortcomings were more than addressed by its two expansions; both of which are included in the complete collection.

The complete collection is an excellent game that I highly recommend. The sheer number of available civilizations and customization options alone warrant acclaim for this innovative title.  Pushing new frontiers of the RTS genre, AoE III allows players to develop each civilization to accomodate various playstyles.  It maintians the classic four resource economy, but intorduces additional aquisition strategies to help propel you thorugh the ages.  The combat is addictive with strong animations, better, physics, and far more unit variety than any of its predecessors.  Explore a unique time in military history.  Use horses, cannons, and muskets to topple your foes as you explore the wonders of the New World or conquer the familiar geography of the old.  If you enjoy classic or historical RTS's, this game is a must for your collection!

Apart from the graphics and the interesting RPG-City system, this is by no means an improvement to AoE2. Here is where it differes from the legendary classic, and why that sucks:

The maps are symmetrical, you can just draw a straight line from your base and know where your enemy is. This is fine in Starcraft or Dawn of War, but what I liked from AoE2 was how Nomad and large randomized maps would force you to explore and tread carefully.

No diplomacy.

You can't choose a giant map and leave several player spots closed so you cant, for example, 2v2 on a 4v4 map.

The military squads are small, yet AoE2 has you field army's.

The interface is twice as big as it should be.

It looks great, and I suppose you can have some fun with the campaign, but gameplay wise and multiplayer wise, I don't think it surpasses AoE2. Looking out for AoE4 to see if they have learned from this mistake.

Excellent game: it's not as popular as it's predecessor, but it keeps the good work done by the team so far.

It an excellent educational tool, as each civilization is basically a new world of interesting facts about this civilization (e.g. Japan's "Onin Wars" card, which basically let's you know there was an awful period in the history of this country characterized for the vandalism shown by it's belligerents, the Ikko Ikki monks, the "isolation" mode in the consulate, that's only for Japan... each civ has its own features).

I would say the advantage over AoE II are mainly that it deals with uncomfortable situations in the previous one (farm limit, ships limit, units different populations, things that should be changed in the previous game). As well it's use of mercenaries, cards, natives & trade make it a different game from AoE II, not it's remake).

A decent reimaging of an old classic.

While not a classic in its own right, or a master class in startaegy. Age of Empiers III is a decent strategy game that manages to bring update the franchises play style and strategy components.  

To those who are familiar with the franchise its a lot of the same with a few interesting new additions.  To those who are not, its a pretty standard romp in real time strategy.  You have a city you build buildings, workers, gather resources-- pretty much what you'd expect.  

The gameplay is solid and very, very similiar to its predesesor.  It does feel a bit stream lined.  There are less things to build and research overall.  In fact, they basically combined stone and gold into a single resource, only leaving the player to have to gather and manage three resources (food, wood, gold).  Far from a bad thing, it seems like these changes stream line the game and speed up the play.  Other new additions like trading posts which establish trade routes place emphasis on controlling the map at all times and further keep the player active at all points in the game.

The really new:  RPG lite.  Affecting the gameplay, but technically outside it, AOE III has introduced a RPG-esque elements that allow you to level up your different civilizations and build "decks".  Technically cards, they are a series of upgrades you can pick off several techs tree (some unique to your civilization)  that can then be activated in the real game using experience gained in that game by fighting and kiling units.  It's not the most well implemented system, but it is novel and I had a great time looking through it, planning things out, and seeing how each civilization could specialize.

Overall,  its a decent game.  The graphics and UI are up to date.  There are some novel additions to the genre.  It isn't a must play.  But as cheap as it is, you may want to consider checking this out if you are a fan of real time strategy games.

I recommend Age of Empires 3 (With Caveats)

Its a good RTS in its own right and brings something slightly different to the AOE series / RTS genre.

However i wanted to caveat this in that whilst being called Age of Empires 3, it is riding off the coattails of its predecessor's, as the game diverge's significantly (in my opinion) from the heritage of AOE 1 and AOE 2's recognisable playstyle. 

For that reason I don't recommend this game if you are looking for a similar play expericence to AOE 1 or 2 and should therefore treat this as a standalone game and not part of the AOE series.

Ahh Age of Empires III... You like RTS games? You like muskets and cannons... You dreamed of creating a colony in a new world? Then this game is for You!

Dont look at my hours, I've only recently have bought AoE 3 on steam, my 3 boxed copies speak for themself.

Campaign is amazing, AoE 3 and its first expansion "The War Chiefs" tells the story of a Black Familly and their fight agains Circle of Ossus, mysterious order looking for Power in a new world. And Assian Dynasties tells 3 diffrent yet very interesting stories set in Japan, China and India. 
For those that finished Campaigns there are skirmishes on plethora of maps and possibility of leveling your chosen nation capital... and for brave enought, there is multiplayer :D

But let's skip details and be honest.
Age of Empires 2 had way better gameplay, most AoE fans aggre with that, when it comes to multiplayer, AoE 2 is way better, as it's MP scene is still alive and healthy while AoE3 faces many ESO connection problems, and lack of players. So if you want an RTS with healthy MP, go get AoE2!

Graphics are amazing! while I can't wait for definitive edition of AoE3 I still to this day enjoy this gem from the past.

And then there is my favourite part of this game... Map Editor! Age of Empires series always had easy to use hard to master map editors, 3rd one is no diffrent. The possibilities of this bad boy are almost endles :D Throughout the years I played many custom maps made by the community, from Colloseum where players have to defend against waves of enemies to survive, to custom RPG maps with own story and quests. Don't belive me? Shameles plug here, but just look for me on YT to see for Yourself some A class Eye Candy that can be made with this game.

So yeah, while AoE2 is better gameplay wise, give AoE3 a chance, story is good, graphics are good, soundtrack is just Epic, and for me personally its time period... the colonial era, makes this game one of my favourite game in existence... easily top 3 :D
What else needs to be said about it in this day and age?

This game gets alot of hate and i can understand why but it is still a great game. i cant wait for the remastered version. because im sure you heard that they are doing a remaster of the series followed by the launch of Age of Empires 4. they already remastered the first game which i havent had a chance to play yet and the second already has an HD version so im curious to see how they are going to up that one because it was one of the best RTS games ever made in the history of RTS. lol but seriously if you look past all the hate for this game you will find a very interesting take on the gameplay. less about building and more about importing and the struggles with colonizing the new world. well maybe not so grand. but you will want to level up your city and customize your imports to the new world to help you in your battles. you cant really just rely on yourself. you need the imports from the home city to get special units and buildings like the fortress. you have to really think about how you want to use these resources. its very different from other games in the series. less self sustainability and more strategy with limited resources. you just got to look at it a different way and look at it from the theme of the game. i would highly recomend this game to someone who likes strategy games. casual and pro alike. it offers alot of uniqness to the series.

People might say AOE 3 is not a worthy successor of AOE 2....

....thats definately untrue. It truly isnt AoE 2 with improved graphics people hoped for in 2005, but its the better online game!
In one word - its comfortable! 
Somce features from AoE 2 were removed in order to make the gameplay WAY faster, so you dont need to waste hours playing one game only. Instead, most games online run from 10 - 20 minutes, so you can have several "Rounds" of pure economy AND war. Its great for people with not so much time at hand, still wanting RTS games.
But you can have really long games as well if you chose Treaty mode offering up to 40 minutes of no attacking each other.

The graphics were really ahead of its time, still looks excellent and highly detailed, the game physics are amazing when canons blast away units or lancers stab the cavalary to their doom.

Also the Home City System is genius! You get different cards over time to build you own individual (or several) decks, which will help you during your game. Eventually you have more cards than you can build a deck with, so chosing them wisely or in good order makes the gameplay unique for you and other players aswell.

Why do AoE 2 lovers then hate this game? Because they mainly play single player and the single player campaign of AOE 3 is completly boring and doesnt follow historic events. But to be honest, THIS GAME IS MEANT TO BE PLAYED ONLINE or MULTIPLAYER , and thats where AoE 3 is the clear winner - its a lot more fun!

Its one of the best RTS out there without any doubt! I rebought this game after owning it on disks for 10 years, its a game you wont regret buying!

How do I know this? Well asfter around 2 hours I went to the store and came home with 23 girlfriends (Every race, but Black) and I banged them good.

Aww, Age of Empires. I remember playing this game back when I was young. Good to see my strategy didn't change much. Randomly place buildings, mis-manage my workers, solve problems with brute force building of units, and then building a wall around the entire mess before sending out the largest army I can build to see how it does. 

This time, I had the pressure of time. An hour isn't exactly a lot of time in this style of game, especially on a map with 3 other computer controlled settlements. However, I'm glad to report, that my mass army of "screw it" won the day. Well, sort of, I demolished one computer player before the hour was up. Fun stuff.

FULL HD AND OUTER ZOOM IS POSSIBLE! (guide)
--> many thanks @wizaerd & RoosterCantrell:

1. CHANGE RESOLUTION (guide from wizaerd):
"For the Complete Collection (base game) I edited C:\Users\<Your Profile Name Here>\Documents\My Games\Age of Empires 3\Users\NewProfile.xml and edited these two lines:


<Setting Name="optiongrfxres">1920 x 1080</Setting>
<Setting Name="optiongrfxwindowmode">true</Setting>
"

2. CHANGE CAMERA ZOOM (edited guide from RoosterCantrell):
"For me, the path is (I have windows 7 64-bit):
C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/SteamApps/common/Age Of Empires 3/bin/Startup

You are going to want to find these file: game.cfg (backup recommended!)

After opening the .cfg file, search (there is a search function in notepad) for the word "zoom". You will find at least 6 entries for the word "zoom". Change Both Normal and Max Zoom to a higher number, I use 70, which I rarely zoom to this new maximum value.

maxZoom=70
normalZoom=70
minZoom=29
extraZoomPercent=0.15
zoomSpeed=0.5
zoomWheelDivisor=30.0
"

3. Improvement Mod
Download & install the Improvement Mod to optimize the game with many features:
http://impmod.blogspot.de/p/features.html

4. Graphic Mod (new textures..)
http://www.moddb.com/mods/graphics-mod-aoe3/downloads

Before this incredible game was added to Steam, I could honestly say in all the years since its release I've played well over 300 hours. This game is therapuetic. Played AoEII since 2001 and you could add at least 2000 more. It deeply saddened me when Ensemble went bankrupt. However if you want MORE than the complete collection, check out the unofficial sequel/expansion pack: the Wars of Liberty mod. Adds an extra 15 or so civs and a TON of features, even modifying the current vanilla civs with special features, and with a reasonable community backing and dedicated admins keeping up with patches every now and then, you will NOT regret this.

Nevertheless, this game, and franchise, is truly up there with the best RTS games money can buy. To this very day, I enjoy a cheeky skirmish or two to kill time. Absolute classic.
This game is... astonishing, a true masterpiece. Get it, on sale, but get it.

AOE is an amazing series that has aged extraordinarily well imo.  I think AOE 2 is still my all time favorite, but Age of Mythology, AOE 1, and AOE 3 are all fantastic in their own ways.  If you can LAN, these are all even better and are on par with StarCraft for fun factor.

I'm sure I've played 100's if not 1000's of games since these were released in the late 90's, but I still find a lot of enjoyment.  I love that new content is still available for AOE 2 and AOM.   The games are all very well balanced and interesting with a lot of different styles of civs that you can play.  This is one of the all time classic series and I'm very excited to hear Microsoft is working on a new title in the AOE series due out in '19.

First off, I should say that this is my first and only AoE game. I picked it up recently after discussing it with a friend some while back, and was surprised at how much I was enjoying it and disappointed I'd missed out on this series when I was younger. This is a great RTS for players who prefer taking things at a bit slower of a pace, or happen to enjoy history or alt-history media.

The games best features are its mildly-randomized maps and that you are rewarded with level-ups for factions you take a liking to and keep playing. While the 'card' system can be seen as a distraction to the actual gameplay, I find it a compelling way to customize a factions call-in abilities.

Age of Empires III is nowhere near the best game in the series, but it is my favorite due to nostalgia. This game's campaign felt lacking to me, but its strong point was definitely the skirmish mode. I remember I had a skirmish once that lasted 2 whole months of my summer vacation, and it was all spent on an XP in my grandma's basement. I also remember making a PowerPoint slide that had information on a bunch of different statistics and tactics in the game. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the series or RTS games in general, and if you like keeping track of statistics, it will likely make the game more enjoyable for you. It may not be the best, but it's definitely worth a play. Just a warning, if you have the disc copy like I do, it will not work on Windows 10, so just wait until the game is on sale if you want to play it.

Age of Empires 3 tries some new ideas to break the monotony of RTS classics.  I have not played any multiplayer, but have beaten the single player campaign of the original and expansions.  The story of the original is a good time, but the expansions aren't as interesting.  Play styles vary considerably between chosen "faction", especially in Asian Dynasties.  


Positives

+Playing different "factions" provides a unique experience, especially across expansions.  Your play style has to adapt to new mechanics introduced by expansions.  Adds replayability and keeps the campaign fresh.

+Despite being quite different from AOE 2, has the completeness you'd expect from this franchise.  Game looks and sounds great while feeling complete.

+Less micromanaging your villagers.  Farms/plantations (gold) and even some "wood farms" allow you to set and forget villagers instead of having to worry about running out of mines/reseeding farms.  There are trade-offs for these "lazy" sources of resoures, but It's nice late game to not have to worry about it.

+Ships look cool.  Zoom in on em', they look impressive.

+Enjoyable difficulty curve.  I played most of this game on hard (I switched somewhere early in the original game) and it was challenging, but doable.  The cards helped.  You could make it harder by not using certain cards.  


On the fence....

-/+Card system...this is the main difference been AOE III and other RTS games.  You have a 20-card deck that provides "shipments", which can be anything from a couple of villagers to a trickle of wood resources to an upgrade or unit not available otherwise.  It adds another layer of strategy and I didn't mind it too much on singe player, but not sure how it goes on multiplayer.  You definitely have to use it, or at least I did when I played on Hard difficulty. 


Negatives

-Story isn't super gripping.  Most RTS games I've played, story is pretty weak, so maybe I'm picky.  The original AOE III campaign is enjoyable, I will say that. The acts tie together well.  It's not that the missions aren't fun or varied, just that the presentation is poor.  Characters don't really grow on you, and historical significance is only learned from reading (for the most part).  I understand why the expansions don't tie together and I'm ok with that, but yeah...not memorable.  


If you enjoy RTS games, you will enjoy this one.  Not much to gripe about here.

I'll try multiplayer soon, but anyway, I expected much better experience.

I have been playing Age of Empires since my cousins introduced me to AOE 2 way back when. I remember seeing the boxed version of this game when it first came out. I was $10 short and my mom reluctantly bought the game for me after much convincing on my part. I booted it up and started to play around with the different civilizations/empires in the game. This game is the reason why I got into studying history. Certain upgrades or names in the game were inspired or referenced by events in history. As I began to see the connections between the game and parts of real life, I loved and appreciated the game even more. Don't let the low hours fool you, I've bought this game twice and have suck a good portion of my time into this game.

What you get when you buy Age of Empires 3

- A vibrant look at the 17th and 18th centuries
- A beautifully looking game (even after 12 years)
- A wonderful soundtrack/atmosphere
- Immersion into a world that no longer exists
- A great RTS/Base-Building game
- A game that still has multiplayer servers up on the Internet
- Age of empires (what more do I need to say?)

Trying to play with Lenovo g580, Windows 10, Intel HD 4000, 8 mb ram. I can't. The problem is AoE III asks for 64 mb video ram (vram) and Intel HD takes dinamic ram for video but it shows 32 vram in details (the minima), so AoE doesn't uderstand it and Lenovo BIOS and Win10 don't give you a way to fool the game. Microsoft makes both the OS and the game and they don't understand each other. If you can play the game I think it seems to be a good game.

This game is worth every single penny. It's a classic RTS game. It's fairly easy to get the jist of. Hell, even I got the hang of it quickly. That really speaks volumes to me. 

This game is even better when you have someone to play with or against. On occasion, the online service will run into problems and people may not be able to join your game and/or you won't be able to join theirs. I have only recently started to notice this problem (10/31/15) so I am not sure how common it will become. It usually just takes a bit of time to fix itself though.

As mentioned before, it's real-time strategy. You get to pick the Civilization that you like the most. These include the Germans, Spanish, British, Asian civs,  Native American civs, and a lot more. Each have their own strategies. In the game, you are pitted against another Civ(s), whether it be an AI or an actual player. Your civilization's economy relies on 3 things: food, wood, and coin. Your villagers, or workers, must work to gather these resources and build your colony. You can use the resources to create buildings, buy improvements, and train an army.

Eventually, you'll need an army. There are infantry, calvalry, and artillery units. You can also have naval battles with various ships if there is a body of water on the map. As mentioned before, there are numerous strategies for victory. I'd recommend trying out all the Civilizations and see which one you feel most comfortable with.

Overall, this game is godly. It will stand the test of time, and I hope that the online service will remain available for years to come (after all, it still has a sizable community).

P.S. There is a fort called Het Huys de Hoop

Fast paced, masterful, timeless and simply beautiful! No other game has surpassed AOE III in terms of hours played even though AOE II came close. AOE II was a great game for its time, but AOE III has not left a single thing to complain about even 12 years since its release.

This is the RTS formula perfected. Not overly simple like Starcraft or Halo Wars, AOE III makes you manage your Economy and your Military, quite like the real world. And the UI and gameplay tweaks from AOE II have now made micromanagement a thing of joy rather than frustation.

This is one of my favorite games.
In short, you take a certain empire and play as it. You train soldiers and settlers and you can blow up your enemies
or, if you prefer a more peaceful approach, you can establish a tycoon on all those trading posts you built earlier.
In the end, when the dust settles, you gain experiance to level up your "home city", the hub of whatever empire you
selected. You can get more home city cards, which when you get enough exp. in game you can send for to get some freebies, and you can customize the buildings and/or who goes about your city. If you get enough levels, you can even
have your citizens talk in little speech bubbles when viewing your home city. Now I'll get to the more simple way of reviewing this game:

Pros
-Graphics are impressive.
-Home city customization is great.
-It's fun to play as each and every empire, which all have their own unique perks.
-The diversity of upgrades and units is awesome.
-Blowing up enemy building with mortars has never been more fun or entertaining,
-The campaigns are really fun to play.

Cons
-AoE II gets new expansions, even though it's really really old, but this one hasn't had one for a
long time.


Conclusion
This game is awesome. If it's on sale, have no hesitation to buy it.

I feel like people where far too eager to write this game off due to its infiriority to AoE2.  The game is charming in its own right, and has several outstanding features that I wish its predicesor had, such as villagers not having to walk resources back to town centers, and galleons being able to train units which gives you this amazing sense that ships are run by massive crews, and sieging a beachhead feels very real and impactful.  

Yes its blatant lack of standard steam-based multiplayer is ABSOLUTLY damming, but it's still a great Lan Party game! And its single player skirmishes are still great to take part in!  Invest a few hours in it to figure out its bells and whistles and I promise you you'll start to enjoy your time with it before you know it.

For those completely new to Age of Empires: it's a real time strategy game that allows you to take contoll over a nation by building a town, growning your economy , building an army, upgrading armies and production, with the goal to defeat the enemy AI or player that tries to do the same as you.

Age of Empires III focusses on the colonial and Imperial era (1492-1870). the base game is centered around the exploration and colonisation of America by European states. The expansions (all included in this complete edition) focus on the native Americans (Aztecs, Souix and Iruquois) and on the asian great powers (China, Japan and India).

Many people say that Age of Empires II was the best of the series, i think Age of Empires III is the best. Reasons for this:

- Ability to have an unlimited amount of gold and food allows you to infinitaly recrute your best units which makes multiplayer matches more interesting (compaired to Age II's lack of ways to have infinite wood, stone and gold, which forces you to use wood based terrible quiality units if you want to be able to spamm units for a long time)

- More intersting Civs: Yes there are fewer civs than in age II (Age III has: English, French, Dutch, Germans, Ottomans, Spanish, Portugese, Russians, Souix, Iroquois, Aztec, Indian, Chinese and Japanese) but the civs in Age III are far more unique than in Age II. For example: the English has the Unique Longbowman unit, the most upgrades for musketeers, rocket production and the ability to get a free setler from every house. The Dutch on the other hand have Banks that generate coin for free(no other civ. has banks), but a setler limmit of 50 (normal is 99), and the unique cavalry unit called Ruyter, which is the only cavalry unit in the game that only costs 1 pop limmit. This together with the low setler limmit allows the dutch to have a larger army (150 men) in the field than other civs (100 men).

- A story mode campaign with videomaterial of the game to simulate the story, in stead of the written stories of Age II. The campaign is much easier on normal difficulty than the campaigns of Age II on their lowest difficulty, but still challenging on hard difficulty


Now to be fair there are some negatives:
- The AI is much less smart and fast than in age II (in Age II i get destroyed by medium AI, in Age III i win against Expert AI half of the time)
- The graphics of Age III are actually worse than those of Age II
- Age II got remasted and now has mod support in the steam workshop, Age III hasn't
- Age III has a lot less maps than Age II, and Age II's maps seem to be better balanced than those in Age III

Over all it's still a good game, that is completely worth it to buy it (although it is of course advised to wait till a steam sale and than just buy the whole Age of Empires bundle)

In response to the many negative reviews this game has gotten recently (Click "Read more" for my own review):
This game needs compatibility mode when running on Windows 10 (I'm using WinXP SP3, but Win7 should work as well), and an ESO (Ensemble Studios Online) account can only be created from within the base game (no DLCs). ESO can be played fine on the DLCs, it's just that the account needs to be created from inside the base game.
Note that in the box that comes up when starting the game, selecting "Age of Empires III: The Complete Collection" will actually run the game WITHOUT DLCs. To play the DLCs, you need to select one of the other options. (The Asian Dynasties has all of the content of The Warchiefs in it)

My actual review:
+ Gameplay (Perhaps Age of Empires 2 was better in this regard, but this game still has great gameplay IMO)
+ Graphics (at least when fully zoomed out)
+ Destruction physics and ragdoll physics
+ Okay AI, with a wide range of skill level settings.

+/- graphics style (matter of opinion, look at the trailer and images to decide if you like it)
+/- somewhat long waiting time to start a match (usually 5-10 minutes for a 20-50 minutes long match), but not as bad as you'd expect for a game that was originally released in 2005 (retail version)

- AI cheats on higher difficulty levels.
- Online mode has a lot of unkind people, as there is no report system.
- Arrow keys bound to camera controls by default. This can be changed, but doing so takes a while.
- No way of rejoining left matches (if the game crashes, or if your internet goes out for more than one minute, then you're out of the match, and there's no way at all to rejoin it.)
- Ships are kind of weird (they're big and tend to clip into eachother)
- The AI handles ships very badly.
- Technical difficulties listed up above (Win10 issues, ESO account creation issues, and confusingly named options to run the game.)

I remember when I bought this game when it came out, and being an avid AOE and AOE2 fan, my intial excitement was soon dashed when I played this seemingly radically different game, on an old pc that made the gameplay laggy and prone to the odd crash. However, approaching this game later, and on a better system, I soon realised I was unfairly harsh on AOE3.
Firstly, it looks glorious. Sure, maybe not for todays standard of graphics, but even in 2017 the game is good looking and the worlds and campaigns seem enchanting and all differ from the other quite markedly. 
Second. The core of AOE is there, resource gathering, exploration, base building and military and unit management. With a few new features, that initially I felt a little gamey coming from AOE2, however, these features, such as having a home base which offers bonuses or allows for certain strategies all enhance the game and enable each civilisation to be noticeably different from the others.

For multiplayer I still stick to AOE2 and will look to give AOE impending new edition a try. However, for singeplayer, I gotta say, I believe AOE3 surpasses AOE2 and if that is what you're looking for, this game, with all the DLC added, offers plenty of enticing and appealing single-player gameplay.

I played the heck out of this game way back in the day. This is a real-time strategy with two parts. The first is the campaign, which is pretty unremarkable. Second is where the game really shines - skirmishes. The big draw here is that you level up between games, which lets you unlock new and more powerful bonuses, which you can activate by doing things such as creating units or controlling train routes.

One huge plus for this game is that the countries play very, very differently. In the first two Age of Empires games, the civilizations were basically the same plus or minus a technology and one unit. Here, the difference is huge. Russians create units in "batches", the Dutch rely on gold instead of food and can build banks to create a flow of passive income. Those are just some examples - each civilization plays very differently and all of them are interesting. Except for Spain, but you can't win 'em all. I definitely recommend this to anyone who likes real-time strategy games!

I have almost 180 hours on this game. I love it so much. I never understood why it got all the hate from the community. It still is an AOE game, just a bit different. I love the new gameplay techniques that you get with the home cities system, and all the civs are actually unique in a lot of ways. The main campaigns are awesome, and I love the historical fiction settings. I also really enjoyed the DLC campaigns as well. It really refreshed my love for history, and more specifially, colonial history. This game earns a solid 9/10 for me, and I can't wait for AOE4.

I'm a big fan of Age of Empires since my childhood, I played since the 1st game came out, and I played the 2nd one with the 2 expansions.

So, how can I describe the 3rd game?

It's one of my favorite.

The Complete Collection offers you the 'Asian Dynasties' and 'War Chiefs' (can count as expansions).

Asian Dynasties is for people who like to play civilizations like China, India and Japan, let's say Asia Civ's and they offer you a more complexed gameplay but it's always fun!

War Chiefs is for people who like Tribes such as Aztecs, Sioux and Iroquois, it remotes to the time of the Colonization, it's so good to play yet it's complexed as well.

It offers as well some Civ's well known such as mine (Portuguese), British, Russia, Turky, ... 

The graphics are awesome and it is not that heavy even on old laptops, the water looks fantastic, the soldiers, the battles,  all completely on a new level.

I'm looking forward to Age of Empires IV!

The path-finding algorithm is very terrible, because every unit need a moment to think before it reacts. I'm using Core i7 7700K with 16 GB of memory and GTX 1070. With this supreme PC spec, it's just unforgiven for the game to have such slow response. It's even worse than the Empire Earth series released a decade ago.

Moreover, the game pace is also very slow and not challenging. And to make it worse, the group selection is not working as it is supposed to. I added more units to a certain group, but when I selected that group, some of the previous units in the group were left out of the group. This is the MOST STUPID BUG I've ever seen in an RTS game!

Age of Empires IV is coming out and after the disappointment of Dawn of War III I feel it's important for me to get my thoughts out in time for Relic to change their formula before destroying this franchise too.

[b]Age of Empires III[/b]
This game was a gem if you started with it like I did. I prefer it to AoE II, but had I started with AoE II my preference would probably be different. The general consensus seems to be that AoE II felt more dynamic. The maps were larger allowing different tactics such as flanks and the battles needed more micromanagment which could make a difference between victory and defeat even when you were outnumbered. AoE III automated a lot of the game and made it simpler for new people to manage armies, economies and upgrades. This could have been seen as a good thing had they increased the population cap and let you do more complicated war tactics, however it instead streamlined the game mostly into rushing in the second age. All of that said I have spent over 300 hours in this game before I bought it on steam and continued playing it here. The enjoyable part of this game that most of the AoE II players feel like they lost out on was the feeling that they created an empire and went to war with competing empires. They don't feel like a little skirmish, they feel like all-out war (AoE II moreso than AoE III) and that's what brings me back to this game. As soon as you join a league or go online people will rush and that removes most of the fun of building and maintaining your empire in the midst of a war you are intent on winning.


[b]Age of Empires IV[/b]
Relic is making Age of Empires IV, which I would be excited about 10 years or so ago. Dawn of War was amazing and Company of Heroes was pretty good too. DoW II and CoH II however were not quite as enjoyable and DoW III (which promised a return to basebuilding) was unfortunately more disappointing than both of them. I am nervous about AoE IV so I am writing this as a list about what you have done well and what you could improve on for AoE IV hopefully people agree:

[list]
[*]Make the battles massive without focussing on special units that turn battles, it takes strategy not gods to win wars

[*]The morale system from DoW works well in that universe, but it should be tweaked to account for hunger and weariness while marching or fortifying a location far from home without making them miss every shot and doing zero damage

[*][u]Emphasize base building[/u]. This is the feature that people want most. If things go badly (or really well) let me make a new town centre on an island. I want to have outposts where I can train men in for sustained fighting if I need to hold land in a specific area. CoH lacked the ability to build any meaningful forward bases and made holding land difficult. It should be on the attacker to displace the enemy fortifications.

[*]Get rid of the pre-game choices like CoH commanders. When the game starts it should be somewhat even, I don't want to feel like I have lost if they select Tank, while I select Infantry. The AoE III homecities were done nicely because the players who have spent more time can have better cards in their decks, but it is not game changing (besides the rushing cards). It is also nice to have all your options open so you can combat your opponent without having to close off other options you could use later on in the game.

[*]Longer games feel more satisfying. You can launch attacks if someone's score is higher than you to try and keep them down, or hustle your economy, but making it immidate combat that could determine the game is the most frustrating thing I have had to deal with online with AoE III. I don't mind losing if it feels like I did all I could, but if I was just caught with my pants down I leave unsatisfied.
[/list]

Overall Relic has made a lot of games that I have enjoyed countless hours in, but the older stuff has always been what I go back to. Please let AoE IV break your streak and be a really large, slow-paced, empire building game.

The game gives rather different experience than Age of Empires II, it's much more faster paced, the natural resources are limited, but you can get farms, plantiations and factories that produces them in unlimited amount. Also, you can capture trade outposts that allow you to get more experience needed for shipment's (which give additional units, resources or upgrades for your nation). With those changes you are able to fight for longer, have bigger battles and in exchange - have more fun.

The unit combat is really sweet and enjoyable, mixing various types of units gives an edge in the battle, which means that spam blobs can be easily defeated if played right.
The game is well balanced, even with weakest nation you are able to defeat any other nation,
and if meele combat is your kink, you can have a lot of fun here.

The only con is that camera position is really really close to your units, and you can change it just by a little bit, which might be irritating, and when you alt+tab the sound options reset's so you have to change them again.
Also, there is a lot of problems with multiplayer if you want to play via lan, which I still didnt figured out.

Age of Empires 3 is a RTS game set during the colonial-Napoleonic era. While the battles aren't as large scale as Total War or Cossack's, the game features an amasing single player campaign and skirmish mode. The multiplayer lobby enables you to play with (and against) friends and strangers. The Complete Collection comes with the Asian Dynasties and War Chiefs expansions, adding a total of 6 new civs to the existing 9. 

Features:
-Single player campaign
-Skirmish
-Multiplayer
-'Home City' XP system

Age of Empires III Offers gamers or normal people who want to try video games the next level of realism, with advanced battle physics and uparalled visual detail.
It places you in the position of a European power determined to explore, colonize and conquer the New World. The time period of the game features stunning scenes, from towering European cathedrals to courageous tribes of Native Americans, and spectacular combat with Industrial Age units like rifled infantry, cavalry and tall ships bristling with cannons. In addition to technology upgrades, Age of Empires III also features a slew of new game-play elements, including the concept of a "Home City", new Civilizations units, technologies and an immersive new single-player campaign that spans three generations which we did not have in the old one. 
The Dlcs of the game are a must have because you get to have 3+3 new Civilizations from Indians to Asian with fantastic and unique upgrades and units!

Ahh such a fun little timesink.... And by little I mean long campaings. You could easily lose days to complete the game, this is just a fun game. Simple, but fun.

-The story isn't half bad and is actually engaging which can be hard to say about an RTS
-A cool feature they designed into the game is a home city. It levels up as you play matches/campaign scenarios  and provides nice perks. It's simple but I feel as though it ties each match together so it feels less like a "whelp starting from the ground up... again" type game. That feeling is still there, the edge is just taken off. 
- Multiplayer - never played it and really don't care to.
- Factions, there are tons to explore!
- Has it aged well? maybe...yes? Not as well as a "classic" but it's still great.
- Is it worth buying it now? I did... so  yeah but you wont miss anything if you choose to pass.

My earliest and most enduring experiences of gaming can be drawn back to the old 'Command and Conquer' and 'Age of Empires' days, where real-time strategy games were a dominant market that was seeing constant expansion and inovation. However as the years went on newer and fresher takes on strategy began to take influence and MOBAs or days-long grand strategy games took over.
Yet after over a decade of gaming I find myself coming back to my roots, and in particular the third and "final" installment of the core 'Age of Empires' franchise. Why? Well I'll tell you.
For many the original 'Age of Empires' is the epitome of antiquity, static and janky movements of soldiers, a low population cap and a small, unimpactful variety of Civs to play. Taking command of a unique civ means little to the gameplay, meerly a change of aesthetic and a neat way to warp events of history in your image.
'Age of Empires II' and its expansions are by a substantial margin the best heralded of the franchise, with changes to civs now supporting unique and more potent traits, unique units, tech trees, appearances and of course the dozens of languages spoken by your loyal subjects. Its true I still come back to 'Age of Empires II' for an honest and lengthy game of good-old-fashioned strategy, games lasting anywhere between 1 to 4 hours.
That brings me to this game, 'Age of Empires 3'. In my mind it is the best Age of Empires, that has adapted to the previous real-time strategy market with a plethora of units, buildings, cards and civ traits that change up the experience even more. Many my criticise the card system, wherein your chosen civ has a deck of cards you unlock at each age in-game, allowing you to improve your economic power, bring in fresh and rare units, unlock new technologies, or even start a revolution.
The variety and adaptability of gameplay is what draws me to this game, a sense of real immersion in my civilization as I level it with each victory, and watch the homecity grow to further my colonial conquests. Both expansions offer new stories for singleplayer and a handful more civs to play as, however I believe the Dynasties expansion to be the stronger effort.
Balance has never been a huge issue for me, however I would like to see a Workshop brought into effect for this game as it could use the love of its community to keep it alive.

AOE3, though not as popular as its predecessor AOE2, has some favourable features such as Home City shipments. By the aid of the right deck settings, it is possible to turn the tide of the game when things are getting worse for yourself. For example, it is harder to finish your opponent with a rush since you have the ability to send a troop to counter the raiders. In addition, it is better not to be dependent to the amount of resources on the map solely. You can gain resources from many alternative ways (other than wood) without exploring the whole map. Also, each unit has its own pros and cons in AOE3. In  AOE2, training scores of cavalry would mean an unequivocal victory. Native tribes and their precious soldiers and technologies give an important advantage to superior explorers of the map. For example, you are British and possess the best foot archers in the game. You ally with Caribs, and their upgrade will also enhance your archers, too.
Great Game

PROS:
+Many nations to play as, each needs a different approach. Some nations are better for bursting, some excel at rushing.
+A huge number of awesome maps. Most of them are not only different visually, but also require different resorse management (for instanse, some maps have many bushes and very few huntable animals, while the situation is different with the other maps)
+Graphics are pleasant
+You can set the game speed before each skirmish. On fast speed, you need to be faster than your foe at all aspects. On slow speed however, you need to come up with superior strategy
+High replayability
+With higher difficulty, AI starts to play better instead of just getting abnormal boosts to everything
+The market. This building lets you sell your wood or food for gold and vice versa. What is fun however, it calculates of much of each unit there is in the game and gives you trade value of it. For example, if you spam the button 'sell 100 food for X gold', at some point worth of food would decrease to minimum.
CONS:
-Map Editor could've been better. Maybe it's just me, but I consider it ugly and uncomfortable
-The MP servers are empty, there's noone to play with.

It is with great joy that I can say that this game does still function even so long after its initial release. My only complaint with this game after so many years is that the only way to get it to function properly is to undergo a process that most would never do on their own. 

On a Windows 10 operating system, it will likely not function upon launching any of the three versions, declaring that it 'failed to initialize'. To fix the error, you must navigate to your 'Apps & features' page, scroll to the bottom, click on 'Programs and Features' under the Related setting section, and in the resulting menu click on the 'Turn Windows features on or off' button next to the windows shield at the left part of the screen. In the NEXT screen, you must click the drop down menu for 'Legacy Components' and enable DirectPlay. You may need to restart your computer afterwards or take other measures such as running as an administrator or verifying your game cache to get this game to work. 

While it pains me that this solution is not properly displayed on the store page directly, there is a solution. Currently, only the efforts of the steam community can ensure that people realize that this solution exists, which is why I deleted a prior negative review. I did so because I ran into the problem and decided to create a negative review in the hopes that someone could diagnose a problem that I could not diagnose myself even after numerous attempts and rooting around steam for a while and missing the correct solution. 

I have nothing but praise for the game itself, as the campaign is really quite entertaining, and the 'new'(As this game is quite old) mechanics for the Hometown makes the game nearly infinitely replayable. I purchased this game during the Steam Sale for a very cheap price, but I would gladly pay the full price tag to enjoy this game. Also, play Asian dynasties as it includes all previous content, including the other dlc. I don't honestly know why you would choose to play the basic version unless you absolutely despised teh Asian/Warchief content, which can be safely ignored anyway if you are so inclined.

For those of you who might look at my recorded hours and scoff, I will inform you that I played this game for hundreds of hours from a CD, that being years ago. Also, cheatcodes exist and can be extremely funny. (Especially the giant thingamajig that slaughters everything in its path and has no right to exist in the game's timeline, lul.)

FYI. Running Windows 10 64 bit latest version. Installed and starterd right up, without any tweaking even though I was fully prepared to get it running by any means if neccessary. A lot of people are having issues if you read the reviews, fortunatly not me. Great game.
Always love Age of Empires and this one is no exception beautiful rts

If you have bought the game and have Win 10 or above and can't start the game through 'initialisation error' follow these steps:
I
-Click Control Panel 
- Programs 
- "Turn Windows features on or off"
- Open folder called Legacy
- Select DirectPlay 
- Tick the box
Hope this helped!

Having accumulated several hundreds of hours in the original standalone version, this is by far my favorite strategy game. While the campaign is, in my opinion, compared to AOM less fascinating, this game shines at its multiplayer. The map details to the randomly generated maps, the classy background music, the vibrant colors, the importance of each different unit as well as the (extreme) differences between the different nations really make this game a gem. If there's ever going to be an AOE4, the milestone set by its predecessor will be hard to reach.

However it changes when i started playing this game, not only this game is different to the type of games that i usually play, it taught me to try on different genres of gaming and as such i fell in love with Real Time Strategy. Close to perfection. This game includes a splendid singleplayer and multiplayer experience with solid explansions. The gameplay is, as with the previous game, almost flawless. This review is from someone who hasn't played the game long enough to know it well. I'd like to consider this more of a comment to the game, rather than a review. 

And when it comes to the question "do I recomend it?" I'd have to say, I wouldn't really recommend it, no. But I have nothing much against it either. 

As a fan of Age of Empires II, this game just didn't deliver for me. They added some new features (compared to AoE II) like that villagers don't have to drop off their resources anywhere (like food at mills), and the hometown-consept. The hometown basically means you level up the civ you're playing, and it makes it so you only play one civ all the time so you get an advatage by having a high level hometown for that civ. The upgrades are also hard to locate, (and i still can't figure out where to upgrade walls to stone...) because the buildings aren't called the same for all civs, another factor making you play only one civ. I guess it's just that AoE II was so plain and easy, that all the details and extra stuff in AoE III really just confuse me. If I had spent more time on the game, I would have understood it better, and liked it better for sure. But since i already know Age of Emprires II, which, for me, was much easier to learn, I'll just play that. 

As for online, it is, let's say, challenging. And now I'm not taliking about beeing beaten up online, I'm talking about just even getting into an online lobby. I have managed (after much time spent on hosting) to play with friends, but I haven't tried playing with strangers. The stupid thing about the online function in AoE III is that you can't just play online through Steam. You need to create an Ensembe Studios Online account, which just makes it that much harder to play online.
I LOVE this game. Lots of fun to play with family and friends.

Do not be fooled by the hours played I have displayed here as I have played many many more. So to this date this is the last AoE games made. It has lots of new stuff and is very inovative from the first two...and yet...a bit boring compared to them. For some reason the developers simplified building stuff and gathering resources then they added home cards and reinforcements. At first it looked cool. But as you play it somehow distracts you, from the game, from the upgrades selectable in the buildings. It lost the AoE charm. By no means is this a bad game! But it falls short even with the great War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties expansion packs. I truly do recommend this as a RTS game because it is good, but it just lacks something to be really great...

Age of Empires 3 is a classic RTS that pits towns against each other in a race for resources and ultimately, military domination. The varied maps and civilizations allow many playstyles to be possible. On a desert map, trees may be scarce, creating a struggle to control the limited timber. Or, on a swamp map there may be very little land suitable for construction, leaving you to build several tiny bases instead of one fortress and leaves you vulnerable to attacks. An Ottoman empire can churn out villagers to gather resources quickly until they can build the civ's crown jewel, the great bombard, a massive artillery cannon. A Dutch empire can build banks that spawn gold, an important currency to build advanced units. Once you think you've played a few matches and think you've learned the best way to play a civ, you learn that you can bring a deck of "cards" in each match. These are free units or important upgrades that can be spawned throughout a game. Winning matches earns experience, which can be used to unlock new cards in a tech tree fashion, largely unique to each civ.  Some sivs might seem weaker at first, but unlock a bit of their tech tree and they become incredibly powerful. The graphics and physics engine were far ahead of their time and although noticably old, are not an eye sore on this brilliantly fun game. Age of Empires is at its best with friends, so I highly recommend convincing a couple pals to buy it with you. The single downside is that you cannot make more than two teams, so you can play 3v3, but not 2v2v2. This is a minor blemish on an older game that does little to get in the way of enjoying this lovingly crafted strategy game.

Overall this is fun, but it changed things without learning lessons from its predecessors, which leaves it feeling rather empty. 

They’ve increased the number of general game options from AoM.

Artillery has a much bigger role – in previous game you didn’t really have devastating artillery

You no longer need drop points, a nice improvement to the eco side of things.

There are a good variety of maps, but you can’t preview them!

The AI is still maddeningly dumb – your troops will happily sit under missile fire and not fight back, they will let the enemy just waltz straight past them. If you accidently walk too far and reach enemy territory you troops will simply die. This can make combat frustrating as you have to babysit your troops continuously.

2017 Edit: 
I would still recommend this game today, but if it was a "one or the other" situation, I'd recommend taking a look at AOE 2: HD. 

To elaborate a little on my original review, when this game came out, I was a die hard AOE 2 fan still, and a lot of the mechanics in this game (the cards especially) I saw as a gimmick. I figured they had just run out of ideas or something. Thankfully, I was wrong, I haven't played enough of this to say more but its definitely a good buy.

Age of Empires 3... This game is legendary! Not as good as AoE II but still a worthy competitior especially being the second to last game the legendary Ensemble Studios released. The amount of mods available and being created is amazing and the user-base for the multiplayer is as populated as it's ever been. It's great fun alone or with friends, if you're playing Arena, Risk or many of the other user created game types there is something that any strategy lover can find in this game.

Tl;dr, if you enjoy strategy, you will enjoy this.

If you like Age of Mythology, you will love this game. Takes all of the factions that were around during the landing on the Americas and throws them into a literal deathmatch. Certain factions have different ways to advance unlike Mythology's 2 way route. EX being that China has to build wonders to advance where as factions like France or Dutch advance from the town center. Not to mention that but there are multiple ways to keep your resources going in the event of material being scarce. I come from a long background with AOE1 and 2, so by comparison, this game was an overwhelming disappointment. The game is, for one, not easy to just pick up and learn. The traditional control scheme of gathering resources while building cities and armies is skewed, removing a large part of resources and troop-building altogether. Most of your income is transported from the 'homeland' to you over the course of a match, which makes sense from a colonial standpoint, but makes games painfully slow, leaves you feeling significantly less in-control of your empire, and narrows down the game into 2-3 playstyles regardless of your civilization choice. And while the game's visuals are nice, the scaling up of buildings and units alongside the 3D view leaves the maps feeling much smaller and minimizes the emphasis on careful exploration that was a landmark of previous games.

AOE3 is, essentially, not reminiscient of its predecessors in any way, and can hardly be called a continuation/conclusion of the franchise: The fact that AOE2 is STILL getting support and new, regular DLCs today while this game is largely left in the dust, speaks to how few gamers made the transition.

Have played this game for years and find it to be a delightful sequel to Age of Empires II.  I am fond of the new way that villagers gather and how units train in particular.

After the critically-acclaimed Age of Empires 2 was released and the expansion of Conquerors was extremely well received, Age of Empires III was bound to happen. And it did in 2009. Moving away from the Conquistador era, AoE III takes places around the 1700's when Settlers began to populate the American continent. 
For starters, the graphics changed from the sprites used in AoE II to a tridimensionally rendered objects in AoE III and that made it extremely unpopular for some, as the hardware necessities the software needed were not average. But all in all, the graphical performance of AoE III was extremely well done and on par with other RTS games of the era. Unfortunately, the RTS gaming era was about to end, with AoE III marking a significant decrease in interest the gamers had in this type of games. 
What was it? One wonders. The gameplay was extremely similar, and yet the charm AoE II had was somehow missing. The AI was not extremely hard and the games had all kinds of countries to be chosen from. 
The expansions made AoE III a bit better, with the return of ancient civilizations being an option just like in the Conquerors expansion. Unfortunately this made a small impact to the decreasing interest in this RTS. 
However, it still is a fun game to play. In 2017 it is a game that doesn't require extreme processing power and it is graphically pretty. 
The investment is well done nowadays. 
If you feel a little nostalgic and want to play one of the last RTS games of the era,

Buy it, play it and don't regret it.

Going to keep this review nice and short.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I played this game a ton in my childhood and I enjoyed it greatly back then and still do now.

[h1]Campaign[/h1]
The Campaign is quite nice and I really like how there are multiple ones and continuations of the stories.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
The population has dwindled down over the years but it is alive and if you have any friends who play the game, it's way more fun. There are plenty of custom games/modes you can download if you get bored of playing against others and/or bots.

[h1]Inside the Game[/h1]
There are a ton of things to do within the game but if you ever get bored, there are many mods that expand the game further. I personally use Napoleonic Era but there are tons of other mods and stuff.

[h1]Final Comment[/h1]
I would highly recommend picking up this game if you got the money to spare but if not, wait till a sale when the game is on sale and pick it up then. I picked this game up with the Microsoft RTS bundle which I would recommend getting but if you don't have the money or don't see the bundle on sale, this game alone will be fun!

A Great Game. I would say Age of Empires III is the best Of the Age of Empires series. But some might very likelly disagree with it. Specially comparing this game to Either Age of Empires II or Age of Mythology. But i prefer this game better.
I cant bring myself to like the graphics in AoE II but i really do like AoM. 
Now for the review iself: 

Graphics: Nicely Detailed Envinronment with an (G)UI that is appealing and very straightfoward so you rarely get confused in the menus. 

Sound: Really nicelly recorded voice acting with very clear sound quality and excelent sound effects.... Although they sometimes seem a little bit too bland. 

Gameplay: You got a Map, Quick actions on a few buttons on the right of it and Basic information about your units such as: Unit count, unit health, attack, armor and relevant stuff. To the right of it a simple grid of commands to give to your units with very self explanatory action. Buildings can build more than one unit at a time allowing for up to five units to be deployed at the same time. It takes the same amount of time to deploy 1 unit and 5 units. 

Story: The game follows the story of a family known as the Black family. In which the first of them is a man Named Morgan Black. The story revolves around this particular family. This family also has relevancy in The WarChiefs. Although more to the side. ANd little relevancy in Asian Dinasties. Needless to say the story is very well structurally built with a fluent and smooth continuum without any drastic changes except between Acts 1,2 and 3. 

Difficulty: The game gets progressivelly harder as you progress further in the story. The same can be said in multiplayer except in multiplayer there is a point where the difficulty will stall as the game seems like its going nowhere.
The final missions of each act are Significantly Harder than any other missions in each act. 

GFX: I already talked about graphics but now is for a less apparent thing. The effects used are detailed to a certain degree and really gives that extra punch to make them even more immersive. 

Variety: The whole game speaks variety. All countries have thier own unique characteristic. For instance, the Dutch can build banks which produce coin/gold constantly, albeit a little bit slower than mines, but never run out. The French have a better kind of villager (Called settler in the game) that is called "Coureur des bois" it gathers resources considerably faster, but cost more and take longer to train/build. 

Total: Overall, this game is a masterpeice for sure. But you probably wont want to play it if you dont have enough time. Because this game gets very long sometimes.

[h1]Age of Empires III is a great base-building RTS game for older and less powerful rigs.[/h1]

This game will run on almost any machine that will run Windows 10 as long as it has the space requirements met.  It's quick to load and easy to host/join.  It's not online-only.  It has single-player campaigns, one for the base game and one for each expansion, and it has LAN support.  (It has online features, too, though I never mess with that.)

The game is real-time strategy or RTS at its core.  It offers a lot of resource-gathering options and many ways to creatively gain a foothold over your competition.  It also has hilarious cheats! If you don't care to cheat your way to victory but need an edge over everyone else on the battlefield, there is the handicap percentage.

[h1]Why do I play this so often over all my other RTS games?[/h1]

My wife's laptop can't play much else.  That's the biggest reason.  We like playing strategy games cooperatively and AOE3 is one of the best-looking, most fun experiences we've got to work on her laptop.  Someday, I want to build her a gaming desktop out of my old parts so she can play newer, prettier RTS games.  Even then, we'll probably compare all of them to AOE3.

First of all there are a few things you need to know about this game if you're purchasing it:

It is a fantastic game in my opinion, but if you're coming here from AoE2 HD thinking it's the same game, you're quickly going to realize it's not. It is very similar, but the gameplay is slightly more basic, and a lot of upgrades and stuff are moved to different buildings which can be quite confusing.


PROS:

The graphics are absolutely stunning compared to AoE2 HD, and you don't even need a decent computer to run the intense graphics which is great if you're on a laptop

Camera rotation is a really cool feature that was included, although you'll have to enable it in settings as it is off automatically

Everythings moves in a lot more of a real time, if you know what i mean. None of the animations are jittery and it runs really smoothly

There are some absolutely incredible mods for this game which improve certain aspects of the gameplay, and i highly recommend you check them out

There are many, many, many other great things in this game, but i'm not going to go through them all as that would take all year


CONS:

A lot less features like upgrades, buildings, units etc.

Certain upgrades can be found in the weirdest places, for instance upgrades for wood cutting and gold mining can be found in the market for some reason. Please don't ask me why cause I don't know

This one most likely isn't a con for most people, but I take issue with it. There are no lumber camps or mining camps or even stone for that matter. This might seem good as it takes away certain annoying things like having to build a lumber camp everytime the trees get cut down near it, but it take a lot of the realism away for me. Other people probably won't find issue with it though, so don't mind this one

Homecities to me are bad news. You'll see what I mean

No steam workshop

The steam overlay doesn't work for me on this game, i'm not sure if it's for everyone but it definately happens to me.

A number of other issues that you'll find for yourself if you decide to get it

CONCLUSION:

I DO reccomend this game, despite it's list of issues, as it is well worth it. Even if AoE2 HD is the better game, this game's graphics make it still very immersive and enjoyable, and well worth wasting your life playing it.

BUY IT NOW OR I TAKE ALL YOUR TF2 COSMETICS


P.S. Get the Improvement Mod 4.8.4 from Nexus Mods. It fixes quite a few bugs, and adds and replaces a number of things that really should have been there anyway.

P.P.S. I wasn't kidding about the TF2 cosmetics. Buy the game

I wanted to like this game. AoE 3 is the third installment in the series, offers an intriguing main single player story as various characters search for the fountain of youth. The single player skirmishes, custom made games, and multiplayer is the bread and butter of the game. In single player skirmishes, enemies are further apart, giving your base time to upgrade and build your army to your specifications before attacking enemy camps. You receive experience points when in battle, building, working, etc. Combat is much better than in AoE2, but unless you are playing on harder difficulties, the AI isn't as good as in AoE2.  This time around you  get wars dogs as well as cannons, and other weapons. You can build decks of cards for the shipments to your colony, forge alliances with natives or other allies to take over the new world.  There are a few things in the game that is annoying. 1. You can't put your soldiers in patrolling mode, you have to manually put them where you want them to be. 2. The npcs are dumber than a bag of rocks. Workers will just stand there while being attack instead of fighting back, soldiers will ignore enemies attack them while they are attacking buildings. 3.They have taken out most of the different matches from AoE2 like King of the Hill, Capture the Relic, Wonder Race, Deathmatch (where you start with supplies), and other matches that made AoE2 great making this game a dumb down version of AoE2. It is still a very good game in the series it just lacks depth. The music is okay and the graphics are beautiful I just wish it had more to offer. 8/10. A good strategy game to own.
