This game didn't recieve great reviews (mainly due to removing several features players loved from AOEII), but in spite of some things I miss, overall I consider this to be the best of the Age of Empires Franchise. Just make sure you pretty much ALWAYS launch the Asian Dynasties DLC to get all content and improvements (such as the ability to use all maps/factions and the ability to view unit/building health by holding ALT). It's the best looking of the franchise, and features a really nice new system where you can build 'hands' of shipments to send in from your Home City (you're colonising, so you can call in reinforcements!). 

This system adds in a new level of progression on top of that which already exists in strategy games, greatly increasing replayability and gives you a range of ways to play. This Complete Collection features a massive amount of maps, as well as a custom map creator and decent randomisation of attributes. All in all there are 8 Vanilla Factions (British, Spanish, German, Ottoman, Russian, French, Portugeuse and Dutch) Plus 6 Expansion Pack Factions (Sioux, Aztec, Iroquois and Japan, China, India) totally for a respectable 14 factions total, each plays differently and encourages a variety of unique tactics. 

Migrating from AOEII you will notice the lack of the diplomacy feature, instead just relying on FFA or a Two Team system to work (you can still request/send resources to each other, as well as help each other out with TEAM Cards or sharing certain buildings). Whilst I do miss these two features, AOEIII adds enough content to keep you contentwithout it, and there is a joy in fighting through Skirmish maps on different sizes and with different factions, as well as levelling up and unlocking more powerful cards for use in your next battle. 

All in all AOEIII is a great game, a must for RTS fans, and my overall favourite of the franchise. It's also pretty easy to mod the SXML files to fix up some of the odd balancing (Culverins and Ranged Calvary being U.P.) which also can be fun.

As long as you know it's different from AoE2, buy it in a sale cause 30$ is way too much, and like or have intrest in gunpowder era battles, you'll be fine with this game.

My favorite genre of electronic game is the old-school RTS, with resource management and offensive and defensive tactics.   Although this is not my favorite era for simulation, this is the best RTS of all.  What many of them leave out is a good sandbox experience, and to me, the acid test of a good sandbox element is whether or not you can do a 360 rotation with the camera.  This is one of the very few strategy games that allows you to do this.  Also, another great element of a strategy game is diversity of factions, buildings and units, and here again, AOE III comes out on top.  Furthermore each class of faction (European, Native American and Asian) is asymmetrical relative to the others.  The graphics are awesome, and not too demanding.  If I could have one wish, it would be that AOE II be reformatted into the AOE III engine.

One of the genre defining RTS'. 

The pros:
Amazing graphics for a mid 2000s game
An active multiplayer community (in contrast to other Microsoft RTS') 
Regular tournaments (about 3-4 a year)
Variety of playstyles and maps, as well as civilization strategies
Scenario editor and custom maps widely available

Flaws:
Some persistent bugs (not game destroying or hindering, but still irritating like a sound bug here and there)
Balance issues in multplayer, some civs are just de facto stronger than others (although this isn't as significant for newer/less skilled players)

Would definitely recommend, the game has aged well and is definitely still kicking around!

Simplifying my gripes with the game:

-No formations like in AOE2, not talking about tactics, actual formations.
-Poor pathfinding, units get stuck and slowed down very often.
-Clunky, busy UI. Hotkey banners get clicked on accidentally often. Too much space wasted at top, everything crammed at bottom.
-Unbalanced units makes games often end up as a rock paper scissors with civilizations. Artillery is extremely OP and easy to win with, even against their counters.
-Not very many civilizations.
-Campaign plays completely differently than multi. It's also campy and the missions jump from too easy to too difficult.
-Card system breaks games.

Plenty of reasons why AOE3 is not as fondly remembered as AOE2. The real talent left Ensemble to make Rise of Nations.

This game is pure gold, as it is fast-paced and sometimes slow, but mostly fast-paced as towns can crumble if left undefended.

And don't worry if you're being attacking, just quickly spam those Musketeers while you're being attacked, or kiss your town goodbye if you cant defend or spam the musketeers. (It's good to have a defensive army full of cannons, and anti-siege)

Revolting in the Industrial era is another neat thing you can do in the Warchiefs and Asian Dynasties expansion (which are bundled in this product) as it allows you to become a new nation, like America, but there are drawbacks.

Oh, did I mention you can launch a space program with a Cannon and a Settler?

This game has aged pretty well, and is still in playable quality for anyone buying this in 2016/2017. Just know that the models aren't the best looking things on the block, but let the physics and lighting portion of the engine paint over that little flaw. But in all honesty, the models look fine when you're zoomed out like you usually should be.

Paying full-price for this game is worth it, on sale it's even better.

The AI in the game actually remembers you, and they poke at you at the beginning of every match. (So it feels like you're legitimately fighting Napoleon.)

A Veteran AOEII/AOE2 fan would probably be kinda iffy about this installment in the series, but hey, it's worth it.

Also most of my life was dedicated to the non-steam version. I'd probably have about 1000 hours on here if I could port them over.

One of my all time favourites. Great strategy game. The campaign is nice, but the skirmish matches are the best. The bots AI is a bit too op on Expert mode (they always know where you are). There were multiple games where I had to "migrate" my settlers to my friends base, or just spent the whole game hiding from the bots (which, again, always find us). 
Here's a small list of weird funny matches I played on, mainly when I was just starting out and was a noob: 
- Against a french player, he made a square with his horses and placed one horse of a different type in the middle of the square. The square was incredible fast and basically destroyed all my buildings in under a minute
- There was this one guy who made like 50 cannons (no other units) and they would simply destroy everything that I threw at them. After destroying my buildings he spent 10 minutes chasing my last settlers with his army of cannons.
- On this one game after I was defeated my friend hid his explorer on a treasure, in a way that it wouldn't be visible from above. After getting to imperial and researching spies to see the whole map, they spent 15 min looking for him until his explorer attacked a settler passing nearby.
It's a shame ESO online is terrible. The system is so old I can't even join a single game. This game would become so much better if there was a steam based multiplayer mode. As it is, I have to use gameranger to be able to play with my friends.
Also worth mentioning, if you lose your password for ESO Online good luck retrieving it. I had an old copy of the game but couldn't remember the password, emailed microsoft, asked on the official forums and never got an answer. I then bought the game on steam only to find that I couldn't join online games...
Not as good as its predecessor but still fun nonetheless.

It's a great RTS: the scenery isn't a depressing post apocalyptic landscape, the music and sounddesign is great, the game is challenging enough and the nations are truly different.

This is a Fantastic Game!
I played this game a ton when I had it on disk back in 2006, and still play it do to its great replayability
The game is set in the colonial period, and boy does it make a good job of it, all the troops have their distinct languages when playing different nations (which there are a lot), even the mercenaries and natives have them, it really helps with the immersion. 
The home city deck mechanic is a cool way to use exp besides leveling up, it allows you to get a big amount of troops early on if you want to rush, or economic improvements to enhance your settlers or villagers and become and economic power house, pumping mosket man to no end. The amount of ways you can play the game is outstanding.
Age of empires also includes a single player campaign which is nice, my favorite campaigns are the ones from the Asian dynasties. 
the only thing negative I can think of is that some of the improvments are locked at certain levels, hoever avraging 2 levels per match more or less, your bound to reach level 40 in about 15 or so matches (you start at level 10 in the asian dynasties)
Still I really recommend this game, especially when it costs 8.00 dollars when it’s on sale.

Ps: remeber to start with asian dynasties by right clicking the age of empiers game in your steam library. if you click the others you are going to miss content you bought.

Age of Empires III is less of a successor and more of a reimagining of Age of Empires II. Limited, level-based, and less challenging than AoE2, it's not easy to fairly compare the two games. It feels like the AoE3 developers never really played AoE2 much, but were fond of playing the Warcraft series and based it off of that. 

In every game you get an "Explorer" which isn't much more than a glorified villager that never permanently dies. Your choices for game setup are 1-vs-1 team or a free-for-all. There are no in-game alliances, all your units and buildings are limited in number, and your max pop is about 200. Oh, and your home city can only earn 30,000 xp each game.

Despite these limitations, resources (Wood, Food, Gold; stone is nonexistant) couldn't be easier to gather. Buildings such as Farms, Rice Paddies, etc. offer unlimited free resources after building for one low cost.

The goal of this game is to level up your home city and earn "cards", shipments you recieve at no cost from your home city. You try each civilization out, level them up, and if you don't have a fiance, friends, or a family member to play with, you never play this again for a very long time.

If you like Age of Empires II, DON'T buy this game unless it's dirt cheap. You will try it, play it, tire of it, and return to Age of Empires II.

5.5/10

Hands down my favorite RTS game of all time. The came play is balanced with every unit having weaknesses and strengths and you as the player can counter anything thrown at you. Empires are unique and offer various units that play different than other and provide diversity in game play that other games cannot match, especially when there are 14 Empires all with unique units and abilites. This game also has great multiplayer which encourages teamwork and communication through in game chat. This is everything I could ever ask for in an RTS. 

The only down side is the game has now been out for numerous years and the online community is thin so at times games can be hard to fine. There are times throughout the day that the community is active but it isn't always so. Just keep that in mind.

PS I want a sequel plz

I've spent roughly 4000 hours with this game (out of Steam) and it's my favorite strategy game of all time.

Great graphics and cool concepts, a ton of different strats, a ton of maps, a ton of ways to cheatsy doodle, and a ton of fun. Definitely holds through time better than its predecessors even if the system is slightly wonkier.

Even for fans of plain builder or city growing games it's fun and easily manageable by altering settings and gameplay into many different skillsets.

This was the first strategy game that I had ever played and having tried many, many others, this is always a treat to come back to. I first had it on a disc for mac but that computer broke years ago. I got a laptop quite recently and saw that there was a complete collection of the game. On sale, I couldn't resist coming back to it and it was worth it. The base game was good with easy, simple mechanics and a fair bit of content, without much range between countries (with the exception of the Ottomans and Russians). The expansions however, add a huge range of content, with vastly different playing styles for different countries and it's still very balanced.
My favourite map remains Caribean but all of the new ones I have tried are very good too. I haven't gotten on to the new campaigns yet. The first campaigns weren't particularly compelling in story but the play modes are unique compared to the 'skirmish mode' so it's worth a play-through.
This is an absolute classic of real time strategy games and it is deserved of any praise it gets.

There is still a good online community and there is always 500 to 2000 online at anytime so you can always find a game to play. The campaigns are challenging and fun, there are a great varierty of maps to master and a good amount of civs. Even at the full price is still worth it but if you can buy on sale its a no brainer !!

The community is still very active and there are community run tournaments with cash prizes. There is lots of youtube and twitch content, plenty of established mods and mods currently under development, new maps, observer UI and scenarios. Its surprising how active this game is considering the age of the game but a true masterpiece stands the test of time.

I nominated this game Test of Time award.

I grew up with the Age of Empires saga. I delved into the Age of Mythology and its expansions. Granted, my inclinations toward story tended to drive me to mash "To Smithereens" over and over again so I could see what happened next, but I did gain a new appreciation for the strategical elements over time. 

Some units, when coupled with certain home shipment cards, do indeed break the game if you play against opponents who know the exploits. I enjoy the benefits and weaknesses of each empire, the upgraded resource gathering where one does not have to build a resource dropoff station, and the fact you can que up a series of units in a single unit-production building. 

The main story of the vanilla edition does tend toward the fantastic, which isn't bad, but I do appreciate the more historical, fact-based scenarios and campaigns of the first and second games. I do miss the Wololo and Rogan, but they do tribute these sounds in the pre-programmed multiplayer taunts. The soundtrack isn't bad; could have used a little more variety.

As always, take this review as an opinion. I'd recommend it.

This game is far too addictive. Sleepless nights with only the sun peering through the curtains letting me know how screwed I am for the next 24 hours. It's simple in many ways. Collect resources, built a city, build an army. Massacre everyone that isn't you or on your team and then start all over again. limited in so many ways and repetitive, but far greater than the sum of its parts. Many claim AOEII was the pinnacle of the series but I'm, not off that mind. I only wish there was a way to go further past the 5th age and perhaps into the mid 20th century or perhaps start earlier in the cavemen era.  

With that said, be warned that if you get into this game, the story won't hold you for long, but the endless skirmish matches against the AI or multiplayer will ruin your life. I am going to uninstall this game as I'll be rendered homeless and destitute should I continue down this path. 

Play it only at your own peril, it will consume you.

Even Microsoft teams see this game as a big mistake, and probably it is. The campaign is boring and badly made, the cinemas are boring, the voice actors are barely ok.  And the balance is null. The enemy will have access to better technology than you.  

This game try to change the dynamic from the second, however the cards system and XP is just annoying.  I tried to like this game, but after the second mission of the second act II had enough.  Could be that the multiplayer have another history, but frankly I doubt. 

The GUI has many weak point in comparison to the previous game, one minor thing that I particularly hate was the fact that the saved games don’t sort by date or the fact you can’t delete them from the game. You need to go to options for disabling or enabling statistics data from other players. 

The campaign difficult and setting in hard is badly handled. It is supposed to be an A.I. without no handicap and no special extra resources. However, the amount of resources that the A.I. is able to gather are ridiculous. I had to enable the truck cheat only to damage the enemy infrastructure and kill all the villagers and still is able to respawn a great number of its army without any problem. In the time you need for getting a small number of everything, the A.I. already  has a full platoon (and when you killed them  the AI will be in half process of creating a new platoon with equal numbers), in the early missions the machine has access to better technologies than you.

The uniqueness of the races…. Is not that unique, you get more from the cards, and probably you can attach to two units in the game, plus artillery. 

The card concept is odd. Maybe part of my problem is because I don’t understand very well how that thing is handled, is part of the XP you get in the game (As a certain amount will give you a “Slot”. But in my opinion break the balance of a strategy game.

Firstly, I would like to point out that, this game is by far one of the best I have seen to date.

Secondly, It is also the worst. Allow me to explain.

From a new player's standpoint, the game is interactive, it has a sense of immersion unlike most games of its genre. It is a fantastic world, in which (With the aid of cheat codes, and the map editor) you can create a story of your very own, and live in your own 3D world of history.

From my perspective, I still enjoyed the game, but not as fully as a new person to the RTS genre might. The story was fantastic, and I loved the continuation of the [spoiler] Black family tree, throughout history [/spoiler] and the way it is handled. But unfortunately, after the campaign, the fun ends. Compared to the first two game series, AoE3 is very simple, and the mechanics are very, Starcraft 2 in essence. 

I strongly recommend this game to everyone who enjoys a RTS game, but I also warn enthusiasts of the AoE franchise, of this versions simplicity. 

Do not let this review turn you off of this game, the story in itself is worth the price, in my personal opinion.

The third installment of the amazing triology, Age of Empires 3 has endless hows to endulge in and there are unlimited ways in the game to mess around, or even play competatively. There are plenty of maps to play as well as game modes to try out. This Age of Empires game is like no other game in its series due to the fact that this game is presented in a 3 dimentional atmosphere, allowing the player to experience the series like no other which gives this game a new and interesting flavour.

Age of Empires III is yet another classic RTS Game and a must for your stratagy collection. The game speeds I also found to be a bit extreme, Normal feels far too slow and fast feels way to fast, If this can be modded than I think it would make gameplay even more enjoyable. Overall, the game sill stands up today and if you are into RTS games this is a must.

This game had a lot going for it when it first came out. I enjoyed it immensely as they seemed to put a lot of work into making a familiar game into something that was "fresh" in terms of additional gameplay features. 

The deck building system is fun, it's rewarding, and it takes some time to do. What is bad about it is that it's practically the same with every faction with only slight variations. This could have had more variety but in a game that features multi-player, I can see why you don't want to have a faction that's known for its naval prowess to suck on land, and instead make it more balanced...and that's the rub really...it's all too balanced.

The city customization was nice for the base game, and I don't know why they got rid of it for the subsequent expansions.

The biggest issue though with this game is that it is unstable as fuck. Expect a metric shit load of crashes during missions that you've been playing for hours on end.

The lack of any kind of cloud save also sucks.

Get this on a sale if you get it at all.

Age of Empires series was supposed to be the best series around - as I've read through many and many reviews. Many people recommended this game and when I saw it on sale I gave it a shot. 

Basically, this game is like European Wars : Cossacks. Old style RTS. 

The only downside to this Age of Empires versus the second is the way you can choose formations in the second. It felt overall the second had more to control whereas the third sort of simplified things and tried to make the game easier and smoother. AoE 3 is your typical RPG, offering peasants (or settlers), militias, markets, church's, walls and gates to protect your city. I really can't see all the hype about this game to be truthful as everyone says. Yes the campaign stories are good, but I find that this game doesn't really set itself apart from other RTS's. 

If I had a choice between playing European Wars : Cossacks or this - I would most likely choose EW : Cossacks. Not to say that this game is bad, but the options that are given in EW far outweigh those of AoE for me. 

I would give it an 8 if it had something to differentiate itself from other RTS of it's class, but 

RATING : 7.6/10

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

Age of Empires III: complete Collection is a small compilation consisting of Age of Empires III and the two expansion packs. I already recommend buying this over the retail version since there was an issue with it. If one was to purchase Age of Empires III then War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties retail, it would only allow the use of Asian Dynasties OR War Chiefs. So, one pro is that both expansions can be played at the same time.

Gameplay
Age of Empires III is an RTS that is set in colonial times. What is most appealing about the game is the beautiful graphics for the time and the amount of replayability. The effort that was placed in each nation was specific and displayed the obvious strengths and weaknesses of each nation after some experience. For example, one nation might be unable to build a tower type build, but have a unit or another building that allows better protection against enemies. This also limits the player somewhat since not all nations can just wall up and defend well like in Age of Empires or Age of Empires II. 

Story
Not much to say on this subject as the story is loosily based on true events and is sub-par at best. To say the least, you would probably play through it once and never touch it again.

Visuals
The audio is superb and feels right. The gun shots of the muskets don't sound like bb guns or anything, the ambient music is relaxing, and combat has its own fast paced music as well. Graphic wise, the game is very beautiful and seems to bring out the environments of the real world. 

Overall, I would recommend this game to long time fans of the series or fans of RTS games.

It's much fun, the singleplayer campaign is entertaining, the atmosphere is great (different nations look differently and speak their own language), and with friends it's a huge lot of fun.

I bought this game at a discounted price of $7 which is the only way you should pick this game up since the price will match the content in this game.

Age of Empires 3 is a joke without any DLC you have like 4 or 5 nations to choose from and a few maps, which would be ok if the game was not $40.

Next, this "RTS" game has many issues with the single player and multy player, first the multy player since thats the easist to cover, it doesn't work, like at all, i tried to get a game going with a friends since as I said I had bought it for $7 so if it sucked I wouldn't be too mad, but it just doesn't work at all which makes me mad, I would have been fine with there were some connection issues or latency since the games so old but no, just doesn't even start.

Secondly the single player which is divided into Skirmish mode and story, the story I found lack luster and not as interesting as AoE 2 stories, and secondly Skirmish mode, this mode got wrecked, Maps are way too small and we all know how Age of Empires AI was and still is SUPER agressive, well small maps just make that worse since you now have to rush around with your villagers to gather resources to get to the next age before the AI does and comes over with cannons and kills you.

Lastly is the card system, while I enjoy it because it makes the game slightly more easy to new and old comers alike, that still does not give this game a pass for punishingly hard AI and really no totorial since you would think that you would get one in the story right, not really their idea of a totorial is just throw them into the heat of battle and tell them how to make units, what building makes what unit, and the time and resouces it takes to make said unit, not what unit is best to kill what unit, you kind of have to go off common sense with that one, like samurai (you only have samurai if you get the asian DLC) what do samurai kill the fastest because it's not infantry like you think it would be, but they seem to kill light cavlery the fastest.

all in all if you pick this game up at a discounted prices like I did you can't complain too much but if you do pick this up keep in mind that this will be a solo game with some seriously cut content, but if your looking for a game like this and don't care about price get Age of Empires 2, it has more content, less DLC and is like $20 cheaper.

This game gets a lot of shit, but I think it's one of the best RTS games I've ever played.

I played the singleplayer campaign, but I haven't ever enjoyed a single campaign from the dozens of RTS games I've played, so I won't say anything about this one.

There are about 1000 concurrent players on the ESO servers at a given moment, so it's a little rough to find a game sometimes but it's not that bad. People play 1v1s, the larger team games, and the custom maps. There are also unique modes for the conventional matches, like Deathmatch, Regicide, No Rush games, etc. People usually only play No Rush games if it's not a standard skirmish. The custom maps are pretty fun in this game, especially Lost, but I wouldn't buy this game for the custom games. Look into WC3 for that.

I mainly play 1v1s, and while the game has some balance issues, the flow of the game is great. It has a really good scale, each civ feels unique, and the shipment system adds to the customization of your playstyle. The economic and military sides of this game complement each other well, where it's fun to try to secure resources with strategic building placement and such.

One final note, there's an unofficial community patch, so if you get into the game, they've tried to balance it for competitive players, but a small subset of players actually use it.

Age of Empires 3 (AOE3) will always be my favourite RTS of all time. I have played this game since 2008 and on my disc copy (actually 3 disc copies lol) I would say I have played around 1500 hours or so total.

[b]The Campaign[/b]: The campaign is not a hugely different playstyle from skirmish or multiplayer but it allows you to feel more like you're involved with the people and characters than usual which definitely makes the campaign worth playing through. Each expansion has a separate campaign and I remember them being highly entertaining and interesting each to their own. The campaigns also allow you to use civs not playable in any other game mode.

[b]Map Editor[/b]: Not something I played around with too much, but it was fun to just create giant battles, or create your own scenarios and historical events.

[b]Civilizations[/b]: The civilizations are really interesting. So interesting, that my interest in European, Native American, and Asian history are based from this game. I play this game as an excuse for studying for my history tests but I can't say that it helped with much more than trivia-like questions. Anyways, This game makes every civilization slightly different from each other (The War Chiefs and Asians are much different respectifully though) and every one is recognizable by not only building styles but troops as well. Each nation is given at least one troop that is unique to their civ. In the original there is 8 European nations (Britain, France, Spain, Portugal, Netherlands, Germany, Russia, Ottoman Empire) with War Chiefs, 3 Native American tribes were added (Iroquois, Sioux, Aztec) allowing 11 total playable nations, and finally with Asian Dynasties, 3 more were added (Japan, China, India), with a total of 14 playable civilizations . Apart from the 3 civs that are just a little bit better than the rest (You'll know soon enough), it is pretty balanced when playing online (IF playing with someone with similar experience).

[b]Multiplayer[/b]: AOE3 was slowly getting weaker with age a few years back but with the game being more widely sold on steam, I feel the community has a chance to bounce back. Usually when I go on, there are anywehre from 600 - 1000 people on at a time. This doesn't count the community that play on places like GameRanger and other programs like it. Don't get discouraged by people baiting new players into their games when they are veteran players. Host a game and name it something welcoming new players, read the ranks of the people who join, to make sure the game will be fair and welcoming to you if you are new. Or join another low ranked players game or grab a buddy or two and practice between you all. I would recommend being able to beat Hard or Expert computers before playing online, but of course, it is your choice. Multiplayer is the best place to play, practice, and have a competitive and some-what stressful game of AOE3. :)

[b]Graphics[/b]: Honestly, in my opinion, the graphics are spectacular for their time and do not look anywhere near "bad" even in today's time. Of course they aren't great for today's standards but they aren't awful enough to turn you away. I actually find them quite nice and I am more than satisfied watching the ships travel the oceans, or seeing the parrots flying through the rainforests. The loading screens are really nice too, all 3 games have different styles. For example in Asian Dynasties there is one loading screen with the Indian Emperor riding on an elephant with the troops behind them. Or the Japanese loading screen with the beautiful Torii Gates. In War Chiefs, one screen is the Aztec emperor on top of a temple with his arms up with the people looking up to him from the ground. This game sparks not only interest, but imagination, its amazing!

[b]Soundtrack[/b]: The soundtrack is phenominal! I absolutely love the theme song of each game and I find myself testing my opera skills most times I play this game. The music is great, intense, and is fitting to the epic introduction to the game or the conclusion to the massive multiplayer game you just finished.

[b]Opening[/b]: The opening to each expansion has a really cool video based on the game. The War Chiefs has the European explorers searching the forest and them being ambushed by the Native troops. It's epic, and amazing to watch from time to time before jumping into the game! I recommend watching all 3 intros so I'll let you watch to find out what they're like!

[b]Extra Features[/b]: Unlike previous installments to the franchise (AOE1, AOE2, Age of Mythology), AOE3 introduces cards, card decks, city levels, city customization, explorer naming, and city naming. Cards can be purchased by leveling up. One level is one card unlock point. A deck can have I think 21 cards to start, and with every ten level ups, can have an extra card in the deck. Cities level up by playing with them, and EXP is given for every building or troop made, or enemy building or troop destroyed. Cities can be customized by upgrading the buildings, such as France's Notre Dam by changing colours, adding features, etc. A minor touch but still interesting enough to have your own sort of style with leading a nation in the game. Your explorer can be named so you can make yourself, a friend, or family member be the greatest European explorer, Native American War Chief, Japanese Shogun, Indian Brahmin, or Chinese Master that has ever existed. The same goes for cities, you can name them the small rural town you live in, or your country's capital city and make it the most advanced city in the world! All theses extra features expand upon the replayability and fun that you can have with AOE3. 

Note, AOE3 - The Asian Dynasties expansion was the latest released and updated. All Civs can be played on this expansion and the majority of the people play on this one. I suggest only playing the original AOE3 and War Chiefs when playing with campaign, or really dislike playing with or against the Asian Civs as they cannot be played in the others.

Also, check out Age of Mythology Extended Edition (AOM) on steam if you like this game, or if you're into Greek, Egyptian, Norse mythology. I prefer AOE3 myself, but AOM is my second favourite in the series. Personally, I would wait until this game, and/or AOM, go on sale to buy them but I still feel they are worth the cost. Like I said at the top, I have 3 disc copies of AOE3 that all work (long story) and also disc copy of AOM. These games ARE worth it.

All in all, I want to see AOE3 bounce back strong. If you're new looking for help, a partner to play with, or want to join a clan who are mostly active, just message me on steam and I hope to see you on the battlefield soon!

This is my second time playing the base game and I still love it. The graphics are a bit old but the gameplay is as exceptional as it used to be years ago. [b] Have been a massive fan of age of empires all my life and brought this game as soon as it was realeased. I have played thousands of hours on the disk version of this game. I brought it on steam to purchase the DLCs and experience them. They are just as good as the base game; but i always go back to my personal favourite: the french! [/b]

Putting that aside Age of Empires III ensures that the Age of Empires is one of the best RTS series' on the market. The new card and shipment system has brought in an extra level of strategy. The cards can be instrumental between a massive victory and a crushing victory, and i have often been involved in battles decided by who has the better cards. They can be the decider in who rushes the quickest, or who has the strongest military, or assist in establishing a stable econonomy with resource cards. 

Trade routes and native training buildings also bring in more strategy, with the ability to train cheap, effective native troops who have no impact on your population (but still have a build limit). Trade routes pretty much replace and improve on relics and allow you to collect more than just gold from them and can be a good resource provider.

Units have been improved from 2 and nearly every unit has a strength against another type of unit, but for every strong unit, there is always a counter of some sorts. Although unique units from castles has been removed, you will find that in the base game, some civilisations will have access to some units while not having access to others.

Artillery has been improved (organers from AOEII would destroy every unit in a battle, friend or foe alike) and the artillery can play a much bigger role in deciding the outcome of a battle.

Ship Combat has also been refined and has become more fun to engage in, with access to ships that can train units, and having more than one ranged DPS ship designed specifically to destroy other enemy ships from a distance.

Overall, Age of Empires III is a great game and is my personal favourite out of the series. I would recconmend it to new players and veterans of the genre who have played the first 2 and are looking for something new. Although be warned, stratetgy masters from the first 2 games will also have to learn the new mechanics; you cannot just pick up where you left off in AOEII and think you'll be just as good in AOEIII, and vice versa. It will feel alot different when you go back and play the first 2 games.

[b] But enough rambling on, i greatly recconmend this game to anyone 8.5/10 [/b]

Hooh boy, AoEIII. A very good contender for my favourite RTS game ever, and definitely somewhere in my top 10 games of all time. 
As a game? I would definitely recommend it to anybody who hasn't played and has the capacity to play. The lack of requiring a storehouse or similar structure to gather resources is a welcome addition, especially for me who often finds it tedious to construct a lumber camp every hour or so in aoeII. It's fairly easy compared to its later installments; i won a Moderate game with the Trade Monopoly condition in about two hours or so. 

But this version... it's basically the same minus a few upgrades, and doesn't really justify a $40 price tag 10 years after its release. It's also a little glitchier than the store version. I also can't get it and Steam to syncronize, which I was looking forward to and was primarily why i bought the game from steam. 

Get it if your current version doesn't work anymore or you've never played before, as AOEIII is a really fun experience, but if your current version works on your computer, I'd give this one a skip.

A game from back when RTS games were still riding high, when "base building" wasn't a dirty word and factions were meant to be colourful and fun.  It shows its age now, but the core mechanics are still solid.

An unusual characteristic of an RTS was persistency; or how your play affected you in the next game.  AOE III had experience gain over time that would unlock "cards", which then could be called into play in a future match.  This also came with nice cosmetic upgrades for a "capital" city, which let players really feel that they were leading an army into battle.  Sadly these cosmetic upgrades were not in place for Asian or American civilizations in the expansions, although the persistant card unlocks are still present.

The factions are nicely done.  The European factions all largely play the same, with some emphasis on artillery, cavalry, or infantry between them.  Asian civilizations are also fairly similar, just implementing "wonders" as well as other minor changes.  I do like the emphasis on the Americans, who end up playing much more differently as they lack the hard defenses that others do.  Overall these different factions make for a high level of replayability.

An old game, but worth the money.  Especially since newer quality RTSs are infrequent.

I have owned this game for a long time, and I finally got around to buying the complete collection. The campaigns alone will keep you busy for a few days. Then you can skirmish and choose any nation you want from arounf the Victorian Era and build massive armies. 

If that wasn't enough you can also use the scenario creator which literally allows you to edit everything from how many men are on the field, to the texture and the color of the blood on the ground. I made an exact recreation of gettysburg, with the full 90,000 vs. 70,000 men. Sometimes I just k500 cannons and watch them blow buildings to tiny bits. Best RTS game steam has to offer.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

This game is honestly one the best, no... I'm sorry, [i]THE BEST RTS[/i] game I have ever played. I liked this better than other games like dota and smite (though I am more of a historical strategy nerd) but I think that the mechanics of building buildings and being able to control of all of your units amazing. I would say that this game is a little overpriced, and that's why I got it during a sale.

[h1]DLC[/h1]

I like the complete edition because playing as the native americans or the asians is very different from the way that you play the Europeans, yet I feel that each country is still pretty balanced. The campaign is actually very fun to play, too.

[h1]Age of Empires III versus Age of Empires II[/h1] 

Now, if you are trying to decide between AoE II or AoE III, I would recommended this game (AoE III) only if you haven't played AoE II before. I've heard that this game is different from AoE II in ways that the people who play AoE II don't like, but if you have never been exposed to AoE II before you will find that the pros outweigh the cons of playing this game because most people who like AoE II mostly like it out of nostalgia.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

In the end, this game and Civilization V are the only games I play frequently on Steam. So, if you enjoy strategy games of historical themes, get this one of you like RTS or get Civilization V if you like turn-based games.

[i]P.S. As for you AoE II fans, well just get AoE II because AoE III tends to disappoint the lot of you.[/i]

Introduction: My favorite RTS franchise of all time! Loved AoE 2 especially! Now coming to this one I wouldn't say its perfect as there are many new additions which is a mixed bag but overall I liked this game after spending some time. 

Played all of the AoE games and I would happily place this at the second place after AoE 2 HD.

Campaign: Campaign in short is okay but mind you I didn't complete it though. Its not easy either but it just didn't feel interesting enough to me so as of now I have yet to complete it. So take someone elses opinion regarding the Campaign.

Multiplayer: The multiplayer community is decently active, around 1300 to 1500 players are online on most weekends. Multiplayer is also one of the strongest points of this game as with 2 or 3 players against 'expert' mode Bots it can be really fun while being challenging and you can 'master' the game more quickly by playing with veteran players! So I recommend playing Multiplayer if you get the game. If the ESO Servers are down for some reason you can still play multiplayer on Gameranger and Voobly. Some dedicated players play there exclusively.

Conclusion: Besides the Multiplayer the Skirmish Mode can also be challenging and decently fun to play. Other than that all I would say in the end is that I can definitely recommend this game when on sale to those looking for a RTS to play with friends. Yes this game has some bugs on more recent Operating Systems like Windows 10 though it can be fixed. 

Also there are some issues like path finding and builders getting stuck after building structures though it can be taken care of if you build your Empire a little spread out rather can cramping your structures while making sure you have it well defended with castles on all sides.

NOTE : When you click on the 'Play' Button it will give you several options like AoE: Complete Edition, War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties etc. The full game with all the expansions is the Asian Dynasties option not the Complete Edition option ironically!

Also for Windows users while you would expect Steam Overlay like every other game here it doesn't works for this game unless you run Steam in Administrator Mode though it depends on your UAC settings.

I haven't had much call to write negative reviews thus far - I habitually only choose to say stuff about things I like, which would make my mum proud I guess - but duty compells me to speak out against Age of Empires III, and sundry, on account of the hideous let down it proved to be with regards to the duty of all sequels to take the best parts of earlier titles in a series and strive to improve them further.

Age of Empires is one of the few series in which I can honestly claim to have a comprehensive base of experience in on which to form opinions (TES, Deus Ex, Civilization and MGS spring to mind as other examples), in fact I don't think there is any game series which I have a more complete relationship to than this one. (I might say Vanilla WoW had the biggest impact on me, for better or worse, but that's not a series is it)

So this might be a bit rant'y. But I will try to also make it instructive.

This game is a massive betrayal and letting down of everything that made the opening two titles of the series, and their expansions, so fantastic.

Starting at the beginning: Age of Empires. Released in, I believe, 1998, this was one of the first full computer games that I ever attempted to play, since my family got it as part of a deal for a new PC, our first modern computing system. I wouldn't say that I played it, per se. I was a bit of a dumbass then and it took me a few months at least to realize that the trial version game I had been playing over and over again actually existed on the same computer in full version, if only I would insert the play CD located near the computer. The trial version however informed my relationship with Age of Empires, and informed what I came to really expect from Age of Empires: The mini-campaign we enjoyed (indeed, I believe it was a single mission - practically at least this is what it was because as a total nubcake I believe I never actually beat the mission, though I got extremely good at playing it) traced the birth of the Hittite culture, from gathering food from a carcass or two to entering the Bronze Age and raiding one - perhaps two? Broad Swordsmen to take the fight to our dastardly red foes.

The game was about history, it was informative, the graphics were detailed, the music lovely, the missions loooong and the scope for imagination limitless.

Then of course we all know what happened when Age of Empires II came out. I first caught wind of AoE2 when I was outside a PC shop in a shopping centre food court and I saw some lucky so-and-so playing the Joan of Arc campaign opening mission inside the window. As someone who had loved Age of Empires for so long (a couple of years at least) this game represented a quantum leap in graphics, detail, narrative, storytelling, scripting - everything! It blew my mind.

[i]But it was still about history. It was still informative - even more so - the graphics were so detailed that even now 16 years later they are still gorgeous to me, the music was even more lovely and the missions seemed bigger, longer, but also more accessible.[/i]

Age of Empires II: The Conquorers Expansion was the final shining badge of honour on the series, the ultimate RTS game. Adding a few tweaks to the fantastic Age of Empires II model - one click garrissoning, farm build queus - everything went into overdrive with the addition of the Aztecs and some other South American civilzations, as well as the introduction 'closer to home' as it were of such slightly less antiquated groups such as the Spanish or Koreans. The Hun campaign, following Atilla, would prove to be the most immersive and replayable of all the narrative-driven campaigns, supplanting Joan of Arc and Ghengis Khan from the base game.

So finally we get to what happened when Age of Empires III came out.

Well, initially it looked like another fantastic rebirth of this timeless, epic series. I deduced this from a raft of gorgeous screenshots - never before [i]or since[/i] has a historic setting been so beautifully presented. Turtled sunned themselves on logs, Native Americans rode dustily across a distant plane, Mayan temples towered above misty swamps. These screenshots can all still eb found online if one looks hard enough through the google image results. It was inevitable, I thought, a done deal: Age of Empires III was going to be the most beautiful, expansive, historically absorbing, atmospheric RTS game ever created. I was so proud of my series.

So what did I get instead? Well to prevent you from feeding money to this pile of excrement I will spoil it for you (at least partially).

The long missions and giant maps have been replaced by crap maps with ridiculous scaling and a totally inadequate zoom range, as well as the addition of a ton of third-party NPC settlements and the like designed to aid the flow of quick gameplay. The graphics that looked so unbelievable - like Crysis made into an RTS - in early screenshots lost entire fields of polygons, lost textural acuity by the boatload, giving us something that looked like a cross between Age of Mythology and freaking Warrior Kings. The gameplay, which had looked pacific, ephemeral and deliberate in the screenshots turned into a pile off bullspit, with hero characters and wonky missions structures completely doing away with micromanagement or preparations. Your villages didn't even walk anymore, you just sent them to gathering places and they just stood there feeding you resources. What the hell does this even MEAN?

But the biggest sin of all is what they did to the historical roots of the series: They took a pewp all over them. You wanted to relive the conquests and dying resistance of the Aztecs in beautiful, out of this world graphics and scale? Too bad. You get some coque and bull story about frigging jesuit knights searching for the fountain of youth. This spoiler is but a taste of the range and depth of the ridiculous plots that we get shoved down our throats by this ridiculous title, which ends up having our chief enemy during our South American adventure being the [i]trucking Ottoman Empire.[/i]

Don't even get me started on the massive gimmick and gameplay-hastener that is the home city concept.

No. Don't get this game. Get the AoE2 HD bundle available elsewhere on Steam. This game is god awful. You will get more fun out of Rise of Nations - a lot more fun - or indeed Age of Mythology which was excused from the sings of this title by being specifically set in a mythological universe.

This perhaps may just be my favorite game ever. The cultures are probably the best thing I like about this game. Every action that you make will change the outcome of the game. Whether you want to keep your villagers picking berries close to home or dare to venture out and hunt animals to gain food faster. Whether you want to spend all your resources on military and take out your opponent early in the game, or decide to build a strong defense back at the home base to ensure you're survival for the late game. Although this game has been made several years ago, it still never gets old due to it's vast array of strategies. Get this game if you love strategy and multitasking.

If you enjoy games that envolve collecting resources and a large quantity of military and economic micromanagement then this game is for you!

The multiplayer is what makes this game fantastic, the community are amazing and the battles even more impressive. The graphics even to this day are impressive so this is not a game to hold back on and is very well optimised for even the oldest and slowest of computers, if your looking for a game to keep dragging you back, this is the it!

My only comments on improvement would be the reliability of the servers as of recent, there has been a few times I have failed to connect (I know they have maintenance on tuesdays, good to see they are still keeping the servers updated!), but with a good NAT type this shouldn't be an issue!

I had this game (sans expansions) as a series of burned discs I would occasionally borrow from a friend. I say friend, what I really mean is "guy I sat next to in visual basic." Regardless of who he was, I got to play AoE3 from start to finish back in highschool

When it comes to the third game in the series, most people completely ignored the good about AoE3. I recall all my friends going on long, nonsensical tirades against AoE3. Mostly due to two things. The first, and most often bi*ched about, was the new twist on gameplay. AoE3 gameplay is basically the same as the first two games except for one major difference; the home city. The home city is a mechanic in AoE3 that allows you to recieve relief supplies from your civs capital. Everything from general supplies (wood, meat, gold) to extra soldiers (some of which can only be obtained from the home city.) Why this mechanic should stir everyones bile, I will never understand. The second was the story. AoE2 had several campaigns in which you controlled historical figures and reenacted historical events. AoE3 has a single campaign (unless you have the expansions) centered around a shady, almost illuminati type group trying to seize control of the fountain of youth. Pure fantasy, but well written. My friends though, sh*t on it. Back then, AoE players were a bit like todays SMASH players. Speaking of multiplayer...

Microsoft has decided you must use there servers to play online. As far as I can tell, you cannot play LAN and you can't host your own internet server. The real problem is that microsofts servers dont seem to work, as they are down almost all the time. Check the community hub for details. Fortunately (for me) this whole multiplayer clusterf*ck doesn't effect me. I mostly play skirmish.

Another issue is the price, what is with some companies (bethesda and microsoft) that they feel their games don't depriciate? Age of Empires 3 was released in October of 2005, and as of the writing of this review, it costs 40$. 40 f*ckin bucks for a game released ten years ago, holy sh*t, the price has dropped a grand total of 10$. One dollar a year. Buy this game on sale, or from a bundle. I do reccomend this game, but if you are paying 40$ for it, you are being ripped off.

A huge big YES.

I have followed and been loyal to the Age of Empires series since it was first released and I still think that I owe my whole career (foreign language teacher and translator) to this game as this is where I was exposed to foreign languages for the first time. 

Aside from that, Age of Empires just has the perfect blend of city building and combat mixed in with some micromanagement (especially in AOEIII) which has sometimes resulted in having multiplayer games lasting more than 4 hours at a time, 4v4. 

I will always cherish this game and come back to it, especially AOEIII as it's set in one of my favourite time periods in world history. I would recommend buying both expansions though if you have to choose, get the War Chiefs as it adds a certain 'something' that I don't think Asian Dynasties got quite right. 

I'm still hoping that one day, just one day, there will be an AOE IV and maybe even V and VI, maybe set in WW1, WW2 and Cold War era?

This is the best Age of Empires game and one of the best strategy games of all time. Ships are big and beefy, cannons are cannons that do huge damage and splash and each civilization is unique. 

In AoE 2, you have crossbowmen shooting arrows at stone walls, battering rams hitting farm fields and making them burn, and swordsmen using their swords to beat down structures. In AoE 3, units have their own siege attacks and animations which fix that problem. Every civ's Church or religious building is a different model. Every civ has their own unique units and tech trees.

The Explorer is your colony's leader and sort of a hero-like unit from Warcraft 3. You get to explore the map, fight neutrals and claim treasures during the start of the game, which makes games less repetitve and more fun in the beginning.

The Home City part of the game is awesome. You can send shipments or technologies from your mother country to your colony. Every civ has a ton of different strategies.

Each map is different enough. Most maps have Native people and settlements that you can trade with or ally. Your mother country will give you additional support on some maps, like early shipments or free economic starting buildings. There are also trade routes that you can establish.

The game has good balance, almost rock-paper-scissors, with various types of infantry, cavalry and artillery. Also, farms and plantations do not need to be 'queued' like in AoE 2, fixing any annoyance from that game.

In conclusion, AoE 3 is the most improved and well made Age of Empires yet. Every civilization is unique and all the annoying or bad features from the previous Age of Empires series games have been fixed. Each time you play will be different and every civ has different strategies. The maps are all different. My favorite part of the game is the sound of distant artillery, which echoes far! This is a great game and I am glad it is on steam, now it will continue to be supported!

"This is my opinion so you cant Critique is" ok so now that we've gotten that out of the way I would like to admit that when it comes to real time strategy. Age of Empires 3 has always held a special place in my heart. I've played since the first AOE so just liking what I have is not a thing here. I genuinly see this as an improvement and large innovation in the series. The pace is nice, and the fact that resources gather so long as your settler are gathering is a nice change that speeds up the game. the addition of deck and shipments is also very fun allowing multple builds for nations and different ways to play your nation no matter what you play. The base nations alone are also well made. some balancing is an issue as it is with most unsupported games but each nation feels different and has a new way to play and thrive. IE Russian= numbers over strength, France= cavalry and defense. There's quite a few ways to play your nation so don't be too focused on the "meta". Trade routes and native alliances make a nice change as well, most native upgrades are helpful and give you a reason to explore the map and find native settlements. Frankly the game I see here is great and I wish the community was larger rather than focusing on the past of AOE 2. The changes are well done and keep the game fresh.
If you're a fan of RTS's I would highly recomend playing this game. especially is you found AOE 2 to be a bit slow and lacking.

A classic RTS, I've burned countless hours in multiplayer and single player.  Then years later, I found myself playing again through it all over again, enjoying the campaign all over again.  Somehow, years after that, I just finished playing through the entire campaign *again*.

Not sure how that works, the story is the same, I know what is going to be said, but the story is fictional, but believable.  I would totally recommend this.  As far as the multiplayer, unfortunately, there's not a lot of people playing these days, and those that are have metagamed the game down to the second, much like any other RTS that's been out for several years.  Still, its a solid buy.

AoE 3 is a pretty decent historical fiction RTS.  The game takes place mostly around the frontier days, with the exception of the Asian Dynasty pack.  I'll be talking a lot about that expansion because it's vastly different from the rest of the game.  Voice acting is decent, as are the stories, predictable though they are.  The music is catchy but highly repetitive.  

85% of the game has no chill.  While it's not really all that challenging on Normal difficulty, most of the missions in the game have some kind of time or mechanical constraint that prevent them from being standard "build then destroy" affairs.  Normally I wouldn't complain about this, but themes are re-used so much that they quickly grow old.  "Oh, I don't start off with a base again."  "Oh, I can't get any villagers again."  "Oh, I don't get any resources so I have to use trading posts again."  So on and so forth.  

The UI is kind of bad.  It eats up a third of my screen on 1080p, and hotkeys (of which there are many) aren't discernible via mouseovers of the buttons, so you wind up having to go back into the Options menu repeatedly if you want to use them.  Attack-move seemed not to work properly for me, which was very noticeable but not a dealbreaker.  

Asian Dynasties involved very different mechanics.  Minus the UI, the production value, and a couple of buildings/progressions, it was almost different enough to be another RTS.  Some of the alterations were neat, others were bizarre.  If you play the Chinese faction during Skirmish mode, they can't build any common soldiers until they Age Up (upgrade the town hall), only siege units.  I'm sorry, what?  Whose brilliant idea was that?  

You see, although there are many factions, there are really only four styles in the game:  European, Japanese, Chinese, and Indian.  It's not merely a difference in units, or buildings, but the fundamental mechanics of how they work.  Because I didn't spend a lot of hours in Skirmish mode, it's impossible for me to say if the game is balanced, but I doubt it.

Something that appealed to me were the farming/shipment mechanics.  There's food, wood, coin, and a separate export resource if you're playing Asian Dynasties.  The way it's handled, however, you can build farms or receive shipments that are slow, infinite pools of any of those things.  If you run out of wild animals to hunt, build a farm or raise livestock.  If you run out of gold, plantations or rice paddies are infinite.   Wood is more difficult, but Asian Dynasties allows you to plant groves, or you can receive shipments in any case.  As a result, resource-management in the game is a lot less stressful than pretty much any RTS I've played.  

Another thing that stood out is the ability to train stacks of five.  If you have the resources, you can train five troops in one building at once, and when it's finished five will pop out.  The need for multiple barracks is basically absent.  

That's about everything that stood out for me.  I wouldn't pay 40 dollars for the game, wait for a decent sale, but it's definitely worth picking up for RTS fans if you don't mind historical backdrop.

Having played untold hours of AE:II as a kid I was a little hesitant to pick up AE:III, fearing it would shit all over my treasured childhood memories. Fortunately, my fears were completely unfounded!

The campaign offers a reasonably challenging introduction to the game and there are plenty of options to play against AI and computer opponents. Fans of the RTS genre owe it to themselves to pick this game up.

A great game that even though it's sorely outdated, doesn't quite have enough competitors. The campaign is rather lenghty for my taste, that's good or bad depending on your preference. To me, what sets this game apart from similar RTS titles is its progressive card system. Allowing for more build strategies than just picking a certain race. I also really like the importance of early-game scouting. While it's important in every RTS, here there's always plenty of randomly placed resources that seem to have minor impact but are very significant in higher-level play. In higher-level play, there really isn't a stale moment, you are constantly dividing your attention between micro and macro from the very start. I like that, no need to APM spam while you wait for the game to get going.

[h1]For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198006568104/] Steam profile[/url], the [url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCiwEA52JfjAgoF8uiB5k8gg] Youtube channel[/url], and the [url=twitch.tv/morgoth0221]Twitch channel[/url]!![/h1]

Ah, yet another entry into the already incredible Age of Empires franchise.  There are few RTS franchises that can boast about having as much success as AoE has had, and there is good reason behind that.  After putting in nearly 100 hours into the game I can easily say, this one does not disappoint for the most part.  It's no AoE II, but it's close.  That puts this game head and shoulders above most other strategy games.  Ensemble Studios really did an incredible job on their final entry into this series, and they will be greatly missed.

[h1]Gameplay : [/h1]The gameplay of this entry in the AoE series is very similar to the previous two.  Build a base/town, build an economy, raise an army, destroy your enemies.  While it might be a simple straightforward process, it's a hell of a lot of fun.  The combat is visceral, the interface is simplistic enough for even brand new strategy game players to get a grasp on it in just a few short minutes, and the payoff is worth it, for the most part.  The only part that seems to have gotten worse in this entry, is the unit path-finding.  I don't know why or how this particular area got worse, but it definitely did.  Units will seemingly go completely out of there way to get to where you want them to go.  And villagers will CONSTANTLY lose track of what they are supposed to be doing.  The Idle Villager button was nice in AoE II, but it wasn't a necessity.  But in AoE III, you will be clicking it every minute.

There are several modes of gameplay in this version including but not limited to: Campaign, Single-player Random Maps, Multiplayer Standard, etc.  But all of them hold the same general process of base building and conquering your enemies.  The campaigns are lengthy, but slightly repetitive and the characters are not really that engaging, even in the expansions.  The real gem is the multiplayer.  There are several different civilizations to choose from, each one with incredibly unique units that have completely different capabilities.  So while the units are different, this forces different strategies depending on the civilization you have chosen. This creates a unique experience and feel to each civilization and keeps the gameplay fresh while extending it's longevity.

Of course when it comes to multiplayer strategy games, balancing is key.  ESO did a pretty good job of balancing units and civs to begin with, but there were a few missteps in the original that were fixed in the expansions.  So of course the final expansion, The Asian Dynasties, is the definitive AoE III multiplayer experience.  (I don't think you can even play the Warchiefs multiplayer anymore)  I do not wish to go much further in depth with gameplay simply because this is a strategy game and can literally be talked and discussed about forever.  So I'll just finish with this:  The gameplay is really incredible and enjoyable, while also being long-lasting.

[h1]Graphics : [/h1]This game was released in 2005.  2005.  I'll say that one more time.  This game was released in 2005.  And it STILL looks better than a ton of games being released these days.  The new physics engine that was put into place for AoE III is incredible and might be the best looking one in strategy games.  Buildings fall apart completely differently depending on what they are being attacked by and how.  Fire two cannons at two different houses, and they will be blown apart in completely different ways, even from the same angles.  This game was WAY ahead of it's time in terms of graphics.  You will often find yourself just sitting and staring in wonderment at the action that is taking place on the screen (when really you should probably be taking care of other things in the game).

[h1]Sound : [/h1]The audio is perfectly matched for this game.  All the way from the muskets firing, to armies being demolished by elephants, and to cannons thundering over everything else.  And you will hear those cannons from very far away.  Just this small addition, brings in a massive level of tension to the game (especially when playing with Fog of War on).  You can hear the artillery slowly encroaching on your base, and depending on your level of readiness, you are either swarming around trying to prepare or silently waiting for the first shot to be fired in a battle that will determine the fate of your town.

As for the music, it's OK.  I'm a big fan of the soundtracks in the AoE series as they have always meshed ever so perfectly with the gameplay and visuals.  This entry probably has the weakest soundtrack of all three games.  But it's not terrible.  Just OK.

[h1]Lasting Appeal : [/h1]This game has tremendous lasting appeal.  And ESO specifically built it that way.  By implementing the new Home City system into this entry, your City can earn experience and level up after almost every match, which unlocks new cards that you can put into your City's deck that provide bonuses that can be called upon during the match.  Anything from a passive bonus to resource gathering rates, to massive extra reinforcement troops.  The servers are still packed with players ready to fight and try to demolish you so don't be afraid of dwindling player base.

[h1]Final Verdict : [/h1]This game is definitely an 8/10.  Superb gameplay, fantastic graphics, awesome audio, and great lasting appeal.  Is it worth $40?  Probably not.  That's a lot of asking money for a game that came out in 2005.  I think $30 is much more reasonable.

Fun variation on the age of empires formula, many features are "streamlined" and aoe-lovers might turn their nose on that.
For example the workers don't have to make the trip back with the resources, this completely removes the skill involved (where once you had to properly place a gathering building, abuse sweetspots and manage workers, here you just tell the workers to gather X resource until it runs out) but allows for the game to run a lot faster.

Many changes in aoe3 are like that, a gameplay feature is changed or removed completely so that the matches last less.

But it's not just a "simpler age of empires set in colonial times", it adds 2 features that distinguish it from the ancestor and cousins completely: hereos and shipments.

Age of empires doesn't have "important" units, everything is sacrificable as long as you spent less compared to the enemy's losses worth. Because of this the idea of a powerful RPG-like "hero" unit is not only heretical it's illogical and goes against the concept itself, does it work in aoe3?

It doesn't and it does.
It's not really an actual hero, it's an explorer unit that you can use for scouting or for clearing "creep camps" that give you a bit (or a lot, if the camp is big) of resources that you can use to strengthen your army, or build buildings. 
Other than clearing "monsters" the hero can build trading posts, these can be used to connect to neutral camps that give you a (weak) unit to train and (sometimes good) improvements for your economy, or travel routes which give you experience and this connects us to the next part the "trading cards" system:

The experience points you gain through certain buildings don't go to your hero or any unit in your army, but instead allow you to receive "shipments" from the mainland. Meaning you can get moscow/amsterdam/istanbul (or whatever your home city is) to send you a shipment of resources, extra villagers, buildings, improvements, entire armies to help you fight.

Aoe2 (and aoe) while fun in its own way, suffered from its length, only at 10 minutes you get to age up, aoe3 uses the above to "fix" that, with enough skill, by 10 minutes you might hit the last age.

Not everybody can get there, but it's possible.

Other than the several races, the shipment system can be edited allowing for a deeply personalized "deck" and gameplay style, takes a while to get used to, but the standard deck isn't painful to play with either.

The servers work, and people still play, there's a consistent community that still gets to hone their skills.

It's still an awesome game, not just a childhood memory, but the constant out of sync error is seriously infuriating. I play with friends, we all bought the game via steam and 30-40% of the games goes out of sync even though we have clean reinstalled the game many times, (hell we have even reinstalled windows..)

Note: I played this game for many, many hours using the non-Steam version, so the play time that you see above is not actually reflective of the total time that I have spent enjoying this game!

A very good historical RTS (real-time strategy) game that covers an era of history that is often overlooked in video games - roughly the time from the European Renaissance to about the 1860s (just after the Civil War in the United States of America). The game is much more historically "authentic" than its predecessor, Age of Empires 2 (which was set in the Middle Ages), because each civilization is now much more distinct, with its own architectural style and many more unique units that are special to that civilization alone.

Personally, I love the new historical setting of Age of Empires 3! I just really enjoy starting in the Renaissance with units that wield mostly swords, spears, shields, crossbows, and only a few gunpowder weapons (arquebusiers and early cannons), and then evolving my civilization all the way to advanced riflemen, bombard cannons, mortar teams, and ironclad warships.

The main new feature in the game is that of the "Home City", which is a sort of capital city for your empire from which you can summon unit reinforcements, resource supplies, and special abilities to aid in your battles. Also, you can force alliances with local neutral factions on the game map that can provide with further unique units, upgrades, and powers.

Overall, Age of Empires 3 is much more fast-paced than its predecessors, something that you may or may not like depending on your play-style in RTS games. The battles usually start earlier in the game and are much more intense than in Age of Empires 2, but there is also less "grand" strategy as in that older game. Basically, Age of Empires 3 is more focused on the micromanagement of individual clashes on the field of battle, rather than on the broader macromanagement of the resources of a sprawling empire. Personally, I do not mind this shift in strategic perspective; when I want to play a "larger" game, I can always go back to Age of Empires 2 (now, in an HD Edition here on Steam), but when I want a more intense experience, I prefer Age of Empires 3.

I should also mention the graphics and sound design. Simply - both are absolutely superb! Although it is true that the graphical textures are pretty bad when you zoom-in very close, from a distance everything looks truly gorgeous. The cannons smoke from the explosions of gunpowder and emit thundering "booms" when firing at the enemy; the water looks "liquid", and it reflects the sunlight; the sails and flags of ships wave back and forth in the winds. The overall presentation really cements the immersion in the battles and the historical setting.

The campaign is, unfortunately, the weakest point of the game because the story departs from the historical set-piece battles of Age of Empires 2; the storyline instead tries to tell a unique "pseudo-historical" tale of intrigue and conspiracy with its own fictional characters (something like out of a thriller novel by Dan Brown), but it just lacks adequate character development or compelling writing. Nevertheless, it is fairly lengthy, and the actual mission objectives for the various scenarios are well-designed, challenging (but fair), and overall fun to play.

You can also play skirmish battles against the computer outside of the campaign mode. The interesting aspect of these skirmish battles is that you can earn "experience points" as you play matches and upgrade your Home City as you progress, thereby unlocking new units and upgrades for any future skirmishes.

The online community for this game here on Steam is small, but still quite active and friendly, so playing online multiplayer is usually easy and enjoyable, although I must say that I do not have much experience with this side of the game, since I am normally a more singleplayer-oriented gamer. The multiplayer matches play out similarly to the computer skirmishes, in that you can upgrade your Home City as you play more and more games (your Home City for multiplayer is stored in your online account).

In conclusion, I have to say that I really have enjoyed Age of Empires 3 as much, if not actually more, than any of its predecessors or contemporaries. Although the singleplayer campaign is not quite a complete success, for me this game is just a deeply immersive and intense historical RTS game. I love the feeling of progression that I can get whenever I level-up and upgrade my Home City, and I really adore the vast number of special and unique units that can become available to your civilization as you explore the map or interact with your Home City.

My only hope and wish for Age of Empires 3 going forward is that maybe the Steam Workshop will be opened up for it in the future, so that we can access and easily install some of the great mods that have been created by the fan community for the game over the years since its release.

Marginally a thumbs down, and for valid reasons. Its a familiar game genre that is easy to pick up and play from scratch, and i remember enjoying this first time round, on old low-res CRT screens.  It is so close to the Settlers that most people will already know intuitively what to do.  HOWEVER...and it's a big however. It's curious that the game hasn't yet been patched or updated to play in HD res, so if you've invested in a thumping good HD flatview monitor you'll have a somewhat pixellated view whichever resolution you opt for, or maybe just stick with AOE 2 with its twee retro graphics.  The control GUI takes up far too much of the screen area, and a lot of features on the map are heaped close together and appear confused.  Things you get used to during play.  I doubt they'll patch or update this version, more likely they'll go for AOE 3 HD and get us to buy it all over again for the higher screen resolution compatibilities.  I scratch my head at Steam, for not making these things clear in the game info.  Getting to the point where they've abandoned any pretence at quality control and are happy to sell us anything.

Final analysis: a glib good-clean-family-fun game by the Bill Gates Empire, except that families don't play games on computers, individuals play games on computers.  The demographic doesn't exist beyond film and TV.  They worked on assumptions back in "those days".  Now we know better and this would have been a slightly grittier game if they'd woken up ten years earlier.
