This wouldn't be a bad game, 15 years ago, and I understand it is an older game. However, given it's initial release date was 2005, I am going to review it's gameplay based on the common expectation of features, and it's current playable status based on compatability with modern computers.

Compairing this to standard RTS of the time that had been released prior to this one, starcraft and warcraft, it is seriously lacking. Units have no special controls that were standard by 2005 such as attack move, patrol, ect. your only option is attack and move, and hope your units are capable of figuring out what to attack.

The storyline is great, it's interesting and engaging, however quirky, and without adding spoilers, it tries to be historically accurate as far as timeline and unit names, however it is like the entire story and themes were created by someone who never achieved a higher grade than C- in history.

The hero unit voices are so repetitive it will make you want to not use them just so you do not have to hear them. 

As far as current compatability, this game works fine with current Windows 7 8 10, however my biggest issue is the size of the interface, it seems like despite the game being made compatible for larger screens, it didn't scale correctly, which makes the entire gameplay feel very claustrophobic on larger screans (higher than 1080).

I would give this game a 4/10, but most would rate it higher, it's worth trying if interested and you can get over the above mentioned problems, but for me it was just too many announces to really make it fun to play.

Even though I'm only speaking on behalf of the campaign, it is an excellent primer for RTS noobs that teaches you the fundamentals of resource management and iconic series combat through a host of interesting scenarios. The plots in all of the campaigns are funny because of how linear and predictable they are, but you'll get to a point where you're more engaged with the elements of gameplay. I'd highly encourage this game to be the one in the franchise to start out in if only because it has an easy mode unlike its unforgiving brother AoE II. 

Some minor gripes about this game would be unintelligent friendly AI (you have to direct them to do everything, even attack enemies that are 4 feet away), audio desynch issues with cutscenes, and lack of steam workshop integration. If mythology and II have it, why not this one? 

All in all it's a steal for the sale price.

Age of Empires 3 is an RTS classic, the (unfortunately) last game in the Age of Empires' series installment, was brilliant for it's time, and definitely still can count itself among the best classic RTS' out there, even according to the standards of today for that genre in particular, as well as the Strategy genre as a whole.
Aside from this, the game also has an interesting shipment system, which is quite unique, and spices up the game, that is not even mentioning all of the different units, from the different civilizations and their playstyles.
The graphics are beginning to show their age, but nevertheless are still quite good, and decent to look at.
The AI, though a bit rudimentary, at hard difficulty can easily prove to be quite a challenge, especially if you are fighting the French with the Napoleon personality (viva la Baguette?).
The game is not supported anymore, due to it's age, [b]however[/b], you can easily through third party programs like GameRanger find and play multiplayer games online.

Oh, and remember to launch the game through Asian Dynasties, as you would otherwise not be able to access the content of all of the DLCs and their content at the same time. Enjoy. : )

Of all the titles in the Age of Empires/Mythology series, I think this one solidly brings up the rear.  Due to various game mechanics and design choices, I just never enjoyed playing this one as much as other games in the series.  That said, if you enjoy the AOE series, no reason not to pick this one up, too (though I would wait for a sale).  For me, AOE III took a long time to find itself, not really "arriving" until the Asian Dynasties DLC.  Since this is the "complete" version, though, you'll have all the added features that finally made this game worth returning to more than a few times a year.

Though It seems very similar to the previous two titles, AoE3 has vastly superior graphics and a greater variety of unit types for each nation.  Combine this with several engaging single player campaigns and excellent multiplayer options to give you a solid strategy experience.

Well, I don't think I need to explain the premise of this game. I am pretty sure that everybody here knows the huge legacy that Age of Empires has created for itself. Age of Empirers I (Released in 1997) was already one of the best RTS games around. So basically, in my opinion, these games are still some of the best and most enjoyable Real Time Strategy games around.

Back in the old days I used to play Age of Empires I and II on the computers on my school. We'd gather with friends around a single computer, and attempt to defeat the AI. Speaking of the AI, they're pretty good. They're strong and reasonably fair enemies to play against if you do not have friends to play with/ who own the game. When I found Age of Empires II I was ecstatic. Age of Empires II basically improved on every single part compared to Age of Empires I. 

Now, Age of Empires III is new to me. I've played it for a while now and it seems more difficult than Age of Empires II. It seems like they gave the AI some new tactics and a higher speed. I was unprepared when the enemy showed up in my town. Although part of that was also me being new to the game. I had yet to find out where to find everything in the new UI, what every building did and what every unit did. So I'll give it a few more tries.

But, knowing what amazing games I and II were, I know for sure III will not be a let down. Everything looks polished and just simply amazing. It's the logical next step in Age of Empires' legacy.

It's worth what you pay for it. For sure. Especially now during the sales.

Dustforce truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself playing one level for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of losing levels is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the levels are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a level to earn a key, and you would use that key to earn more levels. In layman's terms, to earn more levels, you had to perfect current levels. They ditched that and added an XP system in which you gain more XP to earn a key the more levels you play and perfect. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock base levels. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many levels are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging levels, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to sweep up EVERY leaf, and to get an S in Finesse, you have to maintain your combo throughout an entire level. 

Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Dustforce is its expasive community. There are lots of Community Workshop maps for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.

Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:

10/10

I spent years playing Age of Empires 2 + Age of Kings expansion. Since I'm not much of a RTS fan, I never liked other strategy games much, but AoE 1&2 were a pleasure for me. When AoE3 first came out, I tried it, but didn't like it. It was annoying to young me, because I was used to AoE2-like gameplay, and the sudden change was something I hated in AoE3.

Years have passed, and a friend talked me into buying AoE3. We started playing it together, and it changed my opinion completely. While he is a huuuuuge fan, I wouldn't call myself a fan, but I like the game very much. It's smooth, and has some interesting advantages compared to older AoE titles.

Although I'm still not a good RTS player, and I still don't really like playing RTS games, AoE3 captured my time. When played with a friend, this game is a great co-op opportunity. A variety of races, all with their unique units and strategies, makes this game what it is: A classic.

Although I loved the game, I must say that Age of Empires 3: Complete Collection is not worth buying at 37€. It's too expensive, and is old enough to fall below the 15€ mark. However, if you're like me, and like sales - buy the game when its price gets low enough for your expectations.

Age of Empires III was the RTS that made me fall in love with good RTS games, way back it originally released. This version shines as absolute masterpiece. It's aged unbelievably well, and is worth every penny. Instead of a long winded write up of this colossal game, here's a list of some of the reasons this is the must-own version of this game:

[h1] Performance:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Beautiful Graphics
[*] Well Optimized for modern PC's
[*] Supports large Resolutions
[*] Supports high refresh rates
[*] Scrolling that's smooth as silk
[*] Plenty of graphics config options
[*] Controls are easy to configure
[/list]

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Nice tutorial system
[*] Great for RTS game beginners
[*] Great for RTS game veterans
[*] Robust yet easy to learn system
[*] Well written, and casted
[*] Good, Solid Campaigns
[*] All the Expansions
[*] Colorful and attractive art style
[*] Beautiful settings and worlds
[*] Wonderful soundtrack
[*] Intuitive sound effects
[*] attention to detail
[*] many hours of entertainment
[*] cool historical figures and eras
[*] Battle on land and water.
[*]...and it's so incredibly satisfying to build a massive army, and watch it crush the enemy to a pile of bodies and burning rubble.
[/list]

This is not Age of Empires 2 or 1, or Age of Mythology - This is an entirely new breed of animal, so keep that in mind if you have played other AoE games. The game is 10+ years old, which is something else to keep in mind (because it's easy to forget at times as polished as it is).

You may find the current 39.99 tag a bit pricey, but that doesn't mean it isn't worth it. You can get plenty of playtime out of this game, both online and in single player. I love this game.

This is a GREAT game. a little out dated graphically, and in some ways can become somewhat repetitive. but the gameplay itself delivers a well balanced tactical strategy, that changes with every new round. Factors such as locations of resources, natural land obstacles, the strengths and weaknesses of which team you play as, which team you are playing against, and timing of every move all come in to play. If you are looking for a graphically superior game, this is not for you, but if you are looking for a well balanced game that tests your wit on decision making and productivity, this is for you!

Age of Empires 3 is my favorite game. Yes, that places it infront of other video game giants, including Arma, Warband, Civilization, and perhaps more appropriately, Age of Empires 2.

It's not the graphics... it's definately not the graphics. They're not bad per se, in fact they are sometimes beautiful, but compared to the standard rts of today, they probably rank 4 or 5 out of 10.

AoE 3 is my favorite game because it's *fun*. Over the last decade or so, I've loved and then grown tired of dozens of games, Fallout 4 being the most recent victim. Age 3, however, is always fun. AI provides a challenge, the community is still amazingly friendly and going strong, there are tournaments where you can win cash prizes, plenty of mods, and a quite large amount of diverse factions. When you drop yourself into a game, both single and multiplayer, it's an engaging experience every time. Honestly, I can't even find the words to explain why it's always so fun, it just is. Perhaps it's the historical care given to each unit, or maybe the ridiculous cheats and snarky comments of the AI, I don't know. If I said every game was completely unique, I'd be lying; but that's not a problem, because Age 3 does what works.

I usually don't like writing reviews, especially ones over 9 words, but this game deserves at least a little bit of support from me. It's the least I can do for the most captivating game on the steam market.
Recommended :)

Age of Empires 3

Genre: Strategy - Real Time Strategy
Rating: 10/10
Personal playing period: 5+ years
Is it worth a buy: Yes. Even at full price. This is a necessity for any strategy players collection.
Girl vs Game: Unless it's some super model I'd definately rather play the Game.

Personal Comment:
This is an amazing game with endless amounts of game time. The hours on here isnt a fraction of my actual game time online and offline. Been playing this game since the day it was released and still play it and love it today. I even missed a couple of meals as well as toilet breaks playing this believe it or not. I have bladder and bowel control of a ninja thanks to AOE.

Online gaming:
The online gaming community is still very active and people of all skill levels are on it. You will find anywhere between 500 to 2000 people online at any given time. Beware though that even though AOE is helpful and awesome the online community are sometimes a bunch of cocktonsil nimrod supremists who think they're amazing whilst never having seen or felt a girl up close unless in a magazine. But if your skin is thick and you dont give a flying **** about other people you'll be fine.

Short Summary:
This is a real time strategy game that plays off in the medieval times. There are 8 standard civilizations, 3 native indian civilizations and 3 Asian civilizations. Each civ provides a different set of advantages and it takes time to learn how to utilise the various civs to their full capability. Learning each civilisation takes time and it is great fun doing that. There are countless amounts of maps that allow for the use of different strategies. The game also has a story rich single player campaign. I have not played the campaign yet but never felt the need to as the standard game modes offer more than enough fun and game time.
The game also has progressive improvement meaning the more you play the more items get unlocked and the stronger your civilisation becomes. This ensures that you want to play more and more in order to improve the strength of your favourite civilisation.

Learning Curve and Gameplay:
Easy to start but tough to master. The learning curve to start playing and learning the basics is very easy. Learning the various civilisations and their strengths is more challenging and may take a lot of practice and time. The gameplay is very simplistic in it being a basic RTS with click and place. Gathering of basic resources and using those resources are easy and self explanotary. A tutorial can be played to understand the basics but this game is very playable and a new player will get it after playing only for a few hours.

I played this game when it came out 10 years ago. The conventional thinking is that Age of Empires II is the "best," but the truth is that Age of Empires III is actually the best.

I'll make it simple. Age of Empires III is better because it's newer and it's more of a game and less of a time killer. There is actually a single-player with a real story to the campaign. There are a ton of different units in the game and I haven't even gotten to the DLC yet. This version is more fast-paced and is equally as fun on land as it is on water.

There is one issue that isn't major, but it kind of is for me. That is the game hasn't been updated in a while and doesn't allow for steam overlay (shift+tab) and does not contain any achievements. I'm not sure if the game supports 4K either.

I am using WIndows 10 with a GTX 970 and i5-4466. There are absolutely no technical hiccups and the game runs very smooth.

Overall, great game that surpasses Age of Empires II in every way while looking GREAT for its age. Also, no major bugs or compatibility issues with Windows 10. Needs update to add new steam features like the Shift+Tab overlay and achievements.

This is the fourth installment of the Age of series (including Age of Mythology), progressing down the evolution of civilization. Historic real-time strategy games tend to stay around the Middle Ages of Ancient Civilizations. It’s nice to see a game in the colonial era of history.

Unlike Age of Empires 2, it feels like this game was crafted entirely with the idea of balance. Every civilization has an answer to any problem thrown at you. Most of the civilizations have a heavy and counter variant of each of the three main military groups (infantry, cavalry, and siege weapons). This game ‘should’ be the best in terms of competitive play, since the game mechanics are well rounded and nothing is too overpowered.  

But this is where the positive part of the compliment sandwich ends. 

If you were to compare each of the Age of games to days of the week, AoM is the ambitiously positive Friday, AoE2 is the kick-ass Saturday, and AoE3 is the lazy Sunday. Every time I play this game, I feel like I should be doing something else. “Sure, I could be playing this, but I could also practice bass.” (AoE1 is a non-existent day where Horse Archers rule the streets).

As I mentioned, this game is very well balanced. The problem with this is since every civilization has a well-built set of answers, nearly every civilization feels like they play the same. In the two expansions, the only truly-unique civilizations are the Aztecs (only infantry) and the Chinese (batch-based unit creation). The other two native civilizations feel identical to each other and play like a weaker European civs.  The Indians and Japanese have their gimmicks (villagers cost wood and houses attract animals to trickle in resources, respectively), but don’t feel that unique. 

Gathering resources is a complete yawn, especially once you’ve got your farms and plantations organized. It gets even more laughably easy when you’re Japanese with the shrines and rice paddies. Even if there is no wood left or it’s all in hostile territory, you can just order a factory from the home city to make you wood for free. Unlike AoE2, there is little reason to aggressively cultivate resources. 

The campaign is decently written (about equal to AoM), but it infuriates me to no end how you can’t change the game speed in the campaign. I’m used to the fast-paced speed of ‘fast’ in Skirmish mode. When I start a campaign mission, it feels like the game just chugged two cartons of molasses and is recuperating from the syrup hangover. They may have slowed it down because the AI can be a bit difficult, but I feel like they did it so people wouldn’t think the campaign is too small. 

However, despite all of my issues, I still love the game and would recommend it to anyone who likes RTS’s. I am a big fan of the home city mechanic where you gain experience when you play Skirmishes and can improve the shipments you receive in-game.

However, I wouldn’t recommend it to someone who is getting into them. AoM was more colourful and unique, and AoE2 was more intense and challenging.

This game is a game that should continue to have a large community. It actually pairs well with Empire Total War. Empire Total War has a realistic simulation setting while this game plays similar to the obvious classic that is Age of Empires 2 - except a more exciting time period and more exciting fleshed out civilizations. Play Empire Total War when you want  a Simulation. But if you want balanced individual battles come back to this game - this game is more healthy for your mind than Empire Total War as you have to continously strategize - versus the action-based simulation of Empire which will kind of make you feel like a dope if you play long. And winning won't feel as sweet. But the realism in Empire Total War is to pretty to pass up as well. Actually, if you buy Empire Total War, you best buy this game as well because it will only enhance your experience of this excellent time period. This is an endorsement for both games for a person who wants to have an excellent gaming experience set in a great Enlightenment Time Period (the Ancient Roman Period and WWII period being the only rival IMO for great battle gaming)

Despite the 9 hours play time it shows, I'd previously pirated the game (sorry) and played it quite a bit. Upon seeing it in the Steam store (and having an income of my own) I decided to purchase the Complete Collection. I was not disappointed. I'm not a huge fan of how AoE sticks to certain periods of time with its games (1 was Nomad - Iron; 2 was Dark - Renaissance or something like that; 3 was Colonial - late 1800s), but it's understandable because there is such a thing as too much content in RTS's. I'd say Empire Earth is a definitive example of "too much content". It gets to the point that even with restricted Trees (which this game has an excellent way of delivering) there becomes too many upgrades and units that never really get used. AoE 3 somewhat requires you to build different kinds of units. You CAN get away with spamming one or two units, but you're better off actually building an army. Overall it's a really fun game, but a definite con is the somewhat dead multiplayer.

This is my favorite RTS game. I've loved the AOE franchise from the first game. Even with it being about 10 years old, its graphics are quite decent and even compare to current RTS games. If you like RTS games and have not played this one, you're missing out.

[h1] Quick Summary: [/h1] Pretty generic RTS. Single Player Campaigns are ok. Nothing great, but you might burn 8-12 hours doing them. For more entertainment use Cheat codes. Multiplayer has a decent amount of people on normally, but requires heavy grinding for full experience. Revolves around getting food, wood, and coin. Food is used for all infantry and cavalry. Wood is used for certain infantry, all buildings, and most artillery. Coin is used for infantry, cavalry, artillery, and upgrades.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
+Graphics are pretty good for a six year old game.
+Gameplay is pretty good for RTS with some features unique to AOE3.
+Pretty easy to set up multiplayer games with friends.
+Multiplayer has a decent player base still.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
-While not impossible to beat, generally higher level civilizations can crush lower leveled players.
-Leveling up takes ALOT of farming games for xp in multiplayer.
-Xp can't be farmed alone so you always need to have another person to level up in multiplayer.
A game that is unaffected by time, because it is still f**king awesome!

Age of empires 3 is 10 years old already, so why am i writing a review now? Well, because it is one of a few games i have never really stopped playing. 

Ill be honest, it probably is one of the best, if not the best RTS game ever made. Some may disagree with me, but before you do, listen to why i make such a bold claim. 

Well, first off, being a success was a tall order for this game. Why? because of its prequil. Age of empires 2 was and still is amazing. I have yet to meet a single person who played that back in the day, even just once or twice, who have a bad word to say about it. because of this a lot was expected from Age of empires 3, and boy did they deliver!

They added a few things to the original recipe, and none of them bad might i add. First up, when it came out it was a graphical master piece, and even today it is not bad to look at, but graphics is almost not even worth mentioning compared to its features. 

Probably the most notable feature they brought in is the Home City(the one thing that puts this at the top of RTS) 
Basically what this is, is an off map support system that is decades ahead of any other off map support system even by todays standards. You have the ability to pick 20-25(depending on what version you are playing) shipment cards from 100-150 total available cards. These are age specific, with a limit on cards you can pick for each age, and they consist of unit, supply, building and upgrade bonuses you can send to the main map. You gain experience from building, destroying, killing things and collecting resources. This experience counts down on an experience bar until a shipment is ready to be sent. Through the home city you can refine and specialized your deck to your desired playstyle. you may also have more than one deck for each civilization, so there are lots of different ways to play each civilization. Almost anything can be viable in the right situation. 

Secondly, aging. Most games have the first age figured out. It fucuses on aquiring resources in order to go to the next age. Age of empires 3 however has another aspect to it. You are actualy encouraged to explore the map with your starting explorer(a hero unit that can be knocked out and held for ransom, but not killed). In fact you are almost required to. There are treasures all over the map that are protected by treasure guardians. Once these are killed you can collect a treasure. Treasures can give you a unit, a worker, supplies and experience. Depending on which treasures you go for, you may further increase the effectiveness of your desired strategy along with shipment choices. 

A third aspect to this game are trade posts. Trade posts are build either on a specified location on the trade route, or next to a native village. if placed on the trade route you may recieve extra experience or supplies everytime the trademan/coach/train comes by. If built on a native village, you gain access to training one or two types of native troops and some native research. Some of these are very powerful, indeed all of them can be powerful depending on what your strategy is. 

So much strategical choices, and then the unit training and the fighting havent even started yet!
When it comes to fighting there is a very balanced counter system at play. everything can be hard countered by something else, and fighting styles change from age to age. In early ages you want to raid your opponents economy as much as you can to limit him from doing what he wants to do. At this stage it is a good idea to have a few cavalry around. Later on when cannons come to play battles start where players to for the kill. At this time cavalry is your answer again, only generally cannons are defended by Musketeers or pikeman, which hard counter cavalry. To kill these muskets and pikes you need bows or skirmishers, which in turn get countered by cavalry...so the aim is to catch your opponent out of position. Fights are decided by positioning and reinforcement ability just as much as unit composition. 

And now i havent even started talking about the naval aspect! OOOOOH just check it out yourself lol. In short, this is a highly reccomended game. Its online population even after 10 years are still rarely lower than 1200. There are games to be found throughout the day, and they are relatively easy to find.

Most people don't rate this game highly, this is mainly due to the high milestone set by Age of Empires 2 as that game was a work of art.
I personally could not recommend the campaign in this game, whilst it has a semi decent storyline, it is not something you can really get immersed in, if you had some hours to spare it is still worth a play-through however. 
Where this game really does things well is the multiplayer, you have lots of different nations to choose from with lots of different gametypes, deathmatch, treaty (No rush), and supremacy (normal). The different strategies that you can run for each nation is outstanding and really brings a lot of forward thinking to the game, planning out how to rush a base faster than your opponent is something that brings a lot of thrill and planning. 
To summarise, if you are buying this game for the campaign, don't. However if you like multiplayer gameplay, I would defiantly get this.

Being a long time fan of Age of Empires: 2, I bought this game a long time ago, way before it came to steam. At that time I thought it was mediocre, the mechanics being odd, why do some things require buildings and some do not? There are no great ways to get resources, everything costs more and takes longer to build so you are looking at lower villager counts but higher resource costs, it is ridiculous. Much harder to build a good economy and military. Also there is the fact that you can build gunpowder units at the same time as archaic units. Why would you use crossbowmen when you could have musketeers? The two didn't exist at the same points and so it makes the game "feel" weird. Not to mention everything is in a frontier/colonial era. Why are there pikemen at all? Makes no sense. All in all this is a horrible sequel to the amazing second installment and I will be spending my time on the second one.

In the third game of the AoE series the battlefield moves from the great mainland of Europe, Northern Africa etc. to the frontiers of the Early Americas, where colonies fight each other to gain control of the New Lands. 
Compared to the second of the series, it feels like a lot of things are simplified. For example, gathered recources must no longer be carried to specialized buildings by settlers, but are automatically added to your stockpile, ranged units always hit their target, no friendly fire,....
However, this game introduces Experience generation and Shipments. Shipments are bonusses that are send from the Home City (in Europe) to your colony on the Americas to give you a boost in the battle. These can be recources (in the form of recource crates), soldiers, or even special buildings (like a fort). Shipments are earned by gaining experience, which is awarded when killing enemy units, construction, training,...
Another fun feature is exploration. Every colony has an Explorer that can scout the various areas your colonies might be. He can also construct trade posts, which can connect your colony to the local trade route (and receive some of its profits) or establish relations with the local natives (who can provide you with warriors and interesting bonusses). Each map has different features, so exploration is (as always) an important thing to do.
And last but not least: gunpowder. In the second game it was something only available at the very last, now it is available at the very beginning, in the form of riflemen, musketeers, and many different types of cannon. Because, let's be honest, it is a lot of fun to see a regiment of enemy infantry getting blown to pieces by a handfull of your heavy artillery pieces.

It is a very fun successor of the second AoE. Put it on your wishlist and get it once it is on sale

Whether you are a fast paced strategist or a laid back gamer, Age of Empires might be the game for you. Personally, I can't keep up with the many skilled players in the online PvP part of the game, however, I enjoy the more personal single player skirmishes that AoE has to offer. That is not say that the community is terrible, because it is just exactly the opposite. When I first was trying to learn the hotkeys and tips and tricks of the experts, there were many players willing to take their time and guide me when I needed guidance. 

As you may have seen from the trailers and videos of this game, there is much fun to be had. The beauty of being able to conquer another empire is a victory in and of itself. It is a great game to come home to and just unwind from the stresses of the day. 

The campaign mode can be quite easy, so I recommend trying to challenge yourself and set the difficulty a bit higher than you normally would. The AI in the game can be slow and unchallenging should you choose the normal or easy settings. Also, the story is very cinematic so try to watch the video bits if that's your thing.

Overall, I highly recommend this game. It is great for all ages of players.

Yes, it may be 2015, but this is still my all time favourite game! It is a very strategic game with very amusing aspects. It includes colonies; some being the dutch, german, ottoman and british ( there is TONS more colonies ) but each colony has their own ability, i will not spoil anything, but some abilities are quite amazing! If for say; you were tired of the normal version of the game; luckily the game has included little minigames, if you can find it, also there is the little cheat-cheats in the game, that you can activate before you start the game, click the '' allow cheats '' button. This game runs smooth on my old laptop ( which was made in 2004! ) and even smoother on my 2015 gaming one. This game can definitely be a time waster! When people might be in the game thinking to themselves "the graphics can improve", just keep this in mind: the game was made in 2005, but I can guarentee this: even in the year 2050, i will still be playing! Thank you and I really do hope you will get the game.

Absolutely love this game. Probably in my top 5 favourite games of all time. A lot of people resentAoE III because it's such a radical departure from AoE II, but once you give it some time, you realize that this game has way more depth than AoE II could ever have hoped for.

Some contrasts with AoE II:

-Less Civs that are more unique: AoE II has dozens of civs, but ultimately all of them have the same characteristics, whether it be the graphical style, units, similar sampling of techs, etc. There is a good deal of difference between the Euro civs alone in AoE 3, each one plays really differently. Dutch for example has villagers created from coin and bank buildings that generate free coin. Russia generates masses of troops that are weak in strength. Ottoman vils cannot be trained and are generated automatically. When you add the native civs and Asian civs, the difference is even more pronounced. They age up differently, have different classes of units (Sioux for example are mainly cavalry only and Indians have various elephants), have different ways of aging up, have different ways of collecting resources (japan cant kill hunts, but they can build shrines), different ways of generating units (asian civs can ally with a european civ not ingame that gives them euro troops and aztecs can generate infantry from a dance pit). The civs take time to master. You can be an export Iroquois player, but you can fail miserably with the Portugese in the very next game. In AoE II, it was not so hard to transition between civs.

-Streamlined economy. While micromanaging economy can be fun to an extent, handling all those idle villagers has always been a bitch. building a mining camp in the middle of nowhere only to get slaughtered by a light cavalry always sucked. Villagers now no longer have to walk back to a resource depot. There are also many new ways of automatically generating resources like shrines, infinite farms/plantations (coin), whales and factories. This allows you to focus more on the battle than on your 5 villagers in the middle of nowhere. 

-Homecity: The card system looks simple at first, but ultimately the difference between a noob and an expert are the card shipments. The cards allow each civ to be even more differentiated. The same civ can become a rushing civ, a naval civ, a mercenery civ, a boom civ, all based on your card deck. You can choose to have early shipments of villagers or resource gathering boosts, or troops, based on whether you want to rush or boom. India gets free villagers with each shipment, but you can ship a card that makes them send rifleman instead.

-Units: gunpowder units are immensely satisfying. It's arguably a lot easier to micro them than mobs of AoE II. It's fun to watch all your cannons and mortars blow ships, infantry and building to smithereens. You can get a hot air balloon or an invisible spy. You can have surgeons set up field hospitals. You can have a flamethrower or an arsonist. You can set up a gatling gun to mow down villagers. You can get a dog or an orangutan, You can old school if you want and have two handed swordsman as the german (doppels, one of the best units in the game). There's a lot more variety in the battle.

-All the small things: trading posts, native villages, treasures, merceneraies, revolutions, explorer/monk/warchiefs, special wonder, treaty, dance pits, consulates, pets, etc. 

Some of the downsides are as others mentioned: weak AI (strong early game, but become downright stupid in the late game), lag issues, small community (but it's been growing recently. There are tournaments with prizes of 2000$-3000$) and lack of support/patches, though the civs are fairly balanced (with the exception of ottomans).

Full Price is a bit too much imo, but wishlist the game and nab it while it's on sale. Give it some time and you won't regret it.

Decides to play as the Russians

Sees that you can spawn 10 cheap infantry with one click, and three villagers with one click

Decides to make the enemy a Native American tribe

Figures it will be easy because the Native use bows instead of firearms

Makes friends with all the other native tribes

I send a hot air balloon over their village and see that they practically have nothing

Ten minutes later and they have a giant army which wrecks my cheap infantry with their arrows

Decides to build a wall around colony and upgrades it to a stone wall

Sends a second force of men with a cannon

The Natives somehow are able deflect cannon fire and musket fire

My force gets rekt

They send a massive force against my stone walls

Manages to break the stone wall in a minute with just arrows

Repels the assault

Rebuilds the fallen wall

Starts to build a fort

Apparently the Natives have satelite technology and send a force as soon as I start building it

With their highly advanced arrow technology they break down the stone gate to my colony

No infantry left

Rage quits

Like your typical AOE series entry, but with a more RPG feel. The Home City aspect is where the RPG aspect lies. You create a Home City for what ever country you select, and for whatever game mode. As you gain experience points in game, you level up your Home City. You can select many cards for your civilization. These cards give resource bonuses, building bonuses, unit bonuses, unqiue powers, etc. However, most of the cards are basically the same for each civilization. You can have 22 cards in deck, and there are about 100 to choose from. Some are unlocked when your Home City moves up a level. 

The game itself runs nice, and multiplayer still works. There are still people playing the multiplayer. 
There is a lack of civilizations compared to other AOE games. Some nations are really OP, and others are not so much.

Among the best RTS games in history

Though many people say AOE2 is the best in the franchise, I actually think AOE3, with the abundance of exotic civs from 2 expansions and unofficial mods, has surpassed that timeless classic.

Graphics: AOE3 looks great at distance, even up to today's standards. That's mainly due to the excellent using of lighting effects (shades and HDR), the textures and animation on a closer look however, are on the same level as Age of Mythology (kinda obvious they used the same engine), which is a little bit dated. But it doesn't hurt at all, for some of the best RTS games like SupCom and COH aren't beautiful up close either.

Sound: Soundtracks are awesome, definitely the best in the franchise and probably one of the best in the whole genre. I especially love the track of revolution event, it pumps me up so much that I want to punch a freaking baby in the face. Sound effects are even more impressive, more so the sound of canons. God how I love the sound of canon fire in this game, every shot is like the mixture of bass solo and Morgan Freeman monologue coming out of a subwoofer. Pure heaven.

Gameplay: Quite different from the previous games. The tempo has been speeded up a bit. Range attack becomes the mainstream and melee the sidekick. Resources are down to 3, which I think is acceptable. Civs feel very distinct from each other especially those from different continents. Balance is marginally okay, with 3 pretty OP civs and same amount of trench tier ones. Many new features like homecity and card deck building are actually great fun and add a lot to the strategic depth. Online games are quite stable and smooth, and usually end in stomping.

Mods: I love the mod Napoleonic Era to death. This along with another mod called The War of the Triple Alliance make me rate this game among top 3 RTS on my list. Holy crap the additional civs and features are mindblowing. Age of Empires III is an excellent game.

The game has innovations in your gameplay. The first thing is the system of provisions, that help a lot during the game, providing you some things like food, gold and wood. Depending of the nation that you are playing, you have another kind of provisions like soldiers, cannons etc.

The other interest thing is the hero of your campaign always present in your mission, and every hero has a special ability, that helps during the battles.

The graphics are very pretty, with different environmental and climate condition, but the cut scenes in the beginning of 
missions are bad, with a terrible graphic.
The classic things of the game still present in this sequence, with exploitation of natural resources (wood, gold, stone, livestock, fishes)  and the advance of eras, with the improvement of your buildings and military.

This sequence has expanded the experience with Asian nations (India, China and Japan). AoE II has a few missions with 
Asian nations.

The War Chiefs are awesome. Play with the Indians is an incredible experience, with the unique buildings and infantry.

This game still very hard, but less than his predecessor.

Unfortunately, strategy games are rare in these times, but Age of Empires III is a good option of more actual strategy game.

This game offers a lot to people who love RTS games. However, it loses a few points for not having as many ages (time periods) to upgrade through. I really wish there were a few more ages to go through, as the most modern age you can get to still seems pretty far back in time. To make a quick comparison, in Rise of Nations the last age was an age where you could make nukes, computers, tanks, etc. It made the game more epic when you spent time literally going from B.C. times to the times of now (and possibly even slightly beyond).

Overall the game is good, it controls very well and the progression tree is still awesome, just feels a little short.

There's a lot here for the people who just like custom games against the A.I. too. You can have a "deck" of abilities you use for each game and gain experience to buy new abilities. This is for each race (Dutch, Russians, etc.) so if you really want to grind it out, you definitely can.

I loved AoE2 because I felt I can build my own civilization from grounds up, advance it, explore and completely take over the world. It gave me freedom to think and focus on building. AoE3 has nothing of that, is just a rock-paper-scissors RTS where only thing that matters is how quickly you produce your units and throw them into battle... some people may like it, to me its a complete money waste.

Quite a change from AOE II.

What I like:
Home City shipments
Graphics
Gameplay (will explain in detail below)
Treasure hunting
Explorer
Clearer identity for each nationality

What I dislike:
OP units (from Artillery)
Poor AI (well, for SP)

Gameplay
The change from AOE 2 is quite substantial. I would compare AOE 3 to Starcraft. AOE 2 is a game where you spam with strategy. AOE 3 makes it difficult to spam due to population requirements. I think it suits more to my playing style as it is easier to counter different units. Another thing to note is the collection of resources. The removal of carrying resources back to Town Centre/Resource structures makes the game easier and faster, as you can just send workers to unknown parts of the land to get resources. This can be both a boon and a bane. In AOE 2, you stop your opponents by destroying the collection buildings, but you cannot do that in AOE 3; you need to kill the villagers themselves.

Overall an 8.5/10.

This game is almost great. It's a solid historical RTS game at its core. It is immensely satisfying to let loose a volley of musket fire or watch the simulated projectiles from field cannon ragdoll your opponent's troops. It borrows a lot from Age of Empires 2 in terms of mechanics, feeling, and ambience, which I certainly consider a plus. It makes gathering resources simpler and puts an end to annoyances like farm queuing. The game's few glaring flaws, though, affect it considerably.

I run into my first problem with the game when I run it. Having bought the "Complete Collection," I thought I would have one game to run with the campaigns and other content from the two expansions included, but when I start the game up, a prompt asks me whether I want to start the Complete Collection, the War Chiefs expansion, or the Asian Dynasties expansion. Bafflingly, running the Complete Collection only gives me the vanilla content; running the War Chiefs expansion gives me the vanilla content plus that expansion, and running Asian Dynasties gives me vanilla plus both expansions. This is confusing and it gives the impression that the Steam release was poorly done, like a rush job made by an intern in some outsourced office.

Next, I start up the game and I'm upset to see that my units have no formation orders. In AoE2, I could set the formation of my units, choosing to group them together, stagger them, or group them to defend weaker units, for example. I could also set units to be aggressive, defensive, to stand their ground, or to be completely inert. I couldn't do any of that in this game. Only after mentioning this problem to friends who have experience with the game did I learn that you CAN give formation and behavior orders--you just have to enable them from settings. Needless to say, that's poor game design. As far as I know, no in-game hints or tutorial lets you know you can turn formation settings on.

Finally, my biggest problem with the game is the home city and card systems. They are closely intertwined, and they suck. Here's the deal with home cities: In Age of Empires 2 (or really, any RTS that isn't garbage) you begin any game by choosing a civilization or faction. In those games, each civilization has its own strengths and weaknesses which make it unique, and the uniqueness of different civilizations is what keeps those games fun and interesting. In Age of Empires 3, however, you don't just pick a civilization--you pick a home city to go along with it. For example, if you want to play as the Germans, you have to pick your home city of Berlin, or Munich, or whatever (you can have multiple home cities per civilization, and level them up individually.) Playing as any home city lets you gain experience to level it up; experienced is gained when you do pretty much anything (build units, destroy units, find treasure on the game map, trade with civilizations native to the game map, and so on.) Leveling up your home city lets you pick new cards for it. Here's the deal with cards: earning XP in a game will cause a bar to fill up. When the bar is full, you can pick a "card" of your choice from your home city's deck to be shipped to a town center or other building. Cards are bonuses that can be one of a multitude of things, from extra villagers to crates of resources to town center wagons. So, basically, while playing any game, you can choose bonus units, buildings, or resources to materialize for you once every several minutes or so. Every civilization begins with a default deck but leveling up your home city lets you pick better cards. This sucks because it allows you to smooth out the flaws in any civilization and substantially changes what makes each one special. It lessens the consequences for screwing up; if you forget to mine gold, you can just wait until you can pick another card and get crates of hundreds of gold shipped express to your doorstep. No RTS, AoE3 included, could conceivably be improved by adding RPG elements and the ability to beef up a civilization. All civilizations should be on an equal playing field by default, and the ability to grind up the raw strength and adaptability of a civilization flies in the face of that basic fact of RTS design. The game would be vastly improved by having these awful systems removed so that I can just pick a civilization and have it work the same way every time, instead of being obliged to fine-tune it by grinding. 

In summary, it sucks.

This is a classic ok ok before you get your nerd panties in a bunch and spout flemmy gibberish about doom and warcraft sit down. This is AOE but with some better shit added that's all it's in every way a classic in style and form. The stupid campaigns add nothing for me as with all games that add some arbitrary story. I remember people borrowing my warcraft game books to read the story of how it all came to be. What a snorefest! I've always wanted to game as me not some character it feels like watching a movie but it pauses and forces you to click on things before it plays more. The home city concept is very fresh and adds a nice touch to close matches. It compares to the summons in LOTR games as a game changer when used at the right times. I also enjoy the graphics with houses being burned or demolished rather than men stabbing a building like in older games. The cannon effects are amazing with the balls bouncing all over the map. Strategy is much more involved with this game it's not just a race to upgrade units and let them hack away at one another once you build an army. The trade posts make games a back and forth attempt to gain ground and the limited defensive buildings make it more intersting to try and hold a point on the map. The trade posts also offer real advantages while not being so essential that you feel they must be held at all cost. Plus the fun little treasures littering each map make every match interesting without being so complicated it becomes obnoxious. So it's just like any of those old RTS games with a few fun twists. -SEF

I am a big fan of the AOE series, and history. This game is brilliant, although the AI may be silly at times *cough, Napolean* it still has unique gameplay and good graphics, as well a Pretty decent uprgade system. I loved the fact that different units would take up a certain amount of population, e.g. A dragoon would take up 2 population where as the a musketeer would take up 1. There is a huge variety of map choices and with the Asian dynasties pack and The war cheifs DLC, the selection choices are endless, they vary from the Amazon River, The Andes, Anywhere in the US and even the Great silk road in Asia. 

Best feature for me? The Expansion Packs were actually expansions that changed the game in multiple ways and added on to the complete/full base form of the game. normally DLC nowadays is required to get the full package of what the final product should've been. AoE3's Expansion Packs ARE NOT DLC. The Expansion Packs in AoE3 add on to the game content enough to make it feel like a different game within a game. The Expansion Packs aren't neccessary to fully enjoy Age of Empires III; however, having them improves upon the player experience greater.

If you enjoy real time strategy games, enjoy managing an economy, epic large battles, and don't like excessive micromanaging then this is the game for you. It offers brilliant combat with amazing scenery. The unit mapping is rather brilliant and the variety of maps keeps you constantly wanting to play more.

Since I was introduced to Age Of Empires II back in 1999, I was instantly in love with the series. For years I have played AoE2 and all of the sudden Age Of Empires III came out. 
The sheer awesomeness, value and inginuety that went into making this game can be felt in almost every detail. Be it the campaigns, the skirmish modes, the homecity mechanics or the general polish - everything is just cool. Even today, almost 10 years aftet its initial release back in fall 2005. The game looks great, plays great and even though many fans of AoE say that it might be step back, I can totally recommend this gem from a long lost age when real time strategy was at its pinnacle. 
The price might be a bit high, but it is much better than buying the games seperately for 50€ each. I did that. And then I bought this back on steam again. 
Fans of the genre can really grab it now or wait for a rare sale of this game.

AoE 3, the nostalgia.
Third in the AoE series. This game offers a different gameplay style as compared to I and II. The possibility to have home shipments (which in part is predicated on the colonial era settlement) which could to a large extent alter the dynamics of a standard game, can make games very interesting.
The usual strategies and min-maxing continues, as are build orders, resource management, positioning and all the other micro and macro management skills are still present.
Players new to the game, coming from AoE 1 and/or 2 should be warned that it has a generally different graphical style and generally fosters a more dynamic and fastpaced playstyle.

This game is quite a classic RTS from the glory days of AOE, Warcraft, Starcraft, Dawn of War, Red Alert etc. The game features 40+ hours of singleplayer campaign missions for all the expansions, covering several story arcs that are both fictional and historical aswell as multiplayer. The game has aged very well and is still enjoyable and pleasing to the eye after all these years.

Age of Empires allows you to play as many kingdoms from history, ranging from China, The Netherlands, Great Britain and many more. Each country has several unique buildings and units that give all countries a different playstyle. On top of that you are able to unlock 'cards' for your deck by gathering experience. As you build things, destroy enemies etc in the game you will earn experience that can be used for shipments. The shipments you have available are based on which cards you choose in your deck, each one providing a different bonus or group of units. By earning experience while in a battle you'll unlock points, where every point can be used to use one of your shipment cards. 

Another feature Age of Empires has is the Age system, starting at Age 1 you are able to build limited amounts of buildings and units and use limited amounts of shipments. As you upgrade your town hall you'll be able to use better shipments that you can only use at more modern ages aswell as new units, unit upgrades and buildings. 

One of the fun things to do in the game is using the walls and gates to construct a protective barrier around your buildings and placing strategic cannon towers or artillery to defend your base from enemy armies. It's a great game to fool around in against the AI or with and against friends. You can also play with random people if you don't know anyone that has the game, but given the quality of the game it should be possible to convince a friend to get the game aswell ;)

I highly recommend this game, definetely a 4.5/5.
It's great probably one of the greatest games ever made! 10/10

Good points of Age of Empires III:

Good unit diversity: Each civ has a core of units semi-unique to them, making each one feel different enough that playing the Germans doesn't feel like a playing a reskin of the British, or vice versa. For the "European Civs" (I put that in quotes because while the Ottoman Turks are not from Europe at all, they play like one of the other European civs), that diversity is actually rather subtle, with each civ having one or two units totally unique to them, as well as a couple semi-universal units that are their "Best Units", which get special high-tier upgrades. For example, while the Spanish get Hussars, like the British, the British can upgrade them to "Kingsguard" Hussars, while the Spanish just get regular "Guard" Hussars. The distinction is rather intuitive; basically, if a unit gets a special name once it hits its second upgrade, it'll be better in some way than a unit that doesn't. In this way, the European civs harken back, somewhat, to Age of Empires II, which had each civ only have one or two unique units. On the other hand, each of the Native American and Asian civs are completely different, with entirely different units and even different mechanics, and which units each civ is best with is fairly obvious a few minutes into playing them. The diversity is further enhanced with mercenary units available from the home city and native american units from trading posts.

Good story campaigns: I can't quite make this point without clarification. The first three campaigns were not that great. Those were the pre-expansion ones, and frankly, the series had really stopped working out those storytelling muscles it had in Age of Empires II. The action often felt disjointed and rushed, with the endings of each of the three campaigns being the only bits that seemed to matter or have any impact. However, all of that said, the latter five campaigns were actually quite good, especially if you could disengage them from the taint of their predecessors in terms of tropes and pacing. In addition, the characters personal struggles in the latter five campaigns were more apparent, their inner struggles seemed to mean so much more. Really, if you want a great story, the latter five campaigns are pretty damn good.

Good* Mechanics: This game has some rather... mixed mechanics. I'll get to the bad later, but for now, the good news! The home city is the big thing that was touted on release, and frankly, I like the concept a lot. It allows a player to gain advantages specific to their strategy, whether it be resource gathering, naval dominance, or raw military power. Essentially, the way the Home City works is that the player assigns cards to a deck, each card representing a batch of units or an upgrade or some resources. When a home city shipment is available in game, the player selects one of the cards they've assigned, and after a brief waiting period (Hey, it takes time to get a Declaration to Claim the New World overseas. Cut them some slack.), the units, tech, etc. arrives. In addition to this as one of the primary mechanics, you've got your normal suite of resource gathering (done with villager-type units) and military unit production. An interesting nuance of the unit production here is that when you've got a military building selected, let's say, the Barracks, and let's say you want to train a sqaud of Musketeers. You can shift-click the unit portrait to train five at once. While this may not seem novel by itself; a few games already allow this sort of thing, the novel thing is that doing it this way makes the waiting period for your units slightly longer, but you get all five units at once. The Russians and Chinese have this as their primary mechanic, with the Russians training "blocks" of infantry, and the Chinese creating "Banner Armies" which are groups of various unit combinations. Overall, the mechanics are decent in most respects. In addition, the game very cleverly and subtley hampers rushing, which was a brutal, and often severely effective tactic in Age of Empires II, by making it so that the player cannot send units from the home city, or even train them, until the second technological era. I hardly ever notice that my efforts at building an army are being hampered by this restriction, but when I do notice it, I am appreciative of the clever design choice.

Bad points of Age of Empires III:

Bad* Mechanics: As I said, this game has some mixed mechanics. Now we come to the bad. The primary problem we have here is that while the home city, is in concept, a nice idea with some potential for strategic use, it seems best used as a rush enabler. Earlier, I mentioned that the game restricts rushing by limiting military units to the second age and following. But the home city can easily be stocked with military unit shipments so that come second era, you can get an entire army, virtually free of charge. Here's a hot tip for those cheese players out there: Get the best second-era military unit shipments you can. Then, in game, save up your shipments. Once you get to age II, build a Church. Then research Mercantilism, which gets you around 3 shipments for 1,000 Coin. Then, in essence, spawn a horde of troops. Admittedly, this really only works for the European civs, but the overwhelming potential for early-midgame rush is still somewhat staggering, and it means that some of the more interesting home city shipments may not ever see play. In addition, many games, it seems, are decided well before the final technological era. The reasons for this are two-fold: A) Reaching that final era and researching all the upgrades is simply prohibitively expensive, and B) It just makes more sense to strike your enemy before then, fatally, if possible. This makes the late-game content feel a little unnecessary, as you're probably already winning if you can research that final era, and if you're not winning, spending 4,000 food and coin isn't going to make things that much better. The game does mitigate this somewhat, by having a "Revolution" feature, an alternative to the final age-up, which turns all your villager-type units into militia-type units, and also gives you a plethora of new military options for your civ. However, if you're far ahead enough that you can forgo economy entirely, than you probably don't need the feature anyway. Also, it's only available to European civs, so the final age cost problem is still relevant to Asian and Native American civs. Also, unit counters and stats can be difficult to wrap one's head around, as the developers saw fit to give the player the literal math used to determine unit stats. For example, I believe the movement speed for the average footsoldier was 7.25. Not 7, not 8, but a fraction, 7.25. While this may not seem like a major issue, throwing numbers like that at a player makes the game feel less than polished, and also degrades the meaning of the numbers themselves. 7.25 what? And what does it mean when my Musketeer deals 8 damage, but the Hussar it's attacking has 0.20 armor? Does it deflect 0.20 damage? Or 20% damage? The game doesn't tell you, meaning you'll have to examine the numbers closely to determine exact impact of your units against your opponents.

Anachronism: While I will be the first to admit that anachronism in a strategy game isn't that huge an issue, and is in fact, almost to be expected in these kinds of games, the situation here is rather glaring. Granted, the problem is bigger in the first three story campaigns, and I wouldn't mind it quite so much if it were restricted to the game itself only. But c'mon. Having Revolutionary War era musketeers accompany Amelia Black, a railroad owner? And having them in full garb in cutscene? That's the sort of thing that stretches disbelief to the breaking point, and was one of the reasons that those campaigns did not match the quality of the latter five.

[h1]Pointless nostalgic intro[/h1]

Back in 2005, when AoE III was released, I'd already been playing the 2nd for several years. Being an amateur and enthusiast of medieval warfare, the period of time didn't seem too appealing to me. Moreover, I was so used to the iconic 2D graphics of the first 2 AoE titles, that I couldn't join yet the revolution Age of Mythology had started some time earlier.

Then, I found a torrent for the vanilla plus TWC somewhere in 2009 or '10 and it didn't took a while before I developed a passion for the game. But enough of my personal history and feelings with the game's series.

[h1]Actual review and rating[/h1]

I rate the whole expanded game [b]8/10[/b]*. If I were you I would wonder [i]what's wrong with the game so that you didn't rate it 10/10?[/i] The main reason I didn't entirely like AoE III was:

-Lack of deep european theatre
Which subsequently implies the game lacks the following content (more or less):

-European maps and respective natives [i](local inhabitants that commonly formed regional cultures)[/i]
-European conflicts within Europe [i](like the Napoleonic Wars)[/i]
-European major factions/civilisations like the Austrians, the Swede, the Poles, the HRE, and so on
-European "minor" factions between which most of the mentioned-above conflicts occured [i](e.g. the thirty years' war?)[/i]
-I could go on for ages

*I rate the vanilla [b]7/10[/b], and Asian Dynasties [b]9/10[/b]. I liked the accuracy and dedication towards the Asian cultures and peoples, perhaps the crappiest part was that they didn't bother changing the town noise and sounds at all. I cannot say anything about the Warchiefs because I played the native factions very little and am myself not-so experienced with [i](post-colonisation)[/i] north and mesoamerican civilisations.

Many by now are probably already thinking that the review is pointless because "muh europe", but hey, we successfully founded the first advanced civilisations, kingdoms and later empires - ultimately colonising the world. So, whether you like that or not it's history, and we're a large part of it.

Anyway, if you want to know how good the game is, just read older and more rated reviews. I can simply tell you that if you're looking after a traditional RTS set right after the middle ages until the beginning of the 19th century, you won't be disappointed at all. 

In case you agree with me on the lack of the European content, I highly recommend you install the [b][url=www.ne.elpea.net/forum/portal.php]Napoleonic Era mod[/url][/b]. It adds some 5/6 factions and a bunch of units, maps, etc. It also has a small online community.

Simply the best RTS right now. What I like about it:

A fine installation in the Age of Empires series that has a greater emphasis on combat as well as teaching you about things other than human resource management and medieval history lessons. Instead, you will gain a deep knowledge of zoology and learn how to beat up people and steal their stuff.

General:
>Zoology Lessons – Some things you will learn: Capybaras and tapirs live in Central and South America, Ibex, Saigas, and Marco Polo sheeps live in central Asia, Serows live in Japan and the rest of Asia.
>Japanese Daimyos can materialize samurai out of thin air.
>Shogun Tokugawa is a wizard that can open portals to other worlds and summon the likes of monks with clubs, shinobi that shoot grenades using their bows, and entire artillery companies.
>The original American Continental Marines were an army of Japanese Ronin Samurai mercenaries.
>If you throw a lot of torches into a building, it will not burn. However, it will break apart and then finally explode.
>Native American fire pit dances generate magic that they put to use in battle, putting Warcraft spellcasters to shame.
>Medicine men, surgeons, and priests all perform the same healing magic.
>Even standing near an idle monster truck could be lethal.
>Even before the creation of the United States, George Washington always knew he’d end up on both the quarter and the dollar bill.
>As an Asian power, you can ally with your enemy through the consulate… and still wage war with their forces with soldiers from their own home country.
>Chinese flamethrowers never burn anything, they just kill it and blow it up.
>The British employed the use of longbowmen well into the 1800s.
>Cuauhtemoc of the Aztecs is a cool guy; he has a blood fetish and refers to himself in third person.
>Queen Isabella so desperate, she’ll sleep with Cuauhtemoc
>Akbar of the Indians is worse than a fervent Jehovah’s Mormon as he constantly attempts to convert you to his religion (Hinduism) while beating him up. On the bright side, he can’t nuke you like Gandhi.
>Russian strelets are a gift from the Aztec blood gods.
>Russian strelets are equipped with large foam axes and airsoft muskets.
>Created an Iroquois home city called Toronto, named the warchief Rob Ford. He smoked crack, befriended blowgunners and blew up his own city.
>As another reviewer simply noted, you can beat up monkeys and steal their money.
>The Haitians hoped that their new ironclad warships would be their knights in shining armor. They turned out to be their morons in aluminum foil.
>The story of the original Thanksgiving is full of lies, propagated by the capitalist pigs in Washington. The true story goes as follows. In 1603, Shogun Tokugawa wanted to construct a new shogunate palace. He sent a group of Japanese pilgrims across the ocean. A few years later, they landed on Plymouth in New England, an excellent place for a new shogunate palace. There, they befriended a native scout and his pet intrepid scout turkey. Shortly thereafter, a group of allied Chinese pilgrims came ashore and set up shop alongside them. The Japanese and Chinese came together for a great turkey dinner. HOWEVER… The French and the Ottomans landed around the same time and did not take kindly to what they saw as encroachment upon their lands. A great war ensued in which the Chinese and Japanese ultimately prevailed. In the end, a great Thanksgiving feast was held in the new shogunate palace with Tokugawa as the host.

>SPECIAL EDIT: Indestructable outposts
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fZbC69DS_D0

Civilizations:
>You can beat up the British and steal their tea.
>You can beat up the French and steal their military victories.
>You can beat up the Dutch and steal their tulips.
>You can beat up the Portuguese and steal their secret liquor.
>You can beat up the Spanish and steal their dogs.
>You can beat up the Germans and steal their beer.
>You can beat up the Ottoman Turks and steal their turkey.
>You can beat up the Russians and steal their vodka.
>You can beat up the Iroquois and steal Hiawatha’s poetry.
>You can beat up the Sioux and steal Gall’s gallbladder.	
>You can beat up the Aztecs and steal their bottled blood.
>You can play as the Japanese and steal your allies’ food.
>You can beat up the Chinese and steal their many inventions and claim them as your own.
>You can beat up the Indians and steal their elephants and then beat up their sacred cows.

Campaigns:
The campaigns of the base game and The Warchiefs expansion provide an interesting story that follows the Blacks, a family of mostly brutal dark magic thieves. They can create entire armies and civilizations that a can appear and disappear within an hour. However, they end up being known and portrayed as heroes as they more often than not beat up bad guys and steal their stuff. The Asian Dynasties have similar stories but are completely unrelated to the Black Family.

Blood – As Morgan Black,
>Beat up the Ottomans and steal their cannons.
>Beat up pirates and steal their maps.
>Beat up the Spanish and steal their money.
>Beat up the Knight’s Templar and steal their water.

Ice – As John Black,
>Mock your uncle Stuart’s lack of masculinity despite the fact that he packs the most powerful right hook punch in the entire New World.
>Beat up the Cherokee and steal their cannons.
>Beat up the rogue British and steal back your damsel-in-distress girlfriend Nonahkee.
>Pursue a rogue British general across North America with a fleet of monster trucks.
>Finally, blow yourself up and prevent the Knight’s Templar from leading a Russian invasion of America.

Fire – As Nathaniel Black,
>Beat up the British and steal their colonies.
>Beat up the Hessians and steal back your damsel-in-distress mother Nonahkee.
>Win the Revolutionary War with giant stone busts of George Washington that crush and trample entire armies. 
>Level the British forts at Yorktown with these colonial titans while they proclaim, “Check in your wallet. That’s me on the dollar bill.”

Steel – As Amelia Black,
>Beat up rival companies and steal their railroads.
>Beat up the Sioux and steal their land.
>Beat up the Knight’s Templar and steal their money.

Shadow – As Chayton Black,
>Beat up the Sioux again and steal their land.
>Beat up a Civil War veteran and steal his money.
>Beat up General George Armstrong Custer and steal his mullet.

(Asian Dynasties)
Japan – As General Kinchiro (Batman),
>Beat up Japanese daimyos and steal their land.
>Note: The Japanese can run mid-19th century steam trains in the early-17th century.

China – As Captain Huang, 
>Beat up pirates, Indians, and Aztecs with your shirtless partner Lao Chen, and then completely cover up your presence.

India – As a sepoy named Nabir,
>Beat up your own countrymen and steal everything they have.
>Shoot your commanding officer’s bodyguard and just walk away.
>Beat up the British and steal their saltpeter.
>Beat up the British and steal back your elephants.

11/10. If you don’t have the money to buy this game, beat up someone and steal their money.

Age of Empires 3. An amazing RTS taking place in the "New World" during the colonial age. Great game play that keeps you entertained for hours, continuously coming back wanting more!

Pros:
-Great game play, keeping you entertained for hours. 
-Has funny and entertaining cheats, like "tuck tuck tuck" which allows you to spawn in a huge monster truck. That will drive over anyone or anything, creating global havoc. 
-Has a large supply of maps, each map making you have to adjust your strategic plans to win. 
-You get all the DLC's, adds more to the game, civilizations, maps and more!

Cons:
-Dying online community and online support, servers can get high amounts of lag. Servers will go offline sometimes even for an entire day. 
-Franchise has been disbanded, meaning no more support. No updates, no fixing current glitches. 
-Population cap reaches only 200, meaning that your stuck fighting smaller battles. 

I would purchase this game on sale, it's worth to get the game. Just not at full price.
Overall I will give an overall positive review: 8.3/10

I've had this game and previous titles in the series since the discovery age (pun intended) but was unable to play multiplayer until i purchased it on steam, the multiplayer is so much more in depth and unexpected than single player. 

The only 2 things that annoy me and they REALLY annoy me is that, It takes a very long time to find opponents using "quick" search which i guess can be explained by the small playerbase, and in game browser you will always end up with at least 1 pro on your team or the enmy which will single handedly win the game for that team, even if you change the title of the lobby to something like "noobs only" some dickhead will still join. The other annoyance is that if one person is lagging either due to low FPS or bad internet all players will lag to the same extent or even more, which is very frustrating to experience with a high end system and good internet.

Overall  I would recommend if you have played the singleplayer enough and want to play multiplayer, and think you are good enough to not be smashed by the pros, i would not buy for the singleplayer aspect though as the campaign is quick and the skirmish with bots get's repetitive fairly quickly.

A classic RTS game which strikes a great balance between base building and combat. The homecity which allows players to ship resources, units and upgrades encourages fast gameplay and adaptation, sometimes to the point that a shipment can change the entire outcome of a game in a matter of a few seconds. This is an RTS which uses random maps, which greatly adds to the replay value of the game, since map spawn is unpredictable and players have to scout and adapt their strategy accordingly. Despite its age, Age of Empires III still boasts great-looking graphics on the highest settings, which can make for a great gaming experience on maps with a natural setting. The game has a good support for input customisation, allowing players to hotkey unit control in many ways and provides rich realtime statistics for each selected unit and groups.
14 civilisations, including the two expansion packs (with Native and Asian civilisations), more than two thousand units, including combat units, buildings and nature stuff, create a realistic and very diverse world for anyone who wants to prove and improve their strategy skills.
