Its Age of Empires. Come on. What more could you want?
Admittedly, it is a lot different from the first 2 Age of Empires that were developed by ensemble, which did have their own special charm. Age of Empires 3 feels different, but once you get into it you can completely tell that they're one of the same. I love this game for many reasons. You can play a little of each civilization and choose which is your favorite. They all have a different playstyle and personally my favorite is the Ottomans because of their free villagers. I also like them because their units look incredibly Bad A- in a formation. 50 Janissaries. 25 abus guns, some gardeners and great bombards marching toward the enemy base is a sight to behold. 

Anyways, if you've played any of the past Age of Empires games and enjoyed them, or just plain love strategy or war games, then please for the sake of all that is good - get this game. I would advise you to go into this experience with a friend. Yes, single player skirmish does get a little stale. With a friend however, it becomes a LOT more fun. 

Some things that I LIKE about this game:
Home city cards (Come on, who doesnt love these?)
Civilization bonuses (Much more variety compared to Age of Empires 2)
Unique units (Units that arent a copy+paste like the common musketeer)
Trading posts (Hell yes.. upgrade to train and you're in business baby... just remember to defend them)
The music (Seriously, go check it out yourself. I hum along to the menu theme a lot)
Tons of mods ( Ill talk about that later)


Some things that I DONT like about this game:
They've removed the "patrol" option that everyone loved in Age of Empires 2
You cant rotate buildings
AI gets a little stupid now and then. (Mortar ships trying to fire at shore and cant find a "comfortable" position to fire from)
Getting the game to run for some systems has been troublesome. 
Mercenaries (In my opinion, they could have spent more time developing more unique units for every civilization rather than these. I rarely ever use them.)
Wood is a pain in the arse (If i ever have economy problems, its always because theres a shortage of wood)
The Japanese are a tad overpowered. (Not only in military but in my opinion they have incredible advantages in economy as well) 

Most of the things I dont like in the game are actually solved with some mods, in particular, the Improvement mod by Mandos. I can't begin to address how much that mod makes a great game into a spectacular game. Things such as improved AI. Theres also little things like adding your civilizatons icon to your ship's sails (Love that) and even damage being dealt to units who get run over by the trade route caravan. (You didnt think you could get away with a train running you over, did you?). Theres an entire page of improvements in this mod and none of them are detrimental to the gameplay at all, in my opinion. If you dont like it, you can just uninstall it. 

This mod isnt at all necessary for this game to be great on its own, however.
It's old, but its fantastic. The campaign story is great, and you get the war chiefs and asian dynasties to go with the original. If you're considering buying this game, look no further.

They should call this Age of Empires Not. I've always liked Microsoft Games Division because they made quality games. I've been an AoE player as long as I can remember, but this is not AoE. Here's why.

Someone in a meeting during the development of this game, who has obviously never played the game,  must have raised their hand and said these 10 Things;

1. Hey, you know that scenario creator thing? No one really uses that, and the ones that do really don't like it being so easy to use. So let's make one that's much harder to use. 

2. Let's don't let them save game when testing a scenario so it can be played as a game later. No one does that. 

3. And those random maps? Ah, you know they don't use that so let's take that out too. 

4. When selecting an AI, instead of just selecting one for the computer, let's make them also place objects in the game to make it actually work.

5. And here's something really fun to them. When they create a scenario and choose human for player 1, computer for all the other empires, and select AI's for the computer players, here comes the fun part; When they go to play the scenario, we'll switch them from player 1 to another player instead. They'll find that really funny!

6. And you know those formations that you could use in older versions of AoE? I don't think anyone uses that. Let's remove that.

7. Patrols? Why would they want their troops to patrol? Nah. Take that out too.

8. And you know those towers? People build way too many of them. No one needs more than 7, so let's put a limit on them. Even if one player gathers more resources, they shouldn't be allowed to build unlimited towers. No one should ever build more than 7 in my opinion and people should play it the way I would play it, not just any way they want to.

9. Same with Ships. They shouldn't build so many, so let's limit that too.

10. Oh and this one is real important. Players used to have the ability to place waypoints from their barracks, stables, etc. at an enemy location and fill the queue with 15 troops from each one and if it was more than the population limit, they wouldn't be made until the pop fell below the limit. Instead, in the new AoE, let's not let them schedule those troops in advance. If they want reinforcements, make them go back and do that during the attack so the other player gets a break.

Those aren't all of the problems with the new AoE compared to the excellent older AoE versions, so other people who never played the game must have also raised their hands too.

Age of Empires III: Complete Collection is a real-time strategy game from Ensemble Studios and published by to what now Microsoft Studios. It is a sequel to the Age of Empires franchise. Age of Empires III: Complete Collection also contains both expansion packs from Age of Empire III.

Age of Empires III saw many improvements and feature upgrades in term of gameplay while retaining the unique play of Age of Empires series. Many new features included are the new home city and card deck. Card deck allows you to call many abilities such as reinforcements of units, resources delivery, unique upgrades delivery and many more from home city to your new colony. Age of Empires III takes place in the new world of America. You will be seeing units such as the Musketeer, Dragoon, Minuteman and many cannons. Another new features added here is a trade post. Trade post can be built on trade routes or local tribes such as the Aztec to gain their allegiance and lets you train their unique units.

Graphics in Age of Empires III is definitely far better improved and upgraded than the previous Age of Empires, far better effects, models and textures, shaders, everything is beautiful and fully detailed in this game. Performance is also great, no issues that can ruin your play.

Seeing that many Microsoft games such as the Age of Empires II or Age of Mythology has been upgraded with Steamworks feature, Age of Empire III should see that support too, since this is the latest Age of Empire series.

Age of Empire III: Complete Collection is a great game to play, I recommend this.

It should be known by now that I've been a fan of the Age games from way back. There's just something about the historical nature of the games that appeals to me. To be fair, I think elves and space marines are neat too, but I think it's more exciting to explore the what ifs of real, historical situations. Though not quite as faithful to "reality" as some strategy games, the first two Age games offered us exciting sojourns into the worlds of "capital A" Ancient and Medieval strategy. The third title, Age of Mythology, proved that the mechanics were just as solid even if the historical inspiration was a little loose.

Now Ensemble is back on the history train with the third official Age of Empires game. Age of Empires III moves the action to the New World, letting players lead a variety of European nations from the Age of Discovery through the Industrial Age. Eight playable nations battle across a wide variety of geographies -- from the swamps of Florida to the snowy passes of the Rocky Mountains. Players can recruit different Native American tribes and seize control of various trade routes. Material and technological support will be offered by the player's home city back in Europe.

The 24-mission campaign is very well designed. Divided into three large acts, it tells the story of three generations of the Black family. First Morgan Black, a Knight of St. John races to the New World to stop the Spanish from seizing a powerful natural wonder. Next, Morgan's grandson John and his Native American allies find themselves in the Seven Year's War. The final act shows John's granddaughter Amelia as the head of a railroad company making their way west.

I won't spoil the particulars of the story here but a common quest and a common enemy unite all three acts. The connections aren't always clear at first, but the associations start to build as the game goes on. Putting the pieces together isn't terribly hard but it gives a nice sense of purpose to the whole game and keeps you invested in the action.

While we're talking about the game's story, it's refreshing to see a game that covers this era of warfare without referencing either Napoleon or the American Revolution. While both are fertile ground for strategy game developers, it's nice to get something a little different this time around. Meeting Washington and Bolivar and taking part in the Seven Year's War adds a little authenticity as well as variety. On the other hand, some of the choices -- like finding Russians in Colorado -- may leave gamers scratching their heads in wonder.

The range of missions is pretty broad. There are plenty of defense missions where you have to protect a given structure or a whole town from enemy assault. In other cases you'll have to destroy or capture key structures. Along the way there are plenty of other objectives: rescuing captured settlers, seizing trading posts, liberating Native American settlements and a whole host of other tasks. Better still, many missions combine a variety of these objectives at once. While most of the missions let you build a base and start collecting resources, there are some missions where you have to make do with a set number of troops.

Outside of the single player campaign, Age of Empires III benefits from a very soild multiplayer interface. A few simple clicks take you to ESO2, Ensemble's online matchmaking service. Finding and joining games is remarkably easy and there are a wide variety of options to choose from. Different starting eras and resource levels will let players jump into as advanced a game as they want. The AI offers up a few taunts from time to time to (sort of) replicate the personality of a human player. It's a nice trick honestly.

In general the AI is very strong. You can find some exploits here and there but, for the most part, the AI knows how to make a good army and how to lead it. While the computer opponents in some RTS games send out trickles of units from time to time in order to keep things interesting, the AI in Age of Empires III tends to rely more on groups of units and will hardly ever use them in pointless, suicide attacks. In my games the AI has had a good handle on when to press an attack and when to retreat. The only real weak point in the AI is its tendency to leave some of its settlers too isolated. (Since there are no resource dropsites anymore, it's also hard for human players to keep tabs on where all their settlers are.)

The range of technologies and units is relatively broad here. In the early ages, players will have to make do with troops that are very similar to the medieval set from Age of Empires II. Crossbows eventually give way to muskets as the ages pass by. Soon players will be fielding long lines of musketeers and using mortars to bombard enemy towers. While it may seem that some of the unit types are redundant, you'll find that each type has a specific role to play on the battlefield. Like the other Age games you'll have a variety of ranged and melee-focused cavalry and infantry as well as a nice range of artillery units. Identifying the counter units and building a balanced force is just as important as knowing where and when to strike the enemy.

Like the rest of the games in the Age series, the naval element is merely there to support the land battles. The handful of ships and maritime technologies don't offer many options. You will find that the naval side of the game is fairly compelling early on while you're dealing with pirates and chasing your enemies across the Atlantic. Once you start fighting in the interior of the American continent, you won't really miss the naval aspect of the game as much.

Pathfinding seems to be a bit of a problem here and there. Huge formations can easily find their way through the most densely packed settlements but my one hero unit can't seem to find his way out of the middle of a line of infantry. There are cases where the pathfinding is a little too good. Units are able to predict the best routes through a maze even when large parts of that maze haven't been uncovered yet. This is most telling during missions where you're leading a small force through a series of winding canyons. As long as you click on their eventual destination, they'll make their way through the labyrinth with nary a wrong turn.

While we're on the subject, it seems odd that you can't select a single unit out of a group by clicking on their portrait at the bottom of the screen. Trying to grab a specific hero unit out of a large formation should be easier than this. Luckily, there's an option in the game to disregard any non-combat units when you click and drag to select a group. This helps to keep your settlers from marching out with your soldiers.

Age of Empires III also introduces some new elements -- home cities, native tribes, trade routes and such. Taken individually none of these are profound innovations but their cumulative effect makes the game feel fresh and strengthens the appeal of the core design. So in total of this review, I recommend this game to anyone who loves RTS Games.

Why I bought the game: Wishlist game / -66% off coupon. Researching more RTS games I took a chance on this one, and do not regret it. 

What I liked about the game: I was 5 years late playing this game, but I am an avid RTS fan. It has all the elements of a great RTS, unique buildings to each ruler, gathering and maintaining resources, upgrading units, and strategizing your victory. It reminded me of the old school Command and Conquer games, having a Special unit, and unique to each ruler, or province. The graphics for a dated game are pleasing to the eye, I recommend if you're using an up to date monitor to set the game to use minimal UI, and also adjust your zoom out for further away.

You start with Settlers, you build a town, you set up trade routes with local natives, you build defensive structures, and walls. You gather supply, and experience to unlock more upgrades, you conquer your opponite via land, or sea. What sets it apart is the sense of exploration you get on the maps, finding treasure, and fighting for trade areas can be a whole other strategy. 

What i've completed of the campaign I am enjoying, I am playing on medium and have had to restart a few times, the game is not forgiving of mistakes, but learning and adapting is why i love RTS. 

What I didn't like about the game: There is quite a bit of noise notification as default in the game, during battle it can sound like a trumpet battle.

Would I buy at current asking price of 39.99? No, and I waited forever for this to go on sale, it was awesome to unlock a badge and get the -66% off coupon, today I see it is on sale -75% off for spring sale, very worth it, and I will be keeping this one installed!

If you haven't heard of Age of Empires, then say hello to one of the most iconic RTS franchises. With the release of Age of Empires 2 HD Edition, there's quite a bit to go around for fans of the franchise. But enough about that, how is Age of Empire 3?

Well it really depends on what you're after. Visually, it's still pretty freaking gorgeous, and it holds up quite well, though it does show its age a bit (what do you expect for an 9 year old game). the lighting effects are great, and the smoke and particle effects, especially the destructible debris that falls of buildings is a nice visual treat, and I remember how amazing it looked back in 2005, and to me it still looks great.

In terms of gameplay, it feels more in line with Age of Mythology, Ensemble's previous entry, rather than Age of Empires. From the way you choose a leader each age (mirrors choosing minor deities in Age of Mythology) to general UI layout and control schemes, AoE3 feels much like a spiritual successor to Age of Mythology, with a focus on historics rather than mythos. 

Though with this iteration of the series,  there are new, much needed improvements. Gone is the need for a drop off point for your workers; like the Atlantean race in AoM:TT (Age of Mythology: The Titans), your workers only need to mine from the resource to generate that resource. This makes macromangement considerably less fiddly. 

Another change is how Caravans work in AoE3; instead of building a market, creating some caravans, and sending them to a Town Centre, there are now neutral Trading Posts that need to capture, which provide a steady steam of either Wood, Gold, Food or Experience. There are other neutral buildings the map, such as native settlements, or saloons which give you access to new units. 

But by far the biggest addition to the series is the Home City. The Home City has a deck of shipment cards which can be sent to you during the game, depending on how many levels you gain through experience (gained by fighting, find treasure, building or from aforementioned trade caravans). The shipments can range from dozens of cavalry soldiers, supplies of wood/gold/food,  to permanent improvements to military, defense, economy and so on. It can change how you play, and it's an interesting additon to the game.

The singleplayer in the Complete Collection offers up plenty of content, with about 8 campaigns, ranging from 15th/16th Century colonials to Battle at Little Bighorn, to the Indian Revolution, and even a little bit in Japan during the Sengoku period. It has plenty of nicely realised characters, interesting stories for each campaign, and enough content for each campaign so they don't feel short. This along with the 14 civilizations you can play in singleplayer (and multiplayer, though there isnt much of a population) skirmishes means plenty of content for your money's worth. 

If you're new to the Age of Empires franchise or if you enjoyed Age of Mythology, then Age of Empires 3 will be a fun ride through some events through history. If you preferred Age of Empires 2, then you might not like Age of Empires 3 quite as much. For me though, its a hearty recommendation.

Well, a third part for Age of Empires. What to expect of it?

If you have never played the first two parts of AoE, here you'll get a little summary: Age of Empires I and II were defining new standards for the RTS-genre when they came out. Not as fast-paced as Starcraft or WarCraft, but with more strategical Depth and more focus on the organization of your camp and with a build-in history-part wich made the game even a little educational without decreasing the fun of the gameplay. You always could choose from many different cultures which had some units and technology in common, but some unique units and cultural advantages and disadvantages.

Now, what is different in AoE III?
First of all, after AoE I playing in antique times and AoE II playing in Medieval times up to the discovery of the new world, AoE III consequently plays in times of the colonization of America and the civil war. Like AoE I & II, AoE III contains many true historical events, locations and persons, but unlike both prequels, the main storyline of the campaigns is highly fictional so that it might be difficult to tell which events in the game truely happend and which are made up. The main storyline of the campaign is about a sect which tries to find and conquer the fountain of youth in the new world and a family which is bound by fate to stop them. On their journeys they encounter many historical persons like Georg Washington or Bolivar, but most of the game is about hunting down the sect. So the game is far less educational then the previous ones.

The second big difference is that the cultures do not longer have most techs and units in common but every nation has their own tech tree. Some things of course still are open to every culture but the differences between the cultures are far bigger then before. This isn't much of a problem because you can still tell the strengths and weaknesses of an unfimilar unit very fast, but it is more difficult then before to play a new nation.

And the there are the RPG-elements. Not only do you have imortal hero-units (like in Age of Mythology) which can only be knocked unconscious and stand up again if no more enemy units are around, you will also play random maps with a "hometown" which can level up between games and send you support if you collect enough experience by surviving a certain time, killing enemy units or building your camp. Although this may increase the motivation to play more random maps they removed the option to play a random culture, which I really loved in AoE I & II.

The AIs are weaker then in AoE II which is good for beginners but a little disappointing for more expert players. The balancing is also worse. There are some strategies to break the game. A pack of at least 20 osman heavy bombards, for example, is almost invincible. No AI-player ever was able to beat me if I got that far.

With the complete Collection, you will also get the two Add-Ons: The War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties.

The War Chiefs adds playable Native American Tribes (Without this Add-On they are only available as some sort of mercenaries if you build trading posts near their villages witch appear randomly on random maps). Although playing a native american culture is a very wellcome change and a challenge, it is clearly unbalanced. Those cultures are given many new and unique techniques like sending settlers to a totem and dance to do rites which give you advantages like faster ressources or stronger soldiers, they still desperatly lack heavy siege weaponary. Native american soldiers are only strong in large nummers and will have to attack early to not get overwhelmed by superior firepower of other nations.
The Add-On also adds two campaigns which complete the storyline of the original game campaign by filling gaps and finishing the somehow open story. The focus, of course, is more on the war of the native americans against the europeans and so it is no true surprise that you will have to face general Custer at wounded Knee. Still the two new campaigns are much more shallow...

The Asian Dynasties finally adds some civilizations from Asia like the Indians and the Chinese. The storyline of the new campaigns has nothing to do with the story of the original campaign. The Indian campaign for example takes place around the fight for independence in India and the chinese campaign describes the discovery of the american continent by a chinese admiral which might have taken place (or maybe not) long before Columbus was born.

Overall AoE III: Complete Collection is a decent RTS game with some unique features, but if you were a big fan of AoE I & II you might be disappointed because it is a really different game then what you are used to. Still it is worth a try.
If you have never played AoE I or II, but you like RTS games, you should definitly try this one.

[h1]Awesome game, but...[/h1]
I have spent a couple hundred hours playing this game over the past decade. It is an extremely fun and challenging title. However, there is one problem that has [b]never[/b] been fixed. When you play with 4+ computer opponents on anything higher than normal difficulty, the game becomes unplayable and crashes. Unlike AoE2, you [b]cannot[/b] save your game, likely due to being hosted through ESO. Let me stop you before you are quick to blame the users. My friends all have very good internet (100-1000Mbps minimum) and great latency. We also use high performance gaming rigs, so it is definitely [b]not[/b] on our end. 
As you start to become a better player and seek a harder challenge, you naturally want to increase the difficulty/players. This, however, hits a plateau with AoE3, so you are forced to cut yourself short.
It is still a great RTS and we enjoy playing it, just wish this problem didn't exist.

*Note: I have very little time played on my Steam version of this game, but have played around 80 - 100 hours on the disc version.*

Age of Empires III incorporates an awesome New England settings rendered in amazing graphics. The combat is more intense, more diverse, and much more realistic than that of the original two Age of Empires games, which were already great. The interface has been updated and greatly improved (only three resources allow for a smoother process of building and running your civilation). 

The game has many great new features, including:
-use of a "home city", a city you customize and level up through battle, that serves as your main menu and gives rewards
-ability to train troops in groups of five, instead of individually
-random capturable treasures scattered around the map that give unique bonuses
-more realistic battle (soldiers burn buildings instead of hit them, cannonballs knock down trees, ships sink, etc)
-awesome revamped naval combat. Limited fleet size allow more tactical fighting strategies
-unit special abilities. these vary greatly, providing a single powerful shot, treasure gaurdian taming, stealth, etc.
-ability to build trade posts to ally with native americans, providing unique/powerful upgrades and native units
-use of limited and highly-profitable trade posts along a railroad, which are visciously fought over
-unique use of ability cards, picked outside of battle, and used during game for special advantages
-highly diverse wild animals to fight, hunt, and tame. Tamable ones includes wolves, coyotes, bears, cougars, and more.
-interesting and useful incorporation of time-period features, including minute-men, trains, native allies, and more.
-addition of artillery units (various cannons) that add a unique element to combat
-(with Asian Dynasties expansion) ability to play as one of three native American tribes (Sioux, Aztec, and one other)


Things I do not like about this game:
-population size still limited to 200 units
-artillery is a bit overpowered (specifically anti-infantry artillery, though it is more realistic that way)

In short, if you are a fan of the original two AoE games, love historical time period-set war games, like strategy combat, or just want to have some great fun on an amazingly underrated and easy-to-learn game, buy Age of Empires III now. And while you're at it, the expansions are great and well worth the money.

Don't buy this game for it's name. Actually, it's a shame for the outstanding AoE franchise.

AoE III is a wonderful game, with good graphics and enough in-game possibilities (i'm talking about buildings and characters), but it lacks the supremacy of AoE II and AoE.

This game looks like the developers wanted to make a game that would ressemble the very first Empire Earth. Well, it doesn't. 

- Remember that awesome feeling in AoE II and EE when changing the map size to 'gigantic' and you had no idea where to start exploring first? You won't find it here. According to me, this game stands or falls with the scale of its maps.
- Also a big fail is the building-aspect. You don't have the feeling, when building your houses and military buildings, that you're constructing a city. After putting your, let's say 20, buildings close to each other and in an structurised manner, it looks like a mismatched slum of the 14th century which you want to put on fire. I know, some of you will say: 'Oy, AoE isn't about building, it's the fighting that counts!' And i'll even say they're correct. But be honest with yourselves, it's the whole that counts, isn't it?
- Another, rather 'stupid', improvement is the fact that in-game you have the possibility to make your homecountry deliver supplies (troops, food and villagers). Seriously, who gives a damn for this? This makes you feel incompetent for playing this game, since you'll have to 'beg' for help. Not a nice feeling, not?

The lot of you will buy Age of Empires III for the name and because you expect it to be even better than AoE II and EE. But don't be fooled by the name, nor the metacritic score; 
this game isn't worth buying for the full price.

This game, is quite honestly the best game I have ever played. No comparrison to this, no rival to this, NO SUCH THING, as an equal. I Have played this game on the disc, and I lost it. I Bought this game on steam 5 years later to find it was on sale, upon playing it for the first time in half a decade I found a love in this game. The smoothness of the animations, the mighty sea battles, the cries of Crazy horse as he and his men rush crazily into battle, the burning buildings as cannon pelt the cities, the musketeer ranks constantly thudding their feet along the jagged mountain passes, only to find another team has only crushed it already. The game sound good? Of course. I have too much to say for this game, but... Yes, there are bad parts too. THE MULTIPLAYER. But this can be fixed if you just play online with Voobly, of course. The train systems and being able to fight for control over crazy native americans who will fight for you?! Yeah man. You NEED this game, nothing more to be said. The price? The price is nothing. This game is a heaven waiting to be died for. Now, play away! :)

Age of Empires is a terrific series and this particular title only capitalizes on how much fun these stategy games can be. Although smaller in content and map sizes by comparison to the earlier Age of Empires, this game brings more fast-paced and higher quality gameplay, both graphically and mechanically. It's single player campaign is decently fun but I think the 2000 something online community would all agree that the strong suit of this title lays in it's online experience. With the expansion civilizations offered in the complete collection, the game provides countless hours of addicting, competitive online battles with up to 8 players at a time.
Great online-play, good amount of variety, simple gameplay... If you're interested in strategy games or simply want to play online with a small but competitve community, this is a game for you. I highly recommend it.

Age of Empires really needs no explanation. This legendary RTS game is a good relic of a dying genre of videogames. Seriously when was the last time a RTS besides company of heroes came out? Ensemble Studios, the makers of the series. Were shut down by Microsoft a little while back. And even though Microsoft will never revive the studio(or the game series for that matter) We still have this little gem on the Pc. I want to warn you, this game is not for the graphics, the worlds and building models still look reasonably well for 2005. But the rest hasn't aged well. But it does not matter, the campaign is still enjoyable(if not cheesy at times) And the skirmish and multiplayer modes are simple-minded fun.

While not as groundbreaking as it predecessors, AoE3 nevertheless retains much of the what made 1 and 2 great while also implementing new features. Beautiful graphics coupled with a brilliant Home Cities system ensure that AoEIII lives up forever to be one of the better RTS titles in recent times. The Asian Dynasties expansion pack was definitely the real gem in this pack. A major letdown was the absence of historial campaigns which were a staple of 1 and 2. While the story campaigns weren't awful, they bordered on mediocrity and at times, childishly cliche' and odd, trying to desperately interwine historical events/characters into its plot. Ultimately, being a hardcore Age of Empires fan and a hardcore veteran of AoE2 & Mythology, AoE3 still captured my interest as an alternate RTS choice outside of my Starcraft/C&C sessions. 
8.5/10 (Complete Collection), 8/10 - Vanilla, 7/10 - War Chiefs, 9/10 - Asian Dynasties.

Following the successful Age of Empires franchise is AOE III, now wonderfully remastered into one complete pack on Steam. This is a must-get for not just AOE fans, but fans of strategy games in general. Age of Empires III is a strong example of what makes the AOE series a classic in RTS games. From micro to macro-management, housekeeping to empire building, the game is easy to learn yet difficult to master.

The game is set in the 17th thru 19th centuries when European nations expanded their dominions and colonies across the world. On the other side of the globe, Native American civilizations fight to survive or adapt to European incursion, and Asian civilizations cautiously open their borders to a foreign and strange culture. From large musketeer battles to cavalry charges, and artillery blasting away at mortar and brick, the game is a visual delight to relish.

This game does have some good things although I have found that Age of Empires 2 has more to offer than Age of Empires 3.

Reason I would choose AoE2 over AoE3..
- More people to choose
- More structures to build
- Larger maps
- More customizability
- Easier to create things and understand things.
- Better customizable economy (can choose to start with 500 of each resource and work your way up from scratch vs 20k to start)
- Stone resource. (Some may argue this makes it harder and more of a BS resource but at the same time, its not a max out and win game.)
- Stronger structures with more unit specializes.
- More of a story
- A lot more.


Things AoE3 has against AoE2
- Better graphics
- Better UI
- One off screen to choose things to summon in from, "Levels"
- Level up (One hero that you normally need to ransom to get anywhere.)
- If you group someone into group 1 and hold down the 1 button, it doesn't stop the unit dead in its tracks (Until the button is released.)

There was a time when Age of Empires II was all I played. I loved the game. Heck, I even played the DS version. It was one of my all time favorite games. When I was at a friends house, they showed me Age of Empires III, and I thought it looked awesome. It took me a few years before I saw the AOE II and III bundle for sale and bought it. To be honest, I think this is an amazing game. Its as addictive as Age of Empires II and Civilization V (That means you will be spending at least 2 hours straight staring at the computer screen). It also add features that I found to be very useful like cards that can be used to send your colony resources, settlers, and soldiers. Age of Empires is what a sequel should be. A huge leap forward in graphics and adding to the already addictive RTS gameplay. If you like ANY strategy game (This can be as old as Dune or as new as Civilization V), you will enjoy this game.

as a veteran of the RTS genre there are a few words I’d have for this game
lets start with what is good. 
for a game made in 2005 it has very good graphics. And the way buildings fall apart when damaged is very satisfying. There are ALOT of choices for what units to build.
That being said there are far more negatives in my opinion
the controls are clunky at best and hot keys are far from intuitive or fast. The 'cards' add a level of complexity that is completely unnecessary. The units and their counters are so hard that there is almost no point to getting more then the other guy and if you don't have the perfect mix to take him down there is almost no chance to heavily damage his army let alone kill it. Field artillery is far over powered. Workers are absurdly expensive but I suppose that was a balance decision to make up for the fact the resource gathering and macro, if you can call it that, is so simple that it makes where to send your workers to gather minerals in starcraft seam arduous. Factions are far from balanced and not in the good way that promotes a healthy meta game. The computer AI if you can call it that is a joke and needs some serious attention. Battles even when they are at peak seam sluggish or everything is dead before any exchange has happened and micro is almost a joke.
In conclusion. Never buy this game when it's not on sale and your money would be far better spent buying age of empires two and it's expansion for cheaper

[h1]History + action + strategy[/h1]
[b]A bit underrated[/b] if you like history and RTS. Basically, you load up a map, gather resources, build buildings, train armies, etc., etc. Great diversity of nations, tactics and unique units/bldgs/techs.

You can capture trade routes and mini-civs ("villages") on many maps. Easy to customize multi and, when the game's balanced and playing right, it's a thrilling challenge. If you're the creative kind, you can dig into the editor and pretty quickly start creating your own maps, scenarios and cinematics. If you loved Age of Empires 2, this is an easy recommendation. Graphics hold up well - the game still looks gorgeous on a good rig.

I enjoyed AoE II when I was younger and never had a chance to play AoE III. Now that I've played it, I'm not sure the correct lessons were learned from AoE II. 

Pros:
- Generally speaking the tech tree concept is the same
- New units
- Good graphics
- New buildings

Cons:
- Mouse acceleration when scrolling with the edge of the screen. (To be fair, I didn't check if there was a way to turn it off or not)
- Addition of decks (un-necessary new complexity)
- Addition of home cities (what do they do for me?)
- Unit limitation comared to AoE II HD
- Cannons are unwieldy and over powered
- Removal of a resource (stone). Makes the game a bit faster pace, but I miss having to manage resources a little better.

All in all, a fun game once the player comes to terms with the small issues. [b]I will likely play this again. 7/10.[/b]

Genre: Traditional Real Time Strategy with strong historical references

This game does plays like a traditional RTS game. You build a base, units, workers and gather materials and treasures. This game features hero units, mercenary units you can recruit as well as extra supplies that can be shipped in every few minutes. It has a strong historical background and a good amount of story. If you like the older, more traditional RTS style of gameplay this game will please you.

I was bored with the campain, but the diversity of cultures to play from is great. Each one is fun to explore and try out. There are plenty of map types to explore as well. I personally love the range of animals included as well. Personally I found the game difficult, but it keeps me intertained for hours.
This game is fun to play with friends for laughs

Age of Empires III is a pillar of a game in the RTS world. While it has continued to age, even unto antiquity in recent years, it is an excellent game, with some expandable functions to keep players interested. The online multiplayer offers a competitive ladder system, with a broad ranking system. Each campaign is about 3-5 hours of story-driven gameplay, although I find the stories unenthralling. 

I've been playing for years with friends and was pleased to get the Complete Collection recently. The new civilizations and maps offer a good amount of new content, that certainly changed up our playstyles. While we were still getting better and better with our old civilizations, the new ones offer more control and variety in style.

It is a great RTS game for those who want a more casual RTS game that doesn't require a heavy learning curve, this game is honestly what got me into the whole RTS genre of gaming and since pretty much anyone can pick this up and learn it easily, it might do the same to you too.
Tons of fun with friends and nice strategy to defeat your foes!

Despite what the Internet may tell you, AoE 3 is much better than its predecessor. It is very different than 2:, there is one fewer resource, many units can only be built a limited number of times, there are foreign civilizations and/or trade routes on each map, and most of all, there's this weird card concept mixed in.

But all of these things serve to make the game more balanced. Just because the game is different doesn't make it worse. If you take the time to learn the new mechanics, it makes it much better.
i luv it

Great upgrade to a favorite series...AoE II might not have aged too well, but III is a welcome re-vamp.  Interesting new mechanics, great graphics for an RTS, and there's even a physics engine.  The sound effects are very lively, goes along great with the detail of the graphics and physics.  Some interface quirks, I wish we could have gotten the ability to zoom in and out, but in general no issues.

You can still see some of the nations here are still using bow and arrow, looks old school but it's very effective against the slow musketeers. 

Playing skirmish means that you are divided into 2 teams. In AOE 2, you can play alone and fight the rest of the enemies while they also fighting each others. But in AOE 3, if you try to fight alone you'll definitely gonna get crush by the enemies (exception when you play in easy mode and Free for All). A little advice, whenever you try to play skirmish make sure either France or British to be your ally, they build their armies faster and always in large. Sometimes I played this game with my neighbor with Hard level, we both fight againts 6 enemies at once. Very hard, but it's really fun.

I was expecting the same level of fun that the first two Age of Empires gave, but I didn't exactly recieve that. Let me just say that the game feels...small...in comparison to other games like it and to its own games. There are only a few unit types, the research and upgrades feel dull, the maps are a little weird, and the UI looks really bad for 2009. (Sure the UI shouldn't give the game a lower score but it is the one continous thing on your screen the whole time playing which can help you find buttons and/or match the game so it doesn't look out of place) Also there really is no strategy, as you just need a more researched army and big a economy. On top of this the Campaign is uninteresting and the weird home city hub never truly fascinated me. Nothing feels dynamic it all feels linear.And lastly the AI feels like it has an upper hand when I was playing on Normal, as their cities weren't as built up as mine for most of the game. Now here are the good parts about the game. Graphics are solid, Building Destruction is nice, Units speak in their native language, building management, and resource gathering is perfect.
My FINAL SCORE is, (5/10) I love rts games but this feels weak compared to past installments and other rts games. If this game was 20$ I would be happier but this costs 40$!! And this game feels way too short with little variety to keep the ages feeling bigger and last longer. Thank you for your time.

Age of Empires 3 is a great classic strategy game, it improves on the original Age of Empires concept of building a base, military units and gathering resources by allowing you to customise the civilizations with shipments, a new game mechanic which through gaining experience from building units and killing enemies can allow you to deliver shipments of reinforcements, resources or unique upgrades to units allowing you to develop your own strategy. The War chiefs and Asian Dynasties is the icing on the cake, adding new civilizations with unique game mechanics like native dancing pits as one example. The multiplayer is extremely competitive, if you are a fan of strategy games and you enjoy playing versus other players it is highly recommended. I would say the downfalls of this game would be the single player element and if you are new to the franchise the learning curve of this type of game is quite steep.

One of the best new features in AoEIII is unfortunately also the one that keeps me from enjoying it as much as I have enjoyed other games in the series. The introduction of the Home City was a pretty radical departure for the series, introducing persistent leveling to your favorite civilizations, with immediate and powerful gameplay modifications tailored by you to enhance and compliment your playstyle. On the one hand, this feature works great and is very enjoyable, as you pick and choose 'cards' before going into each match, which might upgrade your units, or your production, or they might give you free units, or unlock abilities. On the other hand, you'll quickly realize that each civilization has its own Home City and you have to play each and every one of them for dozens of matches if you want to competitively play all of them. If you have one or two favorite civs that you'll be playing all the time then that's no problem; you can focus on your favorites and be happy as a clam. If you enjoy playing them all though, and are a fan of the Random Civ option from previous games, then the removal of that feature and the introduction of persistence may irritate you.

Other than that, all I'd have to say is that this is a great RTS, with good campaigns, good civilization variety, artwork, music, sound design, gameplay, and scenario editor. Highly recommended.

-Civilizations are significantly different from each other

Cons:

-Expert AI needs to be made less predictable

[b]This review is a little lengthy, so if you just want to know why I recommend this game skip the [u]Results[/u] and read from there.[/b]

Age of Empires III not only lives up, but pushes forward the great series that is Age of Empires. Most people compare it as being weaker than its predecessor Age of Empires II, but I find that these people tend to not see the greatness in this game. It seems in this Age of Empires the game became more realistic, in that the Colonial Era was a point in time when no longer were kingdoms limited in wealth by the amount of gold they could mine. Instead it brings in new Cash Crops, which allow each nation to produce Gold outside of traditional methods. 

[b]Campaign:[/b]
This is a great game with an in-depth campaign that goes through the stories of a Scottish Explorer and his sons/daughters. The campaign is interesting and introduces different styles of gameplay from macro-managing to micro-managing with scavenging and hording. Definitely worth the play through, for Age of Empires III and Age of Empires III: War Chiefs. Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties is fun, but the campaign has nothing to do with either of the other two expansions. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Age of Empires III offers a brilliant combat system that no longer requires precise delegation of finite resources, but allows for macro-scale battle. Allowing some players to turtle and others to expand, depending on your gameplay you can grow or stay at home. Mining gold and gathering food will always garnish better results than farming gold and food. Not only can you focus different resource harvesting strategies, but you can also use different strategies in your combat choices. You can buy mercenaries which cost only gold, or even capture native towns and create tribal units. This can allow you to vary your tactics based on your environment as well as your team. 

[b]Teams:[/b]
This game introduces new challenges with Teams that are complex and highly differentiated, unlike in the predecessors where each team essentially was the same as the last minus a few shifts in upgrade options and one special unit (plus two special upgrades). Age of Empires III and its two expansions offer a variety of teams which include peoples of Europe, Americas, and Asia. Age of Empires III includes the Spanish, British, French, Portuguese, Dutch, Germans, Russians, and Ottomans. Age of Empires III: War Chiefs then offer three more teams including The Aztecs, Sioux, and Iroquois. Finally Age of Empires III: Asian Dynasties adds an additional three teams the Indians, Chinese, and Japanese. 

[b]Hints:[/b]
If you actually want to enjoy this game make sure you edit your cities in order to get all the cards, as earning all the cards takes more than one lifetime. I have owned all three of these games before they were on steam and I put over +300 hours into it still to not have one civilization at maximum level. 

[b]Results:[/b]
If you enjoy real time strategy games, enjoy managing an economy, epic large battles, and don't like excessive micromanaging then this is the game for you. It offers brilliant combat with amazing scenery. The unit mapping is rather brilliant and the variety of maps keeps you constantly wanting to play more. 

Pros:
+Fun campaign with a rather interesting story (for a strategy game).
+High level of variability in teams
+Allowing for turtle or rushing player types
+Good difficulty curve in AI (allowing boosting resource harvest rates to find the best balance of difficulty)
+Each civilization is like a whole new game
+On map bonuses to give reasons for exploring and moving quick across the map.
+Brilliant strategy diversification with special tribal towns on each map type, and special mercenary units for each map. 
+Many different types of gameplay which keep the skirmishes from seeming repetitive. 
+Loads of cards to choose from allowing you to choose if you want to Turtle, Rush, or Support. 

Cons:
-Leveling civilizations is rather dull (just edit the text file)
-You cannot select your AI team members’ cards, which means they will just use resource cards, villagers, and soldiers (not team cards).
-Some civilizations seem unbalanced. (figure it out for yourself as we all have our views on this).
-Rather than producing names for the map choices they are named after states (which can be really hard to guess what type of map you will get if you're not familiar with US Geography).
-You can only have two teams in skirmish mode, which is really annoying if you used to like playing 2v2v2v2. 
-You cannot have repeat civilizations; this means there is only one England per map.

Okay let's get things straight, YES this game isn't as good as Age of Empires II but it is still a very good game and it does one thing that every other age of empires games did aswell and is a must for these games and that it's simply addictive, you will keep playing and having fun with it even due you might notice some faults with the game. First of I think we should care about the story, ECH I liked the previous AoE games (<--- I'm calling it that for now) how it was based about historical events. Here it's some made up crap about the black family I couldn't give less of. The war chief campaign is slighty better cause it focus on historical events more due it still also focuses on the black family thingy. But the best one is the Asian Dynasties campaign that is completey historical, YES. This is how the AoE games was meant to be sad that One out of three campaigns is what I was looking for :(. And oh you focus on one country in the main campaign another thing that the AoE games didn't do they focused on multiply countries and history oh well. Atleast the historical book is back so I'm ok. Anyway presentation, FANTASTIC! Yeah the cutscenes were meh for me but I love the enviroment and I love the small details. I love that you army cheers after killing a enemy or destroying a enemy building, I love that you alley replies of hoping that you be better then last time and also comment of playing the same map twice. And I love how great they went from 2d sprites to 3d models. Gameplay, this isn't easy, ok. First of all formations are gone instead they auto formating which isn't too bad but tell me, WHY DID YOU HAVE TO REMOVE THE STANCES!? In AoE II you could put your soldiers on stances for example aggresive following a enemy or defensive stance that attacks it but doesn't chase it forever and stand ground were they're not allowed to move so ranged guards would work. Why isn't it here!? I have to force my soldiers to constantley move to the right so I don't attack. And there's more things removed from previous AoE games I won't even touch. However there is some features I like first of all home city, I like that. Doesn't make you abuse the market when you're low on something but rather ask for things from your country and then spam the market :). And the abilities due underplayed I really liked the idea. And if there is both ninjas and cowboys in the same game IT'S BLOODY GOOD OK!? I also really like how diffrent the expansion packs are from one another. The war chief has the converting ability.... exclusively to him :( and focus more on the wilderness and the asian dynaties FORCES you to build wonders to age up <--- THAT'S AWESOME. However the main problem is that they did nothing new..... NOTHING. The online uses the old login thing to microsoft that it did in the back in the day which I'm not even sure if it works, you can't SHIFT+TAB ever while you play at all and you can't acces the ''Complete collection'' if you use the desk shortcut you have to go to your libary and click play and chose Asian dynaties and then you get the complete collection and if you pick the War chief one only get that. I still like this game, yeah it's nothing compared to 2, it had no changes and it's a little bit easier but I still say that it's worth it but I would recommend buying this whenever it's on sale if you're unsure. I give it a 7.8/10.

Do NOT buy this game.  The UI is half-@ssed; another grind-for-gear fest.

= Graphics =
+ Water looks beautiful !
+ Ships are properly to scale -- they are BIG !
+ Physics for destroying buildings and units look great -- especially heavy artillery !
- Icons for buildings and units are extremely bland; ALMOST as bad as "Ultima Online."
- Every 3D model in game is "fully lit" making it hard to recognize things you CAN click on and things you CAN'T click on.  The artists didn't understand Contrast ratio nor S/N ratio -- it is TOO HARD to find when crates or bags of gold get delivered to your colony due to foreground objects blending into background objects.  See this excellent talk to understand how to do background + foreground + UI properly:
http://gdcvault.com/play/1015306/The-Art-of-Diablo

= Gameplay =
+ New card system is interesting
- You have to *grind* to unlock cards for EACH city and civilization  You can no longer select your civilization in multiplayer; you must first build a home city.   LAME.
- Teams are limited to 2 instead of 4 as in AoE2 so you can no longer have multiple, separate, computer teams.
- You can only reset your deck ONCE !?!? More grind-for-gear crap.
- Stone resource removed from the game. :-(
- Computer AI cheats like crazy in Hard and Expert. (See next post for details)

= UI =
* The default camera zoom is too close to the ground.  Change "Camera Zoom" to "Very Far" in "Game Options" to fix.
- Selecting a group no longer shows the individual health bars -- it is extremely hard to tell WHICH unit needs healing
- The UI chews up 1/3 of your screen (WHY??) unless you go into Options and turn on "Enable Minimized UI."  
- When you are unable to unlock a card the error message is too generic and doesn't tell you WHY.
- No "TEAM" icon next to cards to EASILY tell which cards benefit the team.
- Stupid default UI settings.  Why is "Show Gathers per Resource" OFF by default??
- The status bar at the top in AoE2 that was easy to read of resources summary has been moved to the clunky bottom UI where it blends in making it WAY too hard to read.
- Tooltips for buildings and units don't work if the item is in the queue.  *facepalm*
- There is no option to remember your password; 2013 and still no auto-login??
- Creating a multiplayer game with a password requires you press a retard "Password Protected" button IN ADDITION to typing in the password. Gee, how about using a -blank- password to determine if the game is password protected or not like every other online game??
- Can only have 9 groups instead of 20 in AoE2
- Can only have 50 units in a group instead of 75 as in AoE2
- Can only have 200 max population with no way to increase it.  This _IS_ 2013 and we have quad-core computers these days ... why can AoE2HD be patched to up the limit but this game can't?
- Hotkey for Flares was removed *sigh*
- You MUST _first_ create an ES Online account with the ORIGINAL game, THEN you can "upgrade" it with the Expansion.  LAME.
- The password box doesn't work in the original host game UNLESS you press the TAB key. LAME.

= Support =
MS Support are a bunch of R.E.T.A.R.D.S.  I misspelt my ES Online name and there is no way to either rename or delete your account !?!?  WTF is this ... 1977 ?

Edit: Fixed spelling mistakes, added note about computer AI cheating.
Edit.2 Valve censoring "re-tard" is lame.

GameSpot said it best: "Age of Empires III has some very big shoes to fill".

It is a very good game, and there are barely any real flaws to speak of, but I still prefer its predecessor, even though almost everything that was good about [i]Age of Empires II[/i] is improved here, most noticeably the A.I. and the graphics.

Perhaps the historical era covered by the game and its heavy focus on gunpowder in later stages isn't as compelling, and the scenario editor (which played a big part in [i]Age of Empires II[/i]'s prolonged success) is a little more complicated to use.

But the core gameplay, which is easy to understand, but hard to master, remains pretty much the same, with some interesting additions like the "Capital City" and the ability to choose different bonuses as you advance through the ages, a similar system to the one seen in [i]Age of Mythology[/i].

If you're a fan of the "[i]Age[/i]" series or you just enjoy well-designed, polished real-time strategy games, or are looking to get into the genre, [i]Age of Empires III[/i] is definitely worthy of your time and money.

Do you like video games? Do you like RTSs? Do you like not having to have 300 apm to keep a constant stream of resources coming in? Then you will like AoE 3. If you don't go hardcore or of Asian descent and play strategy games like a casual (like me) then you will also like this game. What I mean is that the macro from Age of Empires II was VERY watered down in AoE 3. Sure you still need some form of it like all RTSs, but the amount has dropped very much so. And I LOVE gunpowder units. Nothing is more satisfying then seeing 100+ musketiers poppin caps in each other like this is Chicago. 

The addition of Home City shipments is another feature that I like. Basically you choose around 20 shipments (they are cards that you put into a deck and you pick new cards everytime you level your home city) gain experience from various actions and once you accumulate enough you gain the ability to call in a shipment to your town center. Cards are also Age related and most can only be used once. The cards can range from calling in military units, villagers, economic shipments and buildings, and upgrades for many different things. And some cards affect all your allies. There is a lot of different strats you can go with a deck.

As I mentioned earlier you have Home Cities for each civ. Basically when you first start the game you choose which Civilization you want to be, then you choose your home city name and your explorer name ( you can put any name you want for both, great feature ) then you go into a game. You gain exp as you finish games, gaining levels for your city. Then you can unlock new cards. Some cards are locked until later levels ( it goes something like 10>25>40 I think) but from what I have since they aren't that much better, still useful though. If you want to play a different civ you have to make another home city for them and can also name that anything you want, along with the explorer, starting back at level one ( Unless you play the DLC, for some odd reason you start at level 10 with 10 unlocks. So just play the Asian DLC since it has everything for the other one and the base game.) Each Civ has different cards available at the start and to unlock although about half are universal.

Onto the gameplay it is mostly the same as AoE 2. With the addition of Trade Routes and Native camps (which supply extra resources and unlocks special respectively) it adds some degree of map control. There probably was already map control on AoE 2 but I know little of how the meta is for it. If there was I'm sure trade routes and native camps add even more since the extra resources are a huge bonus ( They start off giving only Exp and can be upgrade 3 times with the last being a train, another feature I like. And the free exp is HUGE to getting early home shipment points) and natives can harass early on. Natives also don't add to pop limit but you can only train a certain amount. Having more than half of all the trade posts and native camps gives you the option to start a Trade monopoly victory, which gives you victory in 5 minutes if they don't destroy any trade posts/native camps, helps if the enemy is turtling hard. You also can only build one castle and thats from a shipment you get (Russians can build more I believe). And if the wagon it starts off as gets destory you don't get another. Stone was also removed as a resource. Also, cannons and muskets. Pretty much the two man things you will build, or at least for me. Still plenty of archers, cavalry, swordmen, pikemen, etc. A lot of civs have more than one special unit, and they aren't built from the castle only. The population cap is set at 200 and that has mixed feelings but I'm fine with it. The graphics are great even though I run it on low. Haven't played the campaign nor the multiplayer, just skirmishs.

Overall, a great game and a must buy for any RTS fan. Even if it is slightly watered down from AoE 2 the new additions to it and time setting are amazing, great gameplay, and good graphics.

40 dollars though? Damn, definitely worth at at any sales price, but who even buys triple A games over 30? Still worth it at 40.

I was heartbroken to hear Microsoft disbanded Ensemble Studios.  I loved Age of Empires 1, 2, AND 3 but I loved 3 the most.  I still love AoE 3 and here's why:

First of all, the game has a good mix of ranged units vs melee vs cavalry vs Artillery.  Where other games usually boil down to "create as many units as possible and overwhelm the enemy", that kind of strategy doesn't really cut it in AoE 3.  You might win, but it'll take you far more resources to do so.  Judicious use of your forces will make them last longer and perform better.  

Secondly, the emphasis on the home cities gives you something to work for even between skirmish matches.  Normally, every skirmish would be completely isolated from the overall game, but by levelling up your home city, you can provide better "shipments" to your settlers in future games.

Third, and this is probably where most people diverge in their opinions: The explorer as a sort of "hero" unit, and various minor enemies to fight for bonuses along the way, gives the game more of Warcraft III feel to it.  Without these little distractions you would just grind your way to the 4th age, create mass amounts of units and slaughter the enemy every time.   Now you have a choice: do you want to chance fighting the bears to get that special unit?  Maybe if you attack those pirates the treasure will give you a nice boost?

Lastly: all the enemies have a nice personality to them that makes me enjoy crushing them and sometimes (with them as allies) makes me laugh at the way they choose to attack.  Others make me sad to have been put on the same team (Henry the Navigator, you wuss!)

Mostly though, the game has actually aged pretty well in my opinion.  I know the game is almost 9 years old now, but it still holds up as worth buying and worth playing.  That is just talking about the base game... there's 2 whole expansions in this package I haven't really gotten into!

My favorite nation to fight as?  The Dutch... for some reason by late game I always feel like I'm controlling everything with all that coin flowing in.  It's really awesome.

You guys have got to get this! Its friggin amazing! The multiplayer has brilliant progression system. (selecting special abilities from a deck of unlocked cards to personalise your play style.) The building in this is quite unique in that you can place your structures anywhere, there is no 'grid' placement. The destruction is entirely satisfying; watching cannons blow appart a building and the peices cascade over the landscape BLEW MY MIND! No more generic, repeated destruction animation! The customisation of your home city was an a great surprise! A fantastic reward for leveling up and a great backdrop for the menu screens. Additionally I dont really mind the fewer races, as there are so many units in each. What I would have liked to see is the unit formations buttons from age of empires II, allowing you to alter the positions of your army better. Additionally the stance buttons to prevent your army running off would be great to implement. 4.2 out of 5, im addicted already!
This Game Is a Classic! Highly Recomend it.

I know many who love the original Age of Empires games (especially #2) hate this game or mock it for not being like the others. I grew up on Age of Empires 2 and it remains to be one of my favourite games of all time. Unlike the others I love this game as much, maybe even more, for fixing the small issues in the other games and generally making a more polished product.  The campaigns are more exciting and the combat more visceral. The expansions add many new civilizations with a whole new set of playstyles the likes of which the franchise hasn't seen before! The point of this short review is to convince people that the naysayers are wrong and that this product is the perfect swan song for Ensemble Studios.

Pros :
This is absolutely a fun strategy time-sink. Many hours haven't even been logged on Steam for my current account due to owning two accounts with AoE3 on it. Since good RTS seem limited to Starcraft and Warcraft, I like more realism and history than a fantasy universe. The art and graphics (if that is your main focus) are beautiful. Units work create formations which I have always enjoyed in a RTS. Gathering materials is pretty basic, wood, gold, food, and balancing everything is not too stressful which is great for any strategy game. I also enjoy the way the different difficulties are set. Easy being easy enough to learn and still win and Normal seeming challenging. There is a sandbox mode which is great for people learning the game as well and dont wish to focus on combat.

For single player, Age of Empires 3 has a genius combination of history, customization, and RTS. I make myself sick of this game and even if I stop for a few months I WILL be back.

Cons (without bias) :
Let me start with the warning alert. Over and over you will hear this as long as you are being attacked and not watching that area. It causes me to mute my game when there are multiple battles. Not fun.
It seem frusturating laggy during combat and this is because of units being in formation. Getting used to a combination of different unit speeds makes you break up your selection. Being that realistic is not fun to a lot of people. Single player doesn't hold your hand during the "tutorial" portion. They expect you to know a bit about RTS already.
The ships are terrible in huge groups which they make up for in speed. This is for both you and the enemy so it may seem that they pop up on you very quickly.
It is a great game. It remains faithful to its predicessor's real time gameplay while adding another layer of strategy with the persistent home city feature.

THERE ARE NO MODS TO FIX THESE EITHERl I scoured AOE heaven, etc. modding sites and they got some shitty mods (no offense; I look for historical qualities).

Bottom line: if you're just looking to play a game for fun and not care about if you're getting those good looking redcoats/prussian mercs/etc. just like in the actual Revolutionary War or any kind of quality then I recommend.

Personally I never owned AoE3 growing up and coming to it later on I can say it has not aged particularly well.
Unlike the new AoE2:HD release, increasing the resolution unfortunately does not allow you to see more. Usually this is typical of competitive RTS games in order to keep the playing field even. Unfortunately how much is shown to you on screen is limited at best, especially when groups of units grow beyond the screen size, a particular issue when moving across a map with multiple unit types of varying speeds. 

AoE3 sports a more to-ground camera perspective causing vision to be obscured by walls or buildings to a far greater degree than the other AoE games. Not helping this is how the buildings are absolutely massive (houses are huge!) while this might make it seem like your town is more impressive than it is, navigating your town in a pinch can be very fiddly.

Combat is unbalanced and to be fair, pretty broken. units can be queued but are all produced on the same timer. For example you can make 1 musketeer, or 5 at once in the same time. This all but removes the need to spend any resources until you need them. Most games I find end very quickly both online and against a computer.

Unlike AoE3, the only realistic way to win is through combat, immeditae and unrelenting combat, removing a large portion of what an AoE game means to me. Naval combat has however improved significantly over previous installments, sporting a wide range of galleons and some very pleasing combat animations and damage manifesting visually through holes, masts falling and other immersive effects in constrast to AoE2's all-purpose flames.

Overall I cannot recommend this game however I can see how it could appeal to those looking for a more basic RTS than is typically offered by the AoE franchise.

Age of Empires 3 is the third and (seemingly) final game in the Age of Empires series. If you  don't know already, it's a traditional real-time-strategy game set in the colonial and imperial ages of European history, with a little of flair of Asia for kicks. Although Age of Empires games traditionally feature a very strong campaign, the replay factor in AOE is always the multiplayer and skirmish options, and this time players are given a multitude of options to suit their gameplay preferences. As a "turtle" (high defense, weak offense) player, I especially like the "treaty" mode, which turns off combat for a set number of minutes at the beginning of each round and also forces players to build their base within a confined space during that time period. As with previous games in the series, AoE3 features 4 different "age" milestones that allow your civilization to access new technologies and units.

[u][b]The Good:[/b][/u]

* Trading cards enabled.

* Different civilizations, especially those from different continents, have entirely separate styles of play, giving the game different "flavors" of play and replayability.

* Rather than just giving each civilization unique units and technologies, AOE3 takes "Uniqueness" a step further by giving every play 21 "bonus cards," which can be used to dramatically alter your play choices. Two players can conceivably play as the same civilization and require completely different strategies and playstyles due to the bonuses given to them by their cards.

* Vastly more multiplayer options than the predecessors in the series.

* Some Civs, such as the Sioux, are fairly simplistic. This is a positive attribute as it allows differently-skilled players to enjoy the game in their own way.

* There is a "home city building" side-game that is a little enjoyable.

[u][b]The Bad:[/b][/u]

* I feel like a game that supports 1000+ units on the screen and 1920x1080 resolution should let me zoom the map out a bit further. My town center annoyingly takes up way too much of my view!

* No Steam achievements.

* Antiquated map controls - the only way to scroll the map is by moving your cursor to the edge of the screen. RTS games should support WASD map scrolling and/or click 'n' drag.

* The final "age" is rarely ever needed in a match, and costs more than it benefits your team, in my opinion.

* Map-editing is nowhere near as easy and intuitive as it was in previous AOE games.

* Weak AI. It seems like a 1 vs. 1 AI opponent always focuses strictly on cavalry, which in turn focuses me to only focus on building one type of unit.


[u][b]The Ugly:[/b][/u]

* Horribly WRONG launcher screen. When starting the game, you are given the choice of loading (a) Age of Empires III: Complete Collection, (b) Age of Empires III: The War Chiefs, and (c) Age of Empires III: Asian Dynasties. However, option "A" is not complete at all: choosing it gives you access to [i]neither[/i] of the two expansions. Option B gives you access to the War Chiefs Expansion (but not Asian Dynasties), and Option C gives you access to ALL game content: the base game and both expansions.

* Not as fun as AOE2. A sequal should be a step forward, not a step back. The differences are noticeable in all sorts of small areas, which individually would not be a problem, but lend to an overall diminished quality. Some examples are unit formations being nowhere near as "tight," and units having a tendency to WALK into battle if they are grouped with a slower unit.

[u][b]The Verdict:[/b][/u]

* At the time of this writing, the base price for AO3 is $39.99. That is overpriced, especially since AO2-HD is a more solid and overall better game and comes for the same base price. [i]However[/i], I do think AOE3 is worth checking out if you can get it on sale. I have had a lot of fun with this game, perhaps 100 hours or so, before it ever became available on Steam. But now that AO2-HD has come out, I see little reason to play AO3.

Age of Empires 3 takes an already established concept, and expands and improves it greatly.  The game features "cards" -upgrades that you can send whenever you reach another experiance tier.  Cards allow you to specialize your nations units, which are sharded between all of the nations, with one or two expections.  There are also playstyle differences between nations, with the ottomans getting free yet slow settlers, or the duty settlers costing gold instead of food.  The core gameplay is similar to AoE 2, other then this new card mechanic and trading posts.  Trading posts can be built on trade routes or on Indian villages.  Both of them are worth it.  Trade routes supply you with either resources or exp, and indian villages grant you powerful units and upgrades.  

Overall, it is better then AoE 2, the card system is unique, and it is worth getting.

The Age of Empires series has always been a personal favorite of mine. Dating back to the first AOE I i've been always astonished by the overall gameplay experience this game delivers. The AI system is very well written and, depending on the difficulty, will always provide a challenge. This game is often compared to Starcraft II yet there is a lot of differences between them. In Starcraft I always found myself rushing and trying to be the best, and if you were bad at the game, you were in for a lot of stress. But in AOE players can find servers with their own skill level which makes this game one of my favorite strategy games. 

In my opinion, you don't HAVE to play online like most competitive games. This game actually has a very good Skirmish mode where you go against bots. It may seem boring but if you give it a chance, it will not disappoint you. As for aesthetics, the graphics are great considering it was a game made in 2009 but this is just a small factor since the game's mechanics draw you away from noticing. There is rarely glitches, units walk with great animation, and the battle scenes have you urging to see what team will win. 

The only downfall the game has is that there is no cross-platform multiplayer support and it lacks an intriguing storyline. It is common for an AOE game to have a blan or boring storyline. And you can see that when looking at its predecessors. But don't let this change your opinion. The game wasn't really made with a basis on heartwarming or intense storyline experiences but more of a play-with-friends or AI and just have a great time.

Overall, I wish they made a AOE 4. Their progression from each Age of Empires have only been big leaps in the gaming industry. But I will happily settle for AOE 3 and look forward to playing it many, many years from today. If you are in to strategy games like StarCraft, Warcraft, and Command & Conquer, this is no doubt a game worth adding to your arsenal!

Age of Empires makes a comeback by jumping forward to the Imperial Era. Cannons, muskets, armed cavalries, large vessels and more cannons present a change of pace from the old sword-and-shield Age of Empires II. The third instalment of the franchise also introduces trading routes, a set of locations that you have to capture and control by building trading posts on it, reinforcing your income and XP gain. You can order shipments of goods from your mainland at intervals of time and befriend local indigenous tribes.

In a sense, there are plenty of new features to keep long time fans of Age of Empires interested, while retaining the same core gameplay. Build stuff, gather stuff, advance Ages, kill baddies. Only this time, with more cannons.

This game is too limited in number of resources on the board at the same time. But unlike some games that make this wokr (like Warcraft 3), this RTS doesn't do the job of making this game interesting.

This is one of the most fantastic strategy games I have played in ages.
The Pros:
-Extreme variation, so many units, all custom tailored to each of the many civs
-The home city system adds a persistent set of bonuses, many of which are interesting and unique
-Detailed buildings, cannonballs will actually knock beams and such off of an attacked building
-Infinite replayability, several campaigns, gamemodes and so on
The Cons:
-Multiplayer is sort of a pain to work out
-Balance is non-existent

So basically, if you want a fun strategy game with tons to do and see, this game is for you. If you are looking for competitive online matches, try Starcraft, because you will not see anyone playing this as an esport anytime soon. Hell, the idea of the almost entirely melee, wall-less commanche player facing off against someone playing Russia with their steep stone walls and millions of cheap rifle conscripts makes me laugh heartily.
