Age of Empires III was one of the few strategy games that I played through every campaign.  There are definatly some awful story lines and arcs (The entire 1st game), but you almost have to play it to make sure you get a good foundation for the first and second expansions.  

The main campaign has you following the story of one family from the turkish invasion of Malta too finding settling the west.  A ton of liberties are taken with history in this campaign(Defeating a russian army in the wilderness...).  Ultimately you find yourself in a base building spree attempting to defeat your enemies.  Some variance in mission structure is provided throughout the game to make it a little more interesting.

If you only had 10 hours though I would start on the second campaign, which follows the son of one of the first members of the family.  As you play as the native american you actually engage in the history of the era's that the game represents.  There are some memorable battles such as Trenton, and Little big horn(!) to relieve during the expansion, and it definatly makes it worth it to stick it out.

But, then there is, 'The Asian Dynasties,' which I looked at and said, "How could they link these two games together in one cohesive story?"  The answer is they don't!  And really for the better as each campaign follows seperate leaders as they conquer, explore, or rebel against their enemies.  Ultimately I feel like the AOE series saved one of my favorite campaigns for last in the Indian one.  In the indian campaign you play as a soldier who must choose between military loyality and nationalism for his home land.  The resulting campaign is fun and gives you some level of purpose on building up bases and fighting your enemy.
Love it!

I had forgotten just how good this game was. Like many people i'd bought it years ago, only to find my playing days cut short thanks to it being incompatible with Windows Vista onwards. Not any more! I can confirm the Steam version works perfectly on my Windows 8.1 Pro 64-bit system.

Fans of the first two games will immediately be able to dive straight in, although there have been some major changes in the third installment compared to the first two. Firstly there's not so much emphasis on micro management now. Instead you get to concentrate on the exploration and battle elements, which makes this game the most enjoyable of the three. Secondly there is the new home city section which allows you to ship units and supplies to the new world during the game. Between games you can customise your home city to change which units and supplies can be sent out to you, along with the appearance of the city itself.

Visually this game absolutely trounces the two previous games, and indeed almost any other game in the genre, it is graphically amazing. Sound-wise it's not much different to the first two, with the sound being good but not excellent, and not too intrusive. The campaign isn't too difficult, so the greater challenge will come from skirmish games (rather like Age of Mythology... indeed all previous comparisons to the first two Age of Empires games also apply to Age of Mythology).

If you did not have this game before, you really owe it to yourself to buy it now that the compatibility problems have been sorted out and it works fine on Windows 8, 7 and presumably Vista as well. If, like me, you already had this game but could not play it because of those compatibility problems, well i can now confirm that those problems have been solved! This game deserves to be in everyone's collection.

One of the least respected Age of Empires games, Age III has a lot to offer in terms of depth, strategy, and of course some kick ass graphics.  Using an innovative card system, Age III lets you build a deck of cards that you can use during game to give your fledgling empire a small advantage wether it be a squadron of troops or boxes of resources.  Check it out, It's not as good as Age II, but it's one of my favorites.

Incredibly fun, and with a much smaller learning curve than other RTS games (*ahem* Dota 2). Also, the System Requirements are a lie, the real ones are here: http://www.eso.com/system_requirements_xp.aspx (it runs fine on Windows 7 by the way).

Age of Empires III, is by far my most favorite RTS game of all time. It is a well balanced masterpiece with plenty to do that will keep you busy for hours. Well balanced as in, it has that mixture to where it isn't too militaristic. You spend a lot of time improving your economy. Between building your Empire, leveling and customizing your home city, and developing new technologies, you'll be hard crossed to go to bed at a decent time. It has multiplayer, thirty or so maps, a scenario editior, and twelve unique nations ranging from the powerful British Empire to the traditional Japanese. This game is beautiful, even on my potato battery laptop. I've been in love with this game since 2005. I lost my retail copy so i was thrilled when it was added to the Steam Store. MANY more people should know about this game. It has tons of depth, and is one of the few games from Microsoft i love. Do yourself a favor, and buy this game! It is most certainly worth the hefty price tag!

A true classic strategy game, a really fun game that can be played with as much game immersion as you want; either simply fulfill the main objectives of a mission or explore the entire map, every treasure, every enemy holding, every detail is yours to dominate and exploit for your own profit... oh wait did I get a bit too involved there? Any way, its a great game, a pillar in the turn based strategy game genre, a game that should have a place of honor in everyone's game library.

Still better than [i]Age of Empires 2[/i].

Strike one for imperialism.

Looks nice, sounds nice, cannons are a great feature, has a working online service, trading cards, steam hours counting, *breathes*, all the DLC you might have missed in the old days, great 3-tiered base campaign which follows a families lineage. 

Takes place in the times of exploration, which is a nice departure from ancient times.

The simplification of some game features were hit or miss, some were niceties, others just are too simple. An example of one that was a miss was the removal of individual farm squares, and collection buildings, although it can be assumed that it is automated, it still seems too simple.

Has a nice variety of units, although, the crossbowmen seem kind of weaksauce when I got Janissaries with guns and cannons so big they can be used for artillery. Its let hack and slash, blow for blow of some other strategy games, and more so the style of "you mess up, you just might die".

Price is a little on the high side however, and if you can get it cheaper than $40, I would whole heartidly recommend it.

I have been playing Age of Empires series since I was very young. When I saw that this collection of third game has appeared on Steam, I didnt hesitate with getting it.

Age of Empires III is a real time strategy game set into colonizing the New World to industrial revolution. Game is divided into Campaign, Skirmish mode and Multiplayer. 

Campaign is divided into 3 parts for each expansion and vanilla game.

In single player skirmish you fight against AI in randomly created maps. After game you gain experience for your home town and get better units and upgrades. It has kind of appealing RPG like system to keep you playing. 

Multiplayer is practically same except that you cannot use your home cities and profiles from skirmish to keep the game balanced. Even that I must warn you. Multiplayer is filled with veterans and very experienced players. I recommend to host game with your friends to enjoy the best experience.

I personally prefer the first two AoE games to this one, but it's still worth a look. The gameplay and UI is completely different, though. You still have population caps, but individual troop types use different amounts of space; i.e. cavalry use 2 pop, cannons use 3-6, etc. You also can't dominate games with infinite towers, or massive ocean fleets, like in the other games. Buildings have caps as well, and you can only build a certain amount of each ship type; i.e. 8 galleons, 4 cannon ships, etc. 

I wouldn't advise buying the game unless you can get the complete set, as the base title feels like an incomplete demo. Unlike the first two games, this one only has a single campaign for each title, which is disappointing. But the new game features, units, and civs make this title a great next step in the series. Cons aside, this is a good game to add to your collection.

There are few RTS games I really like. Age of Empires has always been one of them. When you can't seem to get into RTS games like Command & Conquer, but want an RTS game to play without having to settle for the Turn-based appeal of a game like Civilization, Age of Empires is the game for you. If you want a game where there are actual strategic benefits to turtling, Age of Empires is the game for you. If you want to play an RTS game and actually be able to stand a chance against the highest level of AI... Well, that all depends on your skill in RTS games, but if you suck in games like Command & Conquer, you might actually be better suited for a game like Age of Empires. While not as good as Age of Empires II, Age of Empires III is severely underrated for just how good it is. I'd recommend it to any gamer, RTS player or otherwise.

AoE é um jogo especial para mim. Embora não tenha jogado o primeiro, AoE 2 foi a minha primeira experiência realmente intensa nos pcs: o primeiro game que me dediquei de fato na nossa querida plataforma. Foi uma grande satisfação quando vi AoE 3 disponível no Steam. Assim como o 2, o 3 também joguei bastante. Contudo, à época, joguei as versões piratas. O legal era que, mesmo sendo pirata, conseguíamos jogar on line. Comprei AoE 3 aqui no Steam em retribuição aos momentos de diversão que me proporcionou no passado (e também por saudosismo). O jogo é um ótimo rts, que permite várias práticas estratégicas. As civilizações são realmente muito distintas umas das outras, cada qual com sua árvore evolutiva própria, o que permite aproveitar o game a partir de várias possibilidades de combates diferentes.  Interessante é que ainda hoje ele possui gráficos muito bons. Ademais, é possível achar na net sites com mapas, campanhas, civilizações e outros mods que acrescentam bastante conteúdo free. Enfim, aconselho a todos que gostem de construir cidades, evolui-las, formar exércitos e ir para o fronte de batalha colocar em prática suas estratégias.

Ensemble Studios has always developed very great games. This one is no exception. This game out of the whole series has the best story-line that you will find out of every Age of Empires game released to date. That may be taken lightly when you take into consideration the past games that they have released. It is much more in depth than prior games released but it still hold a fairly strong story-line based primarily in the colonial days of course.I personally believe that this game was designed mostly towards the multi-player or skirmish modes. 

The multi-player mode takes you online to a RTS (real time strategy) game where its do or die! With a small but dedicated cut-throat community you dont know who you'll end up running into face to face. With hundreds of customizations towards several very unique civilizations you'll basically never run out of things to upgrade. For a dedicated RTS PC player this is a must buy. With options to upgrade your calvery, infantry, and even ballistic attack units there is too much room for any possibility to happen. When all hope seems lost you or your teammate makes a sudden dash for the enemies TC (town center) and then all is well and victory nis yours. For me, there is nothing better  than inflicting a crushing blow to your enemy and watching his economy collapse from the heavy beating you just put on them. The ranking stucture is strict but very precise. If you're a level 6 private than sticking to people level 0-11 is probably your best bet. Theres more to the game than just ground units. You have the option to form a navy that will rival the famous Queen Elizabeth's navy. 

The game has a beautiful but dated graphics engine that will please most gamers of this generation. Personally, I'm not here for that reason. I'm here for gameplay. With that said I must say that this Age of Empires game satisfies my RTS desires. If this game is on sale buy it! If it's regular price then I advise you to BUY IT.

My wife, siblings and I play this all the time, and have been on a rather consistent basis for upwards of a year. The gameplay is quite balanced, as each civilization has their own unique strengths and weaknesses.

Connecting a multiplayer game across the web is an absolute nightmare; I host my own Minecraft and Terraria servers all the time, but this game refuses to cooperate for more than two people. The only way we've been able to do it is via Hamachi, and by overriding the IP address the game uses in a txt file. Unfortunately this disables internet play, but we don't use that at all.

Despite the half-baked multiplayer connection functionality, the game itself is extremely immersive, and the computer AI poses a fun challenge for all of us. This is an excellent pick for anyone who enjoys RTS games, and comes with a little bonus of historical figures tossed into the mix.

One of the best RTS games for me! Great graphics, soundtrack and gameplay. Online is still pretty active and competetive. You get the core game, War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties where you can play for 3 different civilizations - Japan, China and India. I found China to be the most interesting, Japan in the middle and India most boring, but still good enough. First two games are about Black family. I really like gathering resources in this game and then preparing military for some great battles that lie ahead. Highly recommended to all strategy fans out there! :)

The campaigns of this game are great. A lot longer than most rts games and the storylines are pretty good. The gameplay gets alittle repetitive after awhile. I would recommend this game to any rts lover.

great game for people who like strategy and simulation games but is difficult to fully master all civs. Since each one is different from eachother and has their own streighths and weakness that you will have to be careful to protect and use. Each unit is highly detailed if you have the computer for it along with the maps and buildings. Each map has different terrian, natives that you can ally with, and treasures you can collect. The map creator is difficult to understand but once mastered you can create amazing levels and scenarios you can play with friends. It's not cheap but was worth every penny for me.

Essential for RTS fans. AOE leans more towards offense and military developement more than maintaining a population and defending your city -- that is, if you want to progress. However, you can't select over a certain amount (50+?) of troops though - WHY?

If you enjoy RTS games and/or the Revolutionary Era, you will love this. This game has Native American nation-tribes that you can command, along with European and Asian ones.

The campaigns are much deeper and specially created as campaigns, not only scripted content available elsewhere in the game, though some of it is.

The ships are scaled much more accurately, so a ship in AOE 3 can dwarf the dock and smaller ships.

 I could go on and on, but obviously I really love this game!

One of the few great RTS games, AoE3 provides a lot of eye candy as different civs are "aged" up and improved by player experience.  The styles of the buildings and units as well as advantages and disadvantages based on civilization choice give the game great in-game appeal and replay value.  The "helper" tribes, railroads, and indigenous fauna contribute to both strategy and immersion.  To me, this is a great solitaire or casual multiplayer game.

I have been a fan of Age of Empires since it first came out. I have two accounts and I will pay for the game again if I had to. This is probably the best game ever made (not many people play it) but it is sure entertaining and never gets old. You can be playing for hours in one single game and have fun. I had multiple nights playing 4-5hrs in one single game is insane. If your thinking of getting this game..trust me is worth it. It takes some time to get used to but the community will help you along the way. Can you imagine playing 8 players in a map and all of them are real players? My stats show about 3500+ games played now that tells you something. Since it came to steam I am more excited as more new players will play. This game is now considered "old" but trust me the graphics are good for this day in age.

Writing this much about a game can tell you something. Trust me...BUY IT!
